questions.text:
A G2P2A0L1 woman has a history of a stillborn baby who looked like the one given in the image below after the birth. In which conditions does sensitization of the mother's immune system occur leading to the following outcome?
  1. Delivery of O+ve infant by a O-ve mother. 
  2. Abdominal trauma
  3. Amniocentesis 
  4. Abruptio placenta
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Rh alloimmunization. The given image is that of hydrops fetalis. The correct answer is 1, 2, 3, 4.

Rh alloimmunization occurs when an Rh-negative mother produces antibodies to Rh antigens due to an Rh-positive fetus. 

Alloimmunization occurs in two stages. First, sensitization occurs during the first pregnancy, then the immunization occurs. Sensitization occurs during situations of fetomaternal bleeds. Examples of these situations include miscarriage, amniocentesis, embryoreduction, ectopic pregnancy, hydatidiform mole, cordocentesis, placenta previa with bleeding, abruption of placenta, intrauterine fetal demise, external cephalic version, abdominal trauma, and delivery of an Rh-positive infant to an Rh-negative mother. It can also occur during the third stage of labor, manual removal of placenta, and after a cesarean section. 

Rh immunization can be prevented if the mother is unimmunized. Here, she is given Rh anti-D immunoglobulin (IgG) intramuscularly after childbirth. This blocks the Rh-antigen of the fetal cells, removal of the intact, antibody-coated fetal red cells from circulation by the spleen or lymph nodes, and inhibits the production of IgG from the B cells. 

It should ideally be administered within 72 hours or preferably earlier after delivery or abortion. The dose can be calculated using the Kleihauer-Betke test. 

The antibodies formed as a result of immunization are IgM and IgG. However, only IgG antibodies are small enough to cross the placenta and cause hemolytic disease in the fetus. The three manifestations of the hemolytic disease include hydrops fetalis, icterus gravis neonatorum, and congenital anemia of the newborn. 

Hydrops fetalis (Option B) is the most severe form of Rh hemolytic disease in the fetus. There is widespread erythrocyte destruction leading to anemia, anoxemia, and metabolic acidosis. This leads to hepatic injury, causing hypoproteinemia and subsequently generalized edema, ascites, and hydrothorax. 

The following image shows a stillborn baby with hydrops fetalis.

questions.text: A patient with chronic cholestasis, after recovery, is completely asymptomatic. Laboratory reports show high total serum bilirubin levels but urine is negative for bilirubin at this phase. What is this due to?

choices.text: Indiect bilirubin which is bound to albumin.
Direct bilirubin which is bound to albumin.

questions.solution:
The likely cause of the patient's high bilirubin values is direct bilirubin which is bound to albumin also known as delta bilirubin.

Usually in cholestatic jaundice, direct (conjugated) bilirubin is excreted in the urine. But in some cases of prolonged cholestasis, hepatic excretion of direct bilirubin decreases and direct bilirubin combines with albumin. This form of direct bilirubin which is bound to albumin is known as delta bilirubin. It is formed in the serum when hepatic excretion of bilirubin glucuronides is impaired, causing an accumulation of glucuronides in the serum.

Because it is bound to albumin, its half-life increases to 12-14 days (normal half-life of bilirubin is 4hrs). Because of this, even after recovery, the patient's blood reports may show high bilirubin. Also, this is a form of direct bilirubin which is not excreted in urine because it is bound to albumin hence urine examination will show false negative results.

questions.text: A gastro surgeon performs a procedure shown below on a patient with extrahepatic biliary atresia. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The Kasai procedure or Roux-en-Y hepato-porto-enterostomy is shown in the image.

It is done for all types of extrahepatic biliary atresia. It involves the excision of all extrahepatic bile duct remnants up to the liver capsule and the gallbladder. Following this, a Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is mobilised and anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

Other options:

Option B: Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is used as bariatric surgery where a small proximal gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature of the stomach and a roux limb of 75 - 150 cm (jejunum) is created by anastomosing the proximal jejunum to the gastric pouch and, a shorter biliary/biliopancreatic limb of 30 - 50 cm (consisting duodenum and proximal jejunum) is anastomosed to the roux limb via side to side jejunojejunostomy.

Option C: Billroth II loop gastrojejunostomy, two-thirds of the stomach is removed, the duodenal stump is closed and the stomach is anastomosed to the jejunum. It helps to re-establish gastrointestinal continuity following antrectomy for complicated peptic ulcer disease.

Option D: Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas. It is done only in cases when:

  • The entire duodenum has to be removed e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)
  • Tumour encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach
  • A clear resection margin is not achieved by pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy

The following structures are removed during this procedure:

  • Distal stomach
  • Duodenum
  • Proximal jejunum
  • Head of the pancreas
  • Gallbladder
  • Common bile duct (CBD)
  • Regional lymphatics

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple erosions on the skin and oral mucosa. Skin biopsy shows the following findings. Which of the following is the mainstay of treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic row of tombstones appearance seen in Pemphigus vulgaris. Systemic corticosteroids are considered the mainstay of this condition. However, systemic antibiotics, IVIG, and plasmapheresis are also used in the treatment of pemphigus.

The suprabasal epidermal cells separate from the basal cells to form clefts and blisters, while the basal cells remain attached to the basement membrane, in a row of tombstones on the floor of the blister.

Pemphigus is a group of chronic immunobullous disorders, that are characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal proteins expressed in the skin and mucous tissue.

Desmosomal proteins like desmogleins 1 and 3 help in cell-cell adhesion and form the structure of the desmosome. In the epithelium, desmoglein 1 is mostly seen in all layers, while desmoglein 3 is more in the lower layers. In the oral mucosa, desmoglein 3 is seen in all layers and desmoglein 1 is present at low levels. 

Clinical features of pemphigus vulgaris are:

  • Oral lesions: Ill‐defined, irregular, slow to heal, erosions extending peripherally along with shedding of the epithelium.
  • Mucosal lesions: Occur in conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, esophagus, urethra, vulva or cervix
  • Cutaneous lesions:
    • Occur in the scalp, face, neck, upper chest and back.
    • Flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid, contents may become turbid
    • Either arise on normal skin or an erythematous base
    • Rupture of blisters producing painful erosions
    • Healing occurs without scarring
    • Pigmentary change may occur in resolving lesions.
  • Nail dystrophies, acute paronychia and subungual hematomas are common
  • Phenotypic and immunological conversion from pemphigus vulgaris to foliaceous or vice versa may occur, occasionally.
  • Effect on pregnancy: Deteriorate in pregnancy and the puerperium, with severe pemphigus associated with fetal prematurity and death.

The features associated with the common variants of pemphigus are:

Type of pemphigus Cutaneous distribution Mucosal involvement Lesions
Pemphigus
vulgaris		 - Scalp, face, chest, upper trunk
- May be generalized

- Oro‐pharynx, conjunctiva, genital

 

- Flaccid blisters
- Erosions
- Flexural vegetations
Pemphigus
vegetans		 - Flexural aspects

- Oro‐pharynx, conjunctiva, genital

- Vegetating plaques
- Vesicles
- Pustules
- Erosions
Pemphigus
foliaceous		 - Scalp, face, chest, upper back, seborrheic areas
- May be generalized 		 - None  - Scaly papules
- Crusted erosions
- Erythroderma 
Paraneoplastic
pemphigus 		 - Upper body
- Palmoplantar 		 - Severe mucositis - Polymorphous       bullae
- Erosions
- Target lesions

 The image given below shows the lesions seen in pemphigus foliaceous.

 

The image below shows the lesions seen in pemphigus vegetans.

Acantholysis and cell apoptosis are the key pathological processes in pemphigus. Histological changes include:

  • Intercellular edema with loss of intercellular attachments in the basal layer is the earliest change
  • Suprabasal epidermal cells separate from the basal cells to form clefts and blisters.
  • Basal cells remain attached to the basement membrane, in a ‘row of tombstones’ on the floor of the blister.
  • Blister cavities contain rounded‐up acantholytic cells, also seen in Tzank smears.

The image given below shows the row of tombstone appearance seen in pemphigus.

The image given below shows the round acantholytic cells seen in pemphigus, on a Tzanck smear.

Nikolsky's sign is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin. This leads to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis, producing an erosion, seen in acantholytic diseases like pemphigus.

The diagnosis of pemphigus is confirmed by direct immunofluorescence which shows IgG and C3 deposited intercellularly, on the surface of keratinocytes throughout the epidermis in normal, perilesional skin, in a  characteristic fishnet/ chickenwire appearance.

The image below shows the direct immunofluorescence test used to confirm pemphigus.

Systemic corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment for controlling the disease, improving the quality of life and reducing disease activity. Other steroid-sparing drugs that are used to reduce the dose of steroids include:

  • Azathioprine
  • Mycophenolate mofetil
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Rituximab

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text:
A biochemist is studying the effect of RNA interference on gene expression. He comes across the biogenesis of miRNA. Arrange the following events involved in this process in correct chronological order.
  1. Transported out of nucleus via exportin 5
  2. Trimming by dicer
  3. Trimming by Drosha
  4. Loading into RISC complex

miRNA: Micro Ribonucleic acid
RISC: RNA-induced silencing complex
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events involved in the biosynthesis of miRNA is 3,1,2,4 i.e. trimming by Drosha, transported out of nucleus via exportin 5, trimming by dicer, loading into RISC complex. 

miRNA is an endogenous non-coding RNA. The primary function of miRNA is to modulate the translation of target mRNAs into their corresponding proteins. After the target RNA is transcribed from its gene (post-transcriptional), the miRNA may either induce mRNA cleavage or repress its translation. This is referred to as gene silencing.

RNA interference (RNAi) is a biological process in which miRNA/siRNA molecules inhibit gene expression by neutralizing targeted mRNAs. The miRNA belongs to a group of non-coding genes. The miRNA genes are transcribed but not translated into proteins. siRNA is similar in function to miRNA and is used in RNA interference.

Mechanism of biosynthesis of miRNA:

  • The miRNA gene present in the nucleus is transcribed to primary miRNA, which is further converted to pre-miRNA by an enzyme drosha intranuclearly and exported to the cytoplasm by an exportin 5 protein.
  • The pre-miRNA undergoes trimming, by an enzyme called dicer, into mature single-stranded miRNA.
  • The mature miRNA is associated with a multiprotein aggregate called RISC.
  • The target mRNAs contain seed sequences in their 3′ untranslated region (UTR) that determines the specificity of miRNA binding and gene silencing.

miRNA expression has been found to be dysregulated in many cancers. Some types of miRNAs are oncogenic referred to as oncomiRs and are overexpressed in cancerous tissue. On the other hand, tumor-suppressive miRNAs that counteract oncogenic characteristics are found to be underexpressed in cancers. 

Small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) are short RNA sequences that can be introduced experimentally into cells and then serve as substrates for the dicer enzyme and interact with the RISC in a manner similar to that observed for endogenous miRNAs.

Synthetic siRNAs targeted against specific mRNA species are useful in the study of gene function referred to as knockdown technology. siRNAs are also being developed as possible therapeutic agents to silence pathogenic genes, such as oncogenes involved in neoplastic transformation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman pregnant with twins came to the OPD at 9 weeks with complaints of excessive nausea, vomiting and oedema of legs. When would you do the USG to determine the type of twin pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The type of twin pregnancy is best diagnosed by transabdominal ultrasound at 11-14 weeks of gestation as the chorion and amnion are not yet fused.

At 11-14 weeks, the intervening membranes are clearly visualized at the site of insertion of the amniotic membrane into the placenta. If not visualised transabdominally, transvaginal ultrasound is done.

Women with uncomplicated dichorionic twins should have:

  • 1 first trimester scan (11-14 weeks)
  • 1 second trimester scan (20-22 weeks)
  • scans every 4 weeks thereafter. 

Women with uncomplicated monochorionic twins should have:

  • 1 first trimester scan (11-14 weeks)
  • scans every 2 weeks from 16 weeks onwards for early detection of twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) and twin anaemia polycythemia syndrome (TAPS).

Other investigations:

  • Dating scan- it is done when the crown-rump length (CRL) is 45-84 cm (i.e) 11-14 weeks
  • Beta HCG and alpha fetoprotein are double than that of singleton pregnancies but not reliable for diagnosis of twins

questions.text: The graph shown below depicts a type of gastrointestinal movement. This movement is initiated by which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the migrating motor complex (MMC), which is initiated by the hormone motilin.

MMC is a type of gastrointestinal motility that occurs during the inter-digestive period at intervals of about 100 min and passes in the aboral direction at the rate of 5 cm/min. It is initiated by motilin. It helps to clear the stomach and small intestine of luminal contents in preparation for the next meal. Gastric secretion, bile flow, and pancreatic secretion increase during each MMC.

After ingestion of a meal, secretion of motilin is suppressed and the MMC is abolished. Each cycle of MMC has 3 phases:

  • Phase I - quiescent period
  • Phase II - period of irregular electrical & mechanical activity
  • Phase III - ends with bursts of regular activity

Related Pearl: Types of gastrointestinal motility

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy developed bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps. The bacteria isolated from the stool specimen produced green colonies on Hektoen enteric (HE) agar and pink coloured colonies on DCA. What is the mechanism of action of exotoxin produced by this bacteria?
questions.solution:
The bacteria implicated here is Shigella and the mechanism of action of exotoxin produced by it is inhibition of 60S ribosome.

Shigella is one of the causes of bacillary dysentery. It produces an exotoxin also known as Shiga toxin or verotoxin. The mechanism of action is almost similar to Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC). It consists of two subunits A and B. The B subunit binds to globotriaosylceramide receptors on the target cell and then the A subunit gets internalized. The A subunit leads to inhibition of 60S ribosome, leading to shut down of protein synthesis.

Shigella can be cultured from stool samples on the following media:-

  • Deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA), Xylose lysine deoxycholate (XLD) agar:- pale or pink colonies without H2S production (Salmonella produces H2S)
  • Salmonella Shigella(SS) agar:- colourless colonies
  • Hektoen enteric (HE) agar:- produces green colonies

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with focal seizures since he suffered a stroke 1 month ago. He is on hydrochlorothiazide for the management of hypertension. He was prescribed an anti-epileptic drug which is a synaptic vesicle 2A modulator. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Levetiracetam is an anti-epileptic agent which acts via synaptic vesicle 2A modulation.

It is a preferred antiepileptic drug in an elderly patient with normal renal function.

Also the patient is already on hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic and so levetiracetam is again preferred due to less interactions.

Adverse effects include aggression, hostility, and nervousness.

Other options:

Option A: Phenytoin is a Na+ channel blocker 

Option B: Vigabatrin is a GABA transaminase inhibitor

Option D: Perampanel is a glutamate receptor (AMPA) antagonist.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, arthralgia, and pain behind the eyes for 3 days. On examination, the patient has a petechial rash. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and leucopenia. Which of the following is false regarding the infection?

choices.text: NS1 antigen detection is done after 10 days of onset of illness for diagnosis
It is transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes
The extrinsic incubation period is 8-10 days
It is included under the genus flavivirus

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the symptoms and the rash suggests dengue fever. Non-structural viral protein 1 (NS1) antigen detection can be done only up to 7-10 days from the onset of infection.

Dengue is an acute febrile disease caused by the mosquito-borne dengue viruses (DENVs), consisting of four serotypes (DENV 1 to 4), that are members of the Flaviviridae family, genus Flavivirus. 

Dengue virus is transmitted from person to person by Aedes aegypti or "tiger" mosquitoes. The extrinsic incubation period, that is the time required for the virus to develop inside the mosquito, is 8-10 days.

The intrinsic incubation period, the time period between entry of the virus in humans up to the development of the symptoms, is 3–14 days.

Classical dengue fever begins with an abrupt onset of high fever. The condition is self-limiting though debilitating with headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, petechiae rash, and leucopenia. A macular-papular recovery rash appears 3–5 days after the onset of fever, and it usually starts on the trunk before spreading peripherally. During the febrile phase, dehydration can lead to neurological disturbances and febrile seizures in young children.  

Dengue fever is sometimes referred to as ‘break bone fever’ due to associated severe muscle and joint pain or ‘seven-day fever’ since the symptoms usually persist for 7 days.

Suspected cases of dengue are confirmed by the presence of NS1 antigen or IgM antibodies.

The treatment is supportive management, with hydration, cold sponging, and paracetamol for fever. Aspirin/ NSAIDS like ibuprofen should be avoided as they can cause vomiting, gastritis, platelet dysfunction and severe bleeding. Fluid and electrolyte replacement and platelet infusion should be done for severe cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with excessive bleeding during each menstrual cycle. Examination shows a symmetrically enlarged uterus corresponding to 12 weeks periods of gestation. Diagnosis of endometriosis interna was made. What is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with endometriosis interna/adenomyosis- the best treatment is hysterectomy.

Adenomyosis (Endometriosis interna):

Etiology: Prior curettage, prior uterine surgery, repeated childbirth, excess of estrogen, intake of tamoxifen (SERM)

Clinical features:

  • Multiparous women >40 years
  • Most common symptom - Menorrhagia > Dysmenorrhea
  • Per-Vaginal examination: Symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to <12-14 weeks of pregnancy
  • Bimanual examination: Halban’s sign - Tender, softened uterus

Diagnosis:

  • It is mainly clinical. The uterus is symmetrically enlarged and rarely exceeds 14 weeks in size.
  • Diagnostic hysteroscopy with curettage
  • TVS or MRI (MRI is superior to USG in showing hypo or anechoic areas in the uterine wall)

Management:

  • A diagnostic hysteroscopy combined with curettage is the initial step in the management of adenomyosis (because of menorrhagia).
  • Total Hysterectomy is the treatment of choice
  • Localized excision/ Levonorgestrel containing IUCD, Mirena is tried in younger women

 

 

Note:

Uterine Artery Embolization/Uterine Fibroid Embolization (UAE/UFE) is a promising non-surgical alternative treatment option for patients with menorrhagia and adenomyosis. It is an angiographic interventional procedure that delivers polyvinyl alcohol microspheres or other synthetic particulate emboli into both uterine arteries thus producing ischemia and necrosis. Because vessels serving leiomyomas have a larger caliber, these microspheres are preferentially directed to the tumors, sparing the surrounding myometrium. UAE helped in decreasing the uterine size and junctional zone thickness in cases of adenomyosis.

questions.text:
Given below is the procedure done under 'Nalgonda technique'. What is the purpose of this technique?
Add lime + alum
↓
Flocculation
↓
Sedimentation
↓
Filtration

choices.text: Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal
Air floatation of grains to remove ergot

questions.solution:
The Nalgonda technique is used for the defluoridation of water, which involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic to certain parts of India like Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Prakasam), Telangana(Nalgonda), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu. 

Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis (1.5mg/L): Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. It is best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects permanent teeth. It causes mottling of dental enamel, the appearance of chalky-white, and dull patches on the teeth in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and then brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a  corroded appearance.
  • Skeletal fluorosis (3-6mg/L): Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, and fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone. These are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.
  • Crippling fluorosis (>10mg/L): Can lead to permanent disability. 

Genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limb are seen in a newer form of fluorosis in Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. It is seen in people consuming jawar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

The given images show dental fluorosis and skeletal fluorosis (interosseous-membrane-calcification), respectively:

 

Interventions for Fluorosis 

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.
  • The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur, developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique. 
  • Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.
  • The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age

Other options:

Option A: Controlled superchlorination of water is the addition of large amounts of chlorine to the water, for disinfection. The excess is later removed. It is done for heavily polluted water with fluctuating quality.

Option C: Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal is done for Lathyrism. The toxin beta oxalyl amino alanine, in its crystalline form, is water-soluble. The pulse is soaked in boiling water for 2 hours, and the water is drained off completely. It is then washed with clean water and dried. 

Option D: Air floatation of grains is done to remove ergot, which is a field fungus. It can be removed by floating the grains in 20% saltwater, air floatation, or hand-picking.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with a history of laryngeal papillomatosis for which he underwent multiple laryngoscopies and surgeries eventually developed iatrogenic tracheal stenosis. Which of the following flow-volume loops is expected to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient has developed tracheal stenosis secondary to multiple laryngoscopies and surgeries. Thus the flow-volume curve expected to be seen in this patient is depicted in figure C.

Tracheal stenosis is an example of fixed obstruction due to airway narrowing. Fixed lesions cause plateaus in both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs of the flow volume loop thereby producing the characteristic flattened loop. 

Examples of fixed lesions include subglottic stenosis, tracheal tumors, and thyroid pathologies such as goiters. 

The flow-volume loop is a graphical representation of inspiratory and expiratory flow (shown on the Y-axis) against volume (shown on the X-axis) plotted while performing maximally forced inspiratory and expiratory maneuvers.

Related Pearl: Flow-volume graph/Loop

questions.text: Study A (red) and Study B (blue) done in a given population yield two different distribution curves as shown below. What is the correct option for showing a comparison between the mean, median, and mode in study B?

choices.text: Mean = median, not equal to mode
Mode = median, not equal to mean

questions.solution:
In study A: mean=median=mode

In study B: mean=median but has a bimodal distribution

Hence on comparison mean=median for both studies A and B, but the mode is different.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: A young man visits a doctor with a history of bluish-brown discoloration around the eyes. It has been present for the past year. There is no history of any eye injury or road traffic accident. He does not complain of any pain over the discoloration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows bluish-brown pigmentation around the eye. The most likely diagnosis is the naevus of Ota. 

Naevus of Ota is a dermal melanocytosis that mainly affects the sclera and skin around the eyes. These are generally distributed along the ophthalmic and maxillary divisions of the trigeminal nerve. Extracutaneous lesions may be seen in the uveal tract, nasopharynx, palate, and tympanum. They are managed with Q-switched lasers.

Other options:

Option A- Mongolian spots are seen in infants. They are bluish-grey pigmented areas, commonly seen over the sacrum. They usually resolve during childhood.

The image below shows Mongolian spots.

 

Option B- Naevus of Ito is a unilateral hyperpigmentation in the acromioclavicular region and upper chest. It is usually present in the area innervated by the posterior supraclavicular and lateral cutaneous brachial nerves.

The image below shows the naevus of Ito.

Option C- Becker's naevus is a hyperpigmented nonlinear lesion commonly present over the upper trunk. It is common in men and appears within the first 2 decades. The lesion is frequently hypertrichotic.

The below image shows Becker's naevus.

Related Pearl: Key Chart to help differentiate lesions on face

Key Chart to help Differentiate Lesions on face

 

The following images show the findings in -

  • Melasma

 

  • Rosacea

 

  • Butterfly-shaped malar rash in SLE 

 

  • Acne

 

  • Nevus of Ota

 

  • Portwine stain

 

  • Infantile hemangioma

questions.text:
Under the 'PANCHAYATI RAJ' structure of rural local self-government in India, at which level you will find the following systems?
  • The Gram Sabha
  • The Gram Panchayat
  • The Nyaya Panchayat
questions.solution:
The Gram Sabha, the Gram Panchayat, and the Nyaya Panchayat are systems at Panchayat, which is at the village level.

Panchayati Raj is a three-tier structure of rural self-government in India. It operates at the following levels:

  • Panchayat at the village level (includes Gram Sabha, Gram Panchayat, and Nyaya Panchayat)
  • Panchayat Samiti or Janpada Panchayat at the block level
  • Zilla Parishad at the district level

questions.text: A patient presenting with cola-colored urine and abdominal pain was investigated to find out the cause. The following instrument was used in the definitive diagnosis of the patient's condition. Which disease this patient is most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a flow cytometry tube, which is used for diagnosing paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is due to acquired mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA) leading to deficiency of GPI-linked proteins.PIGA is X-linked.

PNH blood cells are deficient in three GPI-linked proteins that regulate complement activity. They are : 

  • Decay-accelerating factor, or CD55
  • Membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis, or CD59
  • C8-binding protein.

Red cells deficient in GPI-linked factors are abnormally susceptible to lysis or injury by complement.

Clinical features of PNH:

  • Intravascular hemoglobinuria - cola-colored urine
  • Pancytopenia + hypercellular bone marrow
  • Thrombosis (if hepatic vein involved → Budd–Chiari syndrome)

Diagnosis:

  • HAM’S test (acidified serum lysis)
  • Sucrose lysis test
  • Flow cytometry: It is the gold standard for the diagnosis of PNH. It detects red cells that are deficient in GPI-linked proteins such as CD59 and CD55.

Eculizumab is used to alleviate the hemolysis associated with PNH and its sequelae. Eculizumab does not alter the underlying defect of the disease.

questions.text: A microscopic examination of urine is given below. Which of the following patients is likely to have the stones as shown in the image below?

choices.text: A patient with chronic urinary tract infection due to Klebsiella species
Obese patient who has undergone jejuno-ileal bypass
A patient with tophi in the 1st metatarsophalangeal joint

questions.solution:
The image shows calcium oxalate stones having an envelope shape. The patient likely to have these stones is an obese patient who has undergone jejunoileal bypass as a part of bariatric surgery. 

Calcium oxalate stones are seen in conditions such as malabsorption syndromes (small bowel disease, Crohn's disease), a jejunoileal bypass for obesity (bariatric surgery), surgical bowel resection or diversion.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with cystinuria (an autosomal recessive disorder) are at risk for developing cystine stones.

Option B: Patients with urinary tract infections due to urease-producing organisms such as Proteus or Klebsiella infection are at higher risk for struvite stones.

Option D: A patient with gout is at a higher risk of developing uric acid stones.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: An intern in the surgery department uses the following instrument to catheterize a patient. What is the size of the catheter used by him?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is Foley's catheter. The presence of a white-colored ring in the balloon port indicates its size as 12 F.

Indications of catheterization include:

  • Providing relief in acute and chronic urinary retention
  • Obtaining urine for analysis
  • Dilatation of urethral strictures
  • Performing continuous bladder infusion
  • Maintaining the bladder hygiene of an immobile patient
  • Decompression of a neurogenic bladder

Other options:

Option A: 14 F Foley's catheter has a green ring in the balloon port.

Option B: 16 F Foley's catheter has an orange ring in the balloon port. 

Option D: 18 F Foley's catheter has a red ring in the balloon port.

The image below shows Foley's catheters with different colored rings in the balloon ports.

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text:
A patient with dyspnea and cyanosis was started on 100% oxygen, but still, her SpO2 remained at 85%. On further probing, it was revealed that large amounts of a 'numbing cream' called EMLA was applied and left on for a long time. What will be the appropriate management for this patient?

EMLA - Eutectic Mixture of Local Anesthetics
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette depicts a scenario of cyanosis due to methemoglobinemia, induced by the application of a large amount of EMLA cream, and the most appropriate management, in this case, would be the administration of IV methylene blue.

EMLA is a eutectic mixture of local anesthetics containing a mixture of 2.5% lidocaine and 2.5% prilocaine. Methemoglobinemia is a serious side effect of the application of large amounts of prilocaine. Prilocaine is metabolized to O-toluidine, which converts hemoglobin (Fe2+) to methemoglobin (Fe3+) producing methemoglobinemia. This side effect is dose-dependent. 

Pulse oximetry in methemoglobinemia falsely shows 80-85% irrespective of higher arterial oxygen saturation. 

Treatment of methemoglobinemia includes reduction of methemoglobin to hemoglobin by intravenous methylene blue (1–2 mg/kg of a 1% solution over 5 min). 

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine: 

  • Naturally occurring
  • Vasoconstrictor
  • 1st local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine: Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine: 

  • Safest
  • Causes maximum methemoglobinemia
  • Suitable for Bier’s IV block
  • EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

  • Long-acting
  • Most cardiotoxic
  • Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia
  • Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretylium(for VT), vasopressors (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

  • LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia
  • 1st synthetic LA
  • Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

questions.text:
A multigravida with a past history of the cesarean section presents with labor pain. An obstetrician takes a decision on vaginal delivery for this woman. Which of the following is an indication of TOLAC?

TOLAC=Trial of labor after cesarean section

LSCS=Lower segment cesarean section
questions.solution:
The answer is option A-TOLAC can be done in a case of 2 previous lower segment cesarean section

A classical cesarean section is done by a longitudinal uterine incision. A previous classical cesarean section is considered a high-risk factor for failure of VBAC (vaginal birth after a previous cesarean). Hence, it is contraindicated. There is an increased risk of uterine rupture (2-9%) in such cases. In some women, the classical cesarean scar can even rupture several weeks before term. 

Other contraindications for VBAC include:

  • >2 previous lower segment cesarean section
  • Contracted pelvis or cephalo-pelvic disproportion
  • Other obstetric or medical complications
  • Prior uterine rupture

questions.text: Several colonic polyps were incidentally detected on a screening colonoscopy in a 51-year-old male patient. He was further evaluated and diagnosed with MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP). Which of the following defective DNA repair mechanisms is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The DNA repair mechanism that is defective in MUTYH Associated Polyposis (MAP) is DNA base excision repair (BER). Its function is to remove base uracil from the DNA.

Base lesions spontaneously occur in the DNA by various mechanisms including deamination, oxidation, and alkylation. This damage causes the conversion of single bases in the DNA such as cytosine, adenine, and guanine bases to uracil, hypoxanthine, and xanthine respectively, thereby threatening the integrity of the DNA. This damage is corrected by base excision repair. 

Base excision repair may occur in the nuclei as well as in the mitochondria. It includes the following major enzymatic steps-

  • DNA glycosylase- It recognizes the damaged base and removes it leaving an abasic site/ AP-site (apurinic/apyrimidinic site). 
  • AP -endonucleases excise the basic sugar and cleave the DNA strand. 
  • DNA polymerase β (Pol β) add the appropriate nucleotides 
  • Ligase seals the strand and completes the repair.

questions.text:
ABG (Arterial blood gas) analysis report of which of the following patient indicates pure respiratory acidosis?
Patients pH pCO2(mm-Hg) HCO3-(mEq/L)
Patient-1 7.2 30 22
Patient-2 7.0 81 15
Patient-3 7.2 75 40
Patient-4 7.5 40 28
questions.solution:
Patient 3 has pure respiratory acidosis.

Normal values in an arterial blood gas are as follows:

  • pH: 7.35-7.45
  • PaCO2: 35-45 mmHg
  • HCO3: 22-26 mEq/L
  • PaO2: 75-100 mmHg

Respiratory changes (changes in PCO2) promote a corresponding change in metabolic response (changes in HCO3-) and vice versa as a compensatory mechanism. In general, PCO2 and HCO3- move in the same direction for compensation in metabolic and respiratory acid-base disorders respectively. A change in the two parameters in opposite directions points to a mixed acid-base disturbance. 

Respiratory acidosis can be secondary to severe pulmonary disease, respiratory muscle fatigue, or ventilatory control abnormalities. It is marked by an increase in PaCO2 and a decrease in pH. A compensatory rise of HCO3- can also be seen. 

A rapid rise in PCO2 (acute hypercapnia) can present with dyspnea, confusion, and psychosis. It can be seen in severe asthma secondary to bronchospasm, anaphylaxis, or inhalational burns. Chronic hypercapnia causes sleep disorders, memory loss, and daytime somnolence. It is commonly seen in end-stage obstructive lung disease. 

Acute respiratory acidosis may need tracheal intubation and assisted mechanical ventilation. Rapid correction of hypercapnia should be avoided as it can trigger cardiac arrhythmias and seizures. Chronic respiratory acidosis is difficult to manage and improvement in lung function is the primary aim. 

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

High Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (MUDPILES) Normal Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (FUSED CAR)
Methanol Fistula pancreatic
Uremia (Renal failure - Acute or Chronic) Ureterosigmoidostomy
Diabetic ketoacidosis Small bowel fistula
Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea
Lactic acidosis Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide)
Ethylene glycol Addison's disease
Salicylates Renal tubular acidosis

 

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A young woman with backache is suspected to have hemangioma. All of the following are radiological signs seen in this condition except:
questions.solution:
The fallen fragment sign is seen in a simple bone cyst.

Hemangioma is typically a benign tumor of the vertebral body. This tumor is mostly clinically silent and is usually detected incidentally. The vertebral body is the most common location for hemangioma. The atypical location of hemangioma is the posterior elements of the vertebra and is indicative of an aggressive lesion. Symptomatic hemangiomas usually present with pain, neurologic compromise, or fractures.

Radiographs show large lesions with vertical striations and coarse, thick trabeculae, giving a corduroy appearance in sagittal and coronal sections. It is also known as the jail bar sign.

On an axial computed tomography (CT) scan, hemangioma shows a classic polka dot appearance. 

Treatment: Most hemangiomas do not require treatment. Vertebroplasty is useful in aggressive hemangiomas. 

The corduroy sign is shown in the image given below.

questions.text: What is the equilibrium potential for sodium-ion calculated by using the Nernst equation for a spinal motor neuron?
questions.solution:
The equilibrium potential for Na+ is +60mV.

For Na+ both electrical and the concentration gradient is directed inward. So, one would expect the cell to gain Na+. But the intracellular concentration of Na+remains constant because:

  • The activity of Na+- K+ ATPase pumps out 3 Na+ in exchange for 2 K+ 
  • Selective permeability of the membrane.

 K+ +1  -90

Cl-

-70

+2

+130

Mg2+

+2

+9

questions.text: The image below shows the dissection of the right side of the neck, and the red arrow denotes the right subclavian artery. What is not true about the structure labeled as A?

choices.text: It arises mainly from C4 spinal nerve.
The right side nerve is shorter than the left.
It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior.
It is purely a motor nerve.

questions.solution:
The structure labeled as A is the right phrenic nerve, and it is a mixed nerve (sensory and motor nerve).

 It is derived mostly from the C4 ramus and also receives contributions from the C3 and C5 ventral rami. It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior.

At the root of the neck, the right phrenic nerve runs anterior to the second part of the right subclavian artery from which it is seperated by scalenus anterior muscle. The phrenic nerve lies posterior to the right subclavian vein.

Right phrenic nerve is shorter and more vertical than the left.

Each phrenic nerve provides the sole motor supply to its hemidiaphragm. In its thoracic course, each phrenic nerve supplies sensory branches to the central parts of the diaphragm.

questions.text: A patient presented with bull neck edema and a pseudomembrane on the tonsils. Which of the following stains is used to demonstrate volutin granules of this organism?
questions.solution:
Presence of bull neck edema and pseudomembrane on tonsils points towards the diagnosis of diphtheria. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Albert stain is one of three stains that can be used to demonstrate the volutin granules (metachromatic/Babes-Ernst granules) of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. 

The two other stains used for this purpose are Neisser’s stain and Ponder’s stain. The bacilli are usually arranged in pairs or palisades or small groups, at various angles to each other, resembling the letters V or L. This has been called the Chinese letter or cuneiform arrangement.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man was found dead in his apartment. No medical records were found in his place. An autopsy image of his liver is given below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the nutmeg appearance of the liver, which is seen in heart failure. Congestive hepatopathy, also known as nutmeg liver or chronic passive congestion of the liver, is liver dysfunction due to venous congestion. It usually occurs due to congestive heart failure.

Pathogenesis:

  • It is seen in patients with chronic cardiac lesions, especially those affecting the right heart, which causes the blood to be drained back into the inferior vena cava and then into the hepatic veins.
  • This transmission of right ventricular pressure directly into the hepatic veins causes passive congestion around the central veins leading to enlargement of the liver (congestive hepatomegaly).

Gross appearance:

  • In chronic passive hepatic congestion due to heart failure, the centrilobular regions are grossly red-brown due to congestion and slightly depressed due to cell death and are accentuated against the surrounding zones of the uncongested tan liver.
  • The appearance is called a nutmeg liver pattern due to its close resemblance with the cut surface of the nutmeg seed.

Microscopic appearance:

Microscopic examination reveals centrilobular hemorrhage, hemosiderin-laden macrophages, necrosis, and variable degrees of hepatocyte dropout.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male patient is being evaluated for sweating, palpitations, and pallor that occur a few times a day. He was diagnosed with pheochromocytoma and planned for surgery. Choose the incorrect statement regarding anesthesia for this patient.

choices.text: Ketamine may exacerbate the effects of his condition
Halothane can be used safely in this patient
Vecuronium is safe to use in this patient

questions.solution:
Halothane should not be used in the patient as it sensitizes the heart to the arrhythmogenic effects of epinephrine.

Pheochromocytoma is a condition where the chromaffin tissue, most commonly in the adrenal medulla, produces excessive norepinephrine and epinephrine. 

Other anaesthetic drugs to be avoided in a pheochromocytoma patient are:

  • Succinylcholine - can cause fasciculations which lead to raised intraabdominal pressure and catecholamine release from the tumor
  • Ketamine - as it is sympathomimetic and might exacerbate the effects of adrenergic agonists
  • Anticholinergics and Pancuronium – vagal blockade leading to tachycardia
  • Atracurium – due to histamine release which may provoke catecholamine release. The safest options for these patients would be vecuronium and rocuronium

Other considerations in patients with pheochromocytoma:

  • Phenoxybenzamine, an alpha1-antagonist, which can be administered orally, is often given preoperatively to reverse the vasoconstriction. This results in a drop in arterial blood pressure and a drop in hematocrit
  • Phentolamine is used intraoperatively to control hypertensive episodes
  • A major regional block such as spinal/epidural could block sensory and sympathetic discharge in the area of the surgical field. But catecholamines released from the pheochromocytoma could still bind to receptors all over the body.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man was posted for bronchoscopy under procedural sedation. After the administration of anesthetic drugs, he developed chest wall rigidity and ineffective spontaneous ventilation. Attempts at manual ventilation were unsuccessful due to the non-compliant chest wall. The opioid that is most commonly associated with this condition is?
questions.solution:
Chest wall rigidity and ineffective ventilation is a classic presentation of 'wooden chest syndrome'. This opioid-induced muscle rigidity is most commonly associated with the use of lipophilic opioids such as fentanyl and its congeners (alfentanil, sufentanil, and remifentanil).

Risk factors for wooden chest syndrome:

  • Rapid administration of a large dose of fentanyl
  • Concomitant use of nitrous oxide
  • Old age

The clinical presentation can vary from mild hoarseness to chest wall rigidity severe enough to prevent adequate bag-and-mask ventilation.

Management of wooden chest syndrome:

  • Discontinuation of the opioid
  • Replacement of the opioid with a non-lipophilic version (such as hydromorphone or morphine) for analgesia
  • Consider naloxone for reversal (you do not want to reverse analgesia on an intubated patient unless absolutely necessary)
  • Addition of a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker for paralysis
  • Supportive ventilatory care

questions.text:
A patient after a kidney transplant was diagnosed with an infection from cytomegalovirus (CMV). This virus encodes certain important proteins that inhibit caspases, thus hampering important mechanisms of host defense. In this situation, a form of 'cell death' which acts as a backup mechanism in host defense is ______
  1. Morphologically same as necrosis and biochemically same as apoptosis.
  2. Mechanistically same as necrosis because it is caspase-independent.
  3. Mechanistically same as apoptosis but it is caspase-independent.
  4. Both morphologically and mechanistically same as apoptosis and it is caspase-dependent.
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of necroptosis. It is mechanistically the same as apoptosis but it is caspase-independent.

In a CMV infected cell, caspases are inhibited hence apoptosis is not working. In that case, a form of cell death which serves as a back up mechanism should be caspase-independant which is necroptossis.

Necroptosis is a form of cell death that is morphologically and biochemically similar to necrosis and mechanistically similar to apoptosis but is caspase-independent. It is also called programmed necrosis and serves as a backup mechanism in a CMV-infected cell.

Examples where necroptosis serves as an important mechanism of cell death:

  • CMV infected cell.
  • During the formation of the mammalian growth plate.
  • Steatohepatitis.
  • Acute pancreatitis.
  • Ischemia-reperfusion injury.
  • Neurodegenerative diseases such as parkinsonism.

Related Pearl: Necrosis vs Apoptosis

Necrosis

Apoptosis

Mechanism

Genetically programmed cell death

Active process

Invariably pathologic 

Both physiologic and pathologic

Enlarged (swelling)

Reduced (shrinkage)

Nucleus

Pyknosis →karyorrhexis →karyolysis

Fragmentation into nucleosome-size fragments

Plasma membrane

Disrupted

Cellular contents

Enzymatic digestion; may leak out of cell

Intact; may be released in apoptotic bodies

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient developed severe abdominal pain, vertigo, and convulsions after consumption of the seeds shown in the image. The active principle of this plant which is a toxalbumen is known as _____ and it acts by inhibiting ______
questions.solution:
The seeds shown in the image are of the Abrus precatorius plant. Abrin is a toxalbumen toxin of this plant and it acts by inhibiting protein synthesis.

Toxic principles of Abrus precatorius are:

  • Abrin (a toxalbumen)
  • Abrine (an amino acid)
  • Abralin (a glucoside)

Abrin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis, thereby, resulting in cell death. The clinical features after oral ingestion of these seeds include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, weakness, cold perspiration, trembling, weak rapid pulse, and miosis. Faintness, vertigo, dyspnea, and convulsions can also occur. If taken by injection, painful swelling, ecchymosis with inflammation, and necrosis are seen at the site of injection.

Medicolegal Importance:

  • It is a commonly used cattle poison in Indian villages by injecting the seed extract into the animal in the form of certain fine needle-shaped structures known as Sui (meaning needle in Hindi).
  • These are prepared by mixing the seed extract with opium, datura, and spirit/water and then blended into a paste, shaped into fine needles and dried in the sun, and used to kill cattle by driving it deep into the animal body by blowing through a hollow bamboo pipe.

Option A- Ricin is the toxic principle of the Ricinus communis plant. It causes the burning of oral mucosa similar to alkali burn, severe abdominal pain, hemolysis, convulsions, uremia, collapse, and death. 

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of seizures. On examination, she has a port-wine stain on her face. CT scan showed characteristic tram-track calcifications in the cerebral cortex. Which of the following is not an ocular finding commonly associated with this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Sturge-Weber syndrome. Optic nerve glioma is not an ocular finding associated with the Sturge-Weber syndrome, it is associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. 

The characteristic features of Sturge-Weber syndrome include port-wine stain on the face, a history of seizures, and tram-track calcifications in the cerebral cortex. The ocular findings commonly associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome are choroidal hemangioma, iris heterochromia, and ipsilateral glaucoma.

Important ocular manifestations in neurofibromatosis type 1 include:

  • Eyelid plexiform neurofibroma- S-shaped deformity of the upper lid, with a 'bag of worms' like texture.
  • Optic nerve glioma - A pilocytic astrocytoma that typically occurs in young children.
  • Bilateral Lisch nodules are hamartomas that develop during the second–third decades.
  • Spheno-orbital encephalocele - due to dysplasia of the greater wing of the sphenoid

The various neurocutaneous syndromes and their ocular manifestations are as follows:

retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and retina

questions.text: You are following up on a patient who is suspected to have Gradenigo's syndrome. Which of the following will not constitute a component of the classical triad of this condition?
questions.solution:
Gradenigo’s Syndrome generally occurs secondary to petrous apicitis. It is a complication of the attico-antral type of otitis media. Immobility of the homolateral soft palate (generally due to X cranial nerve palsy) is not a component of its classical triad of symptoms. 

Gradenigo’s syndrome is a triad that consists of:

  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (VI nerve palsy) - lateral rectus palsy
  • Deep ear/facial pain (V Nerve involvement)
  • Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

Fever, headache, vomiting and sometimes neck rigidity may also be associated. Some patients may get facial paralysis and recurrent vertigo due to the involvement of facial and statoacoustic nerves.

Diagnosis of petrous apicitis requires both a CT scan and MRI. CT scan of temporal bone will show bony details of the petrous apex and the air cells while MRI helps to differentiate diploic marrow-containing apex from the fluid or pus.

Treatment with suitable intravenous antibacterial therapy should precede and follow surgical intervention. Definitive management would include mastoidectomy. 

Note - 

Trotter’s Triad:

  1. Conductive hearing loss
  2. Immobility of homolateral soft palate
  3. Trigeminal neuralgia

This is generally seen in Nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: A girl who is _____  years old can give consent for general physical examination but neither can she be employed in a factory nor can she give consent for sexual intercourse.
questions.solution:
A girl who is 13 years old, can give consent for general physical examination but neither can she be employed in a factory nor can she give consent for sexual intercourse.

This is because the legal age for general physical examination is 12 years, for employment in a factory is 14 years and for consent for sexual intercourse is 18 years. 

Related Pearl: Medico-legal importance of age

Age  Medico-legal importance
7 months period of gestation Attainment of viability by fetus – infanticide can’t be charged if fetus is proved to be less than 7 months of age.
>5 years Criminal responsibility as per railways act.  
<7 years No criminal responsibility as per Section 82 IPC/ BNS Sec 20.      
10 years Abducting a child below 10 years for the sake of moveable property amounts to kidnap (369 IPC / Sec 97 BNS)
7 – 12 years Criminal responsibility if he/she is of sufficient maturity to understand and judge the nature and consequences of the act (Section 83 IPC/ Sec 21 BNS).
<12 years

Consent by the parent or guardian is needed before examination of the patient.

Not punishable under the Railway Act.
<14 years Cannot be employed in factory jobs. (Factory Act)
14 – 15 years Can be employed in nonhazardous factory jobs in the daytime.
>15 years Can be employed in any job
<16 years Taking away a boy without consent of parent or guardian amounts to kidnapping
<18 years
  • Juvenile (boy and girl) 
  • Taking away a girl without consent of parent or guardian amounts to kidnapping
  • Sexual intercourse with a girl with or without her consent amounts to rape (Section 375 IPC/ Sec 63 BNS)
>/=18 years 
  • Attainment of majority 
  • Can give valid consent to suffer any harm not known to cause death or grievous hurt. 
  • Valid consent given by a girl for sexual intercourse. 
  • Can make valid will. 
  • Legal age of marriage for girls.

questions.text:
A patient is seated one meter away from the light source and is asked to fixate on a distant object as the retinoscopy is performed. With respect to the movement of the plane mirror in the retinoscope, the red reflex in the eye exhibits the following finding. Putting a -1.0 D lens in front of the eye neutralizes the reflex. What is the likely refractive error of the patient? (No cycloplegics were used).

D - diopters
questions.solution:
The most likely refractive error in the patient is myopia of 2.0 D.

Here the red reflex is against the movement. To neutralize it, a concave lens with negative power will be required. So the patient has myopia. Now here -1.0 D lens is used, along with the distance correction of 1 meter. Thus subtracting 1 from -1 gives us the final value of 2.0 D.

When a plane mirror retinoscope is used at a distance of 1 meter, based upon the movement of the red reflex, the results can be interpreted as:

  • No movement of red reflex: myopia of 1D
  • Movement of red reflex with the plane mirror retinoscope: Emmetropia, hypermetropia, or myopia < 1D
  • Movement of red reflex against the plane mirror retinoscope: Myopia >1D
  • Oblique movement is seen in astigmatism.

questions.text: A patient with a focal seizure, post ictal disorientation, and memory loss, with MRI findings as shown in the image below, will respond well to which anti-epileptic drug?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option D-none of them.

The given clinical scenario of a patient with a focal seizure, post ictal disorientation, memory loss, and MRI showing hippocampal sclerosis has the most likely diagnosis as mesial temporal lobe epilepsy syndrome (MTLE). The condition is refractory to anticonvulsant therapy but responds well to surgical intervention.  

It is the most common epilepsy syndrome characterized by the early onset of focal seizures with impairment of consciousness. Clinically, aura, postictal disorientation, dysphasia, memory loss, and unilateral posturing may be seen.

The EEG shows unilateral or bilateral anterior temporal spikes and MRI is characterized by hippocampal sclerosis.

Related Pearl: Mesial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy

Mesial temporal lobe epilepsy shows a familial inheritance and begins in childhood. It presents as focal seizures with a remitting and relapsing course. It is associated with:

  • Aura
  • Complex automatism
  • Post-ictal confusion
  • Anterograde amnesia

EEG findings include temporal spikes, and MRI shows hippocampal sclerosis. Management includes anteromedial resection of the temporal lobe.

questions.text: Which is not a complication of the procedure depicted in the image below?​
questions.solution:
The given image depicts hemodialysis. Weight gain is not a complication of hemodialysis, it is a complication of peritoneal dialysis.

The other three conditions are the complications of hemodialysis.

questions.text: Which of the following lifestyle modification to treat hypertension is not recommended?

choices.text: Attain and maintain a BMI of <25 kg/sq m
Diet rich in fruits, vegetables and high-fat dairy products
For those who drink alcohol, 2 or less drinks/day for men and 1 or less drink/day for women

questions.solution:
The correct answer is option B-Diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and high-fat dairy products.

Lifestyle modifications to manage hypertension:

  • Attain and maintain a BMI of <25 kg/sq m
  • Diet rich in fruits, vegetables and low-fat dairy products with reduced content of saturated and total fat. Diet rich in potassium, calcium and magnesium. 
  • Dietary salt <6 grams/day
  • For those who drink alcohol, 2 or less drinks/day for men and 1 or less drink/day for women
  • Physical activity: Regular aerobic activity, eg, brisk waking for 30 min/day.

questions.text: What is the function of the structure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows a proteasome, and its function is protein degradation. 

The proteasome is a cylindrical structure in the cytosol that degrades polyubiquitinated proteins. It has a central core with proteolytic enzymes. Proteins that are tagged by ubiquitin to be degraded enter the core through regulatory rings on either side of the cylinder.

Clinical relevance: It plays an important role in antigen presentation to T lymphocytes as it degrades viruses and other molecules to small peptides.

Related Pearl: Structure of proteins

questions.text: Which of the following psychiatric disorders doesn't require 6 months duration to make a diagnosis according to DSM-5?
questions.solution:
Depression is diagnosed if symptoms persist for 2 weeks.

The other three disorders require persistence of symptoms for at least 6 months to establish the diagnosis, according to DSM-5.

questions.text: A biochemist is studying the structure of a triple helical quarter staggered protein found in fibroblasts. He hydrolyzes the protein and separates the constituent amino acids via paper chromatography. Which of the following amino acid is most likely to be found in the highest quantity in these proteins?
questions.solution:
The triple helical quarter staggered protein found in fibroblasts is collagen. The most abundant amino acid in collagen is glycine.

Collagen is the most abundant protein in the animal world. It consists of three alpha chains held together by hydrogen bonds forming a triple helical structure.

A striking characteristic of collagen is the occurrence of glycine residues at every third position, (Gly-X-Y) repeats.

Proline and hydroxyproline confer rigidity on the collagen molecule. Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are formed by the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues. This hydroxylation is catalyzed by the enzyme prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase, and cofactors are ascorbic acid (vitamin C) and α-ketoglutarate.

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text:
A male infant presents with hypertension and undervirilized genitalia. Which of the following are correct laboratory findings regarding the diagnosis?
  Cortisol Corticosterone Aldosterone 17-OH progesterone

1

 ↑ ↓ ↓ ↓
2 ↓ ↑ ↑ ↓
3 ↓ ↓ ↑ ↓
4 ↓ ↓ ↓ ↑
questions.solution:
Incomplete virilization of male genitalia and the presence of hypertension indicate 17α hydroxylase deficiency presenting with decreased levels of cortisol and 17-OH progesterone and increased levels of corticosterone and aldosterone (option B).

Since the patient has hypertension, it suggests increased aldosterone or deoxycorticosterone. Thus, there are two conditions with increased blood pressure.

  1. 17α-hydroxylase deficiency:- increased aldosterone with decreased androgens leading to undervirilized male genitalia.
  2. 11β-hydroxylase deficiency:- increased deoxycorticosterone and decreased aldosterone but with increased androgens, leading to normal male infants but females with ambiguous genitalia.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-hydroxylase deficiency 17-hydroxylase deficiency 11β-hydroxylase deficiency 3β-HSD deficiency

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone

Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones

Deficiency of cortisol

Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone, and testosterone

↑ in testosterone

 ↑ in aldosterone ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone  ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

 Salt-wasting crises
Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient on long-term lithium treatment came to the emergency room with symptoms of acute gout. He was treated with indomethacin and colchicine. Later, he developed nausea, vomiting, ataxia, coarse tremors, seizures, and hyperreflexia. Identify the drug responsible for this and the mechanism of the interaction.

choices.text: Indomethacin decreases plasma protein binding of lithium
Colchicine decreases renal excretion of lithium
Indomethacin increases tubular reabsorption of lithium
Colchicine inhibits the metabolism of lithium

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute lithium toxicity. The drug responsible for this is indomethacin as it increases the proximal tubule reabsorption of lithium.

Increased reabsorption of lithium from the proximal tubules is also seen with other non-steroid anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen, naproxen, and possibly aspirin.

The important symptoms of acute lithium toxicity are nausea, vomiting, ataxia, coarse tremors, dysarthria, seizure, and hyperreflexia. There is no specific antidote, and treatment is mainly supportive. In severe toxicity, dialysis is the most effective treatment.

Thiazide diuretics may also lead to lithium toxicity. Lithium competes with sodium for reabsorption. Diuresis leads to Na+ loss and compensatory Li+ reabsorption from the proximal tubule, leading to toxicity.

Important side effects of lithium are-

  • Fine tremors in therapeutic dose
  • Seizures
  • Significant weight gain
  • Nephrogenic diabetes inspidus
  • Hypothyroidism
  • T wave flattening
  • Worsening of psoriasis
  • Teratogenic effect causing Ebstein anomaly and floppy infant
  • Leukocytosis

Other options:

Colchicine is an antimitotic drug that is used in the treatment of acute gout. It acts by inhibiting microtubule and spindle formation and thus:

  • Arrests cell division in the G1 phase
  • Inhibits neutrophil-mediated phagocytosis 
  • Decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors IL-18 and IL-1β

Colchicine has many other effects that may cause depression of the respiratory center, an enhanced response to sympathomimetic agents, and induction of hypertension by central vasomotor stimulation. 

Important side effects of colchicine are:

  • Nausea and vomiting 
  • Diarrhea
  • Myelosuppression 
  • Aplastic anemia
  • Rhabdomyolysis

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text:
Match the following :
Disease Defect
1. Leukocyte adhesion defect a. Defect in tyrosine kinase 
2. Bruton's agammaglobulinemia b. Deficiency of CD40L
3. Hyper IgM syndrome c. Adenosine deaminase deficiency
4. Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) d. Absence of CD18
questions.solution:
The correct answer is -

Disease Defect
1. Leukocyte adhesion defect d. Absence of CD18
2. Bruton's agammaglobulinemia a. Defect in tyrosine kinase 
3. Hyper IgM syndrome b. Deficiency of CD40L
4. Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) c. Adenosine deaminase deficiency

 

Leukocyte adhesion defect is due to the absence of CD18 (an integrin), which is necessary for the adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium. Thus leukocytes can't migrate out of the blood vessels to the sites of inflammation.

Bruton's X-linked agammaglobulinemia is due to a defect in Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK), which is required for the maturation of pre-B cells. Thus the defect leads to the arrest of maturation of pre-B cells and a decrease in the number of mature B cells.

Hyper IgM syndrome is due to deficient CD40L on T-cells. B-cells have CD40 on their surface which interacts with CD40L on T-cells to undergo class switching from IgM to various other classes (IgG, IgA, IgE) depending on the type of antigen. Thus, failure of this class switching leads to an increase in IgM and a decrease in other classes of antibodies.

SCID is due to many defects but the most common cause of an autosomal recessive form of SCID is the deficiency of adenosine deaminase enzyme. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to accumulation of adenosine derivatives inside the cell, which is toxic to them. Since lymphocytes are rapidly diving cells they are most affected by them leading to immunodeficiency. 

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: A professor asks a student to identify the structure marked by the red arrows in the dissected part of the neck. He gives him a hint that this nerve arises from the medulla oblongata. He further adds that its damage causes the structure supplied by it to get deviated to the same side of the lesion. What is the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked with the red arrows in the image is the hypoglossal nerve. 

The hypoglossal nerve courses lateral to the internal and external carotid artery and the facial artery. The nerve then ascends along the lateral surface of the hyoglossus muscle.

The hypoglossal nerve supplies all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue, except the palatoglossus, which is supplied by the vago accessory nerve. Deviation of the tongue to the affected side is seen in injury to the hypoglossal nerve.

Related Pearl: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain

  • IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect
  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)
