questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presented to the emergency room with sudden pain in the right upper quadrant of her abdomen. Initial ultrasound evaluation showed free fluid in the peritoneum. The ascitic fluid is aspirated for investigations. Which of the following laboratory findings will point to a diagnosis of early-onset Budd-Chiari syndrome?

SAAG - Serum-ascites albumin gradient
questions.solution:
A laboratory finding of Serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) >1.1g/dL and ascitic protein >2.5g/dL will point to a diagnosis of early-onset Budd-Chiari syndrome.

A SAAG is used to differentiate between the portal and nonportal hypertensive ascites. It represents the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids and correlates with the hepatic venous pressure gradient.

It is given by the formula: SAAG = Serum albumin - ascitic fluid albumin.

Interpretation of SAAG:

  • SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It reflects the presence of portal hypertension.
  • SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy.

In cases with high-SAAG (≥1.1), ascitic protein level analysis further helps in identifying the etiology:

  • ≥2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing the passage of protein into the ascites. eg. early Budd-Chiari syndrome.
  • <2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein. Eg. late Budd-Chiari syndrome.

Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) is a form of congestive hepatopathy caused due to blockage of the hepatic venous outflow anywhere along the venous course between the hepatic venules to the junction of the inferior vena cava (IVC) to the right atrium. Hypercoagulable states due to primary myeloproliferative diseases are the leading cause of the disease.

Investigations for BCS include: 

  • Elevated bilirubin, liver enzymes with decreased albumin is usually seen.
  • Doppler ultrasonography of the liver: highly sensitive, specific, initial investigation of choice. Hepatic veins without flow signal, with spider-web appearance, collateral hepatic venous circulation and stagnant, reversed or turbulent flow are indicative of BCS
  • Magnetic resonance imaging
  • Hepatic venography: a spider-web pattern confirms BCS
  • Liver biopsy 
  • Echocardiography
  • Diagnosis of the underlying cause of thrombosis is important.

Management strategy includes:

  • Anticoagulation
  • Treatment of identified prothrombotic risk factors
  • Percutaneous revascularization, transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic stent shunt (TIPSS): to re-establish hepatic venous drainage
  • Liver transplantation in unresponsive patients.
 
5-year prognosis is >90% while the long-term outcome is influenced by any underlying haematological condition and development of hepatocellular carcinoma.

High serum levels of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) can be used to identify heart failure as the cause of high-SAAG ascites.

Low ascitic glucose level <50 mg/dL and high ascitic LDH level are indicative of ascites due to secondary peritonitis.

Ascitic amylase level >1000 mg/dL is indicative of pancreatic ascites.

Tuberculous peritonitis is typically associated with ascitic fluid lymphocytosis and elevated adenosine deaminase levels.

Other options: 

Option D: SAAG >1.1g/dl and ascitic protein <2.5g/dl is seen in liver cirrhosis, late Budd-Chiari syndrome, and massive liver metastases.

Options A and B are not possible. 

Related Pearl: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.

questions.text: What can be the likely clinical finding in a patient presenting with the following pattern of immunofluorescence?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option A-Sclerodactyly.

Given here is a speckled pattern on immunofluorescence that is most likely to be seen in systemic sclerosis. 

Scleroderma or Systemic Sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4:1 female predominance.

A wide spectrum of clinical features are seen in Scleroderma:

  • Severe pruritus
  • Initially, puffiness and non-pitting edema of fingers
  • The skin later becomes indurated, thickened, and fixed to underlying structures resulting in sclerodactyly
  • Vasospasm and digital ulceration
  • Most patients have dysphagia and GERD
  • Mask like facies is seen due to the waxy nature of skin and lack of wrinkles, expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia, perioral furrowing, and beak‐like nose.

The antibodies tested in systemic sclerosis include:

  • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) - positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis.
  • Anticentromere antibody (ACA) - usually positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
  • Antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis 
  • Anti-RNA polymerase III antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Other options-

Option B-Heliotrope rashes are seen in dermatomyositis.

Option C-Joint pain and morning stiffness is seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

Option D-Calcinosis cutis is a feature of limited scleroderma/CREST syndrome.

 

The image below shows a nucleolar pattern in immunofluorescence, seen in systemic sclerosis due to anti-U3-RNP antibody. It is also seen in polymyositis.

 

A centromeric pattern of staining is seen in limited cutaneous sclerosis due to antibodies against centromere proteins and Sjogren's syndrome. The image given below shows the centromeric pattern of immunofluorescence.

 

Speckled/granular pattern of staining is seen in systemic sclerosis due to antibodies against Scl-70, SLE, and Sjogren's syndrome. The image given below shows the speckled pattern of immunofluorescence.

 

The image given below shows the homogenous/diffuse pattern of immunofluorescence, seen in SLE due to antibodies against ds-DNA.

Related Pearl: Manifestations of systemic sclerosis

Organ

Manifestations

Skin

Endothelial injury and microvascular disease causing chronic ischemia

Alimentary Tract

Affected in approximately 90% of patients.

Progressive atrophy and collagenous fibrous replacement of the muscular is most severe in the esophagus.

The lower two-thirds of the esophagus often develops a rubber-hose–like an inflexibility.

Gastroesophageal reflux and Barrett metaplasia and strictures.

Musculoskeletal System

Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the synovial soft tissues

Joint destruction is not common in systemic sclerosis.

Inflammatory myositis

Kidneys.

The most prominent are the vascular lesions.

Interlobular arteries show intimal thickening as a result of deposition of mucinous or finely collagenous material

Lungs.

The lungs are involved in more than 50% of individuals

Pulmonary hypertension and interstitial fibrosis

Pulmonary fibrosis

Heart

Pericarditis with effusion, myocardial fibrosis, and thickening of intramyocardial arterioles

Related Pearl: Pattern of nuclear body suggests the type of antibody present in patient’s serum.

Five basic patterns of nuclear fluorescence is recognized for anti-nuclear antibodies:

Staining pattern Antigen
Homogenous or diffuse nuclear staining Antibodies to chromatin, histones, and occasionally double-stranded DNA
Rim or peripheral staining Antibodies to double-stranded DNA, and sometimes to nuclear envelope proteins
Speckled pattern

One of the most commonly observed patterns of fluorescence, the least specific. 

Antibodies to non-DNA nuclear constituents such as Sm antigen, ribonucleoprotein, and SS-A and SS-B reactive antigens.
Nucleolar pattern

Few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represent antibodies to RNA.

Seen in systemic sclerosis.
Centromeric pattern

Seen in systemic sclerosis

Often contain antibodies specific for centromeres, which give rise to this pattern.

questions.text: An electron microscopic image showing the skeletal muscle sarcomere is given below. The area marked by the arrow is known as the _____ band and its length _______ during muscle contraction.
questions.solution:
The area marked by the arrow in the electron microscopic image of the sarcomere is the A band or anisotropic band and its length doesn't change during muscle contraction. I (Isotropic) band reduces in length. 

The portion of myofibril that lies between two Z lines is known as the sarcomere. One sarcomere comprises one entire A band and two half-I bands. The various bands of sarcomere are as follows: 

  • A band consists of myosin surrounded by actin filaments
  • I band contains only actin filaments
  • H zone is the middlemost part of the A band which comprises only myosin heads. 

During skeletal muscle contraction, the A band remains constant, Z lines come closer to each other, and the H and I bands reduce in their lengths. 

Related Pearl: Sarcomere

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: A patient with myocardial infarction develops a sudden circulatory collapse. On examination, his BP is 80/70 mm Hg and his pulse rate is 40 beats/minute. Which of the following physiological reflexes is involved in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The circulatory collapse in a patient of MI (myocardial infarction) is due to Bezold-Jarisch Reflex. 

Carotid sinus baroreceptors sense the arterial hypotension and trigger afferent fibres that send autonomic signals resulting in an increase in heart rate and contractility, while pressure receptors in the left ventricular wall send signals that trigger paradoxical bradycardia and decreased contractility. This results in suddenly marked hypotension and the individual feels lightheaded and may lose consciousness for a brief period.

The activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. juxta capillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) that causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing is the Bezold Jarisch reflex.

It can be elicited by :

  • Substances like capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, veratridine
  • Myocardial ischemia and reperfusion as a result of increased production of oxygen radicals 
  • Radiocontrast agents for coronary angiography

Other options:

Option A: Tachycardia following acute volume overload is due to the Bainbridge Reflex. The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction.

Option B: Hypertension following a head injury is due to the Cushing Reflex. When the intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to RVLM neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

Option C: Apnea followed by rapid breathing after iv capsaicin is due to the J Reflex. C fibre-endings close to the pulmonary vessels are called J (juxtacapillary) receptors. These receptors are stimulated by hyperinflation of the lungs or intravenous administration of capsaicin. The reflex produced is apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension. This is called the J reflex or pulmonary chemoreflex. A similar response is produced by receptors in the heart (Bezold-Jarisch reflex or the coronary chemoreflex).

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman delivered a baby vaginally, without any complications. After birth, the placenta was expelled and it was found that the cord was attached to the membranes and the cord vessels were traversing between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta. Identify the abnormal placenta.
questions.solution:
The abnormal placenta shown in the image is a velamentous placenta as the cord is attached to the membranes.

The umbilical cord is usually attached at or near the center of the placenta at term.

The cord is attached to the membranes in the case of velamentous placenta. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta. The rupture of the membranes involving the overlying vessels leads to vaginal bleeding and fetal exsanguination. 

Management-

  • If fetal bleeding occurs, urgent delivery is done either vaginally or by cesarean section. The infant’s hemoglobin levels should be tested and if necessary, blood transfusion can also be done.
  • If the baby is dead, vaginal delivery is allowed to occur.

The below image shows velamentous placenta:

 When velamentous placenta is associated with vasa previa, there is an increased chance of rupture of vessels and bleeding:

Option A- Circumvallate placenta is a type of placenta extrachorialis. There is a smaller chorionic plate as compared to the basal plate. The amnion and chorion fold and roll back on themselves to form a ring that is reflected centrally. This leaves a rim of placental tissue exposed extrachorially. There is an increased chance of abortions, hydrorrhea gravidarum, antepartum hemorrhage, growth retardation of the fetus, preterm delivery, and retained placenta and membranes. 

The below image shows circumvallate placenta:

Option B- Battledore placenta, where the cord is attached to the margin of the placenta. When it is associated with a Previa or a low-lying placenta, there can be cord compression, fetal anoxia, and fetal death.

The below image shows battledore placenta:

Option D- Succenturiate placenta is characterized by the presence of one or more small lobes of placenta placed at varying distances from the main placental margins. A leash of blood vessels connects these accessory cotyledons to the main placenta. If these vessels are absent, then it is called placenta spuria. If this lobe is retained postpartum, there can be primary or secondary postpartum hemorrhage, subinvolution of uterus, uterine sepsis, polyp formation. 

The below image shows succenturiate placenta:

questions.text: A woman presents with progressive swelling of the lower limb, as shown below. On examination, there is non-pitting edema associated with the thickening of the skin. Which type of biological transmission is seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of progressive unilateral lower limb edema, which is non-pitting and associated with thickening of the skin, is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis. The microfilaria of the causative agent W. bancrofti undergoes cyclo-developmental biological transmission. 

Lymphatic filariasis occurs due to the transmission of Wuchereria bancrofti by the bite of Culex mosquitoes. It undergoes only developmental changes and no multiplication in the vector, known as cyclo-developmental transmission.

Epidemiological classification of vector-borne diseases by methods in which vectors are involved in the transmission and propagation of parasites : 

Mechanical transmission: Here, an arthropod carries the infectious agent by either crawling or flying or is excreted by the vector at the site of infection. The infectious organism does not undergo multiplication or development during its transmission by the vector.

Biological transmission: The vector serves as a site for development, multiplication, or both for the infectious agent. It is of three types :

  • Propagative
  • Cyclo-propagative
  • Cyclo-developmental

The image below demonstrates the life-cyle of Wuchereria bancrofti:

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text: A male patient presents to the surgery OPD with complaints of perianal pain and intermittent purulent discharge. Upon examination, he was found to have a perianal fistula. Identify the inter-sphincteric fistula in the image below.
questions.solution:
The intersphincteric fistula in the given image is 1.

The other structures marked in the image are: 

  • 2-trans-shincteric fistula
  • 3-supra-sphincteric fistula
  • 4-extra-sphincteric fistula 

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin. The most common cause is a perianal abscess. Other causes include tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.

Symptoms:

  • Perianal pain
  • Discharge- intermittent purulent discharge (which may be bloody) 

Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula.

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

Exceptions to Goodsall’s Rule

However, exceptions to this rule often occur: Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

Investigations:

The investigations done for fistula-in-ano are as follows:

  • Fistulogram
  • Endoanal ultrasound
  • MRI
  • Computed tomography (CT) scan
  • Endocoil MRI
  • Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography

An MRI is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula. (Option-A)

Treatment:

  • Control of constipation
  • Sitz bath
  • Fistulotomy
  • Fistulectomy
  • Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT)
  • Setons
  • Advancement flaps

Related Pearl: Park's classification of fistula–in–ano

 Type of Fistula

Arises due to 

Begins from

Track

Ends in

Inter-sphincteric

Perianal abscess

Dentate line

In inter-sphincteric space

Perianal skin or perineum

Trans- sphincteric

Ischiorectal Fossa abscess

Dentate line

Crosses the internal and external sphincters 

Perineal skin or perineum

Supra- sphincteric

Supra-levator abscess

Dentate line

Penetrates the inter-sphincteric space, continues above puborectalis, and penetrates levator ani

Perineal skin or perineum

Extra- sphincteric

Penetrating injury

Crohn’s disease

Carcinoma rectum

 Rectum or sigmoid colon 

Outside the external sphincter, penetrating the levator ani 

 Peri-anal skin via ischio-rectal  fossa.

questions.text: An elderly patient came to you with lower abdominal pain and was unable to pass urine since the previous night. His wife says that he was prescribed a new medication for his depression which he has been taking for one week. Which of the following drug can be the one which caused the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms point to urinary retention. Among the given drugs, this is most likely due to imipramine which is a tricyclic antidepressant. 

Tricyclic antidepressants have anticholinergic (antimuscarinic) effects like urinary retention (especially in elderly males with an enlarged prostate), epigastric distress, dry mouth, constipation, blurred vision, and confusion. 

Tricyclic antidepressants are mainly used in depressive patients who are unresponsive to commonly used antidepressent such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRI).

Other options:

Option A- Trazodone is an atypical antidepressant with no antimuscarinic effects. It is known to cause priapsim.

Option B- Sertraline is an SSRI with no antimuscarinic effects. 

Option C- Venlafaxine is an SNRI with no antimuscarinic effects.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who underwent renal transplantation a year ago presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever with chills, headache, confusion, and vomiting. On cerebrospinal fluid microscopy, gram-positive rods with tumbling motility at 25°C are observed. Which is the most likely mode of transmission of this pathogen?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an immunosuppressed adult with symptoms suggestive of meningitis, and an organism showing tumbling motility at 25°C points to a diagnosis of Listeria monocytogenes. The most likely mode of transmission of Listeria monocytogenes is through the ingestion of contaminated food such as cheese, fruits, or vegetables.

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus that shows characteristic tumbling motility at 25°C and becomes non-motile at 37°C. The image below shows the tumbling motility of Listeria.

Listeria can overcome the food preservation process since it grows at 4°C, with low pH, and high salt concentration. 

It has cell wall surface proteins called internalin A and B that interact with E-cadherin, a receptor on epithelial cells, promoting phagocytosis into the epithelial cells. The virulence factor produced by Listeria is called listeriolysin O. This helps the bacteria to escape and cause septicemia. They are catalase-positive and show beta hemolysis. This helps to differentiate Listeria from other gram-positive bacilli.

Listeriosis can present as gastroenteritis in healthy adults. It usually develops within 48 hours of ingestion of a large inoculum in contaminated food. It can also lead to the formation of an abscess, pharyngitis, pneumonia, and endocarditis. It leads to neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and meningoencephalitis in the elderly and immunocompromised people. Listeriosis in pregnancy can lead to abortion and stillbirth.

Most laboratories do not routinely culture Listeria from stool samples. The diagnosis of systemic listeriosis rests on the isolation of the organism in cultures of blood and spinal fluid.

Ampicillin plus gentamicin is often recommended for therapy. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is the drug of choice for central nervous system infections in patients who are allergic to penicillin. 

Other options:

Option A- Respiratory droplets are the mode of transmission for pathogens including Neisseria meningitides, respiratory syncytial virus, etc.

Option B- Needlestick injury is the mode of transmission for pathogens including Hepatitis B, HIV, etc.

Option D- Arthropod bite is the mode of transmission of various pathogens including dengue virus, yellow fever virus, etc.

questions.text: A head trauma patient develops a subdural hemorrhage. Which of the following is not true pertaining to the chronic form of this hemorrhage?

choices.text: It arises from stretching and rupture of cortical-dural bridging arteries
It is usually seen in elderly individuals
Burr hole drainage is a preferred method of treatment
Appears as diffuse hypodense lesion on CT scan

questions.solution:
Chronic subdural hemorrahge (SDH) arises from stretching and rupture of cortical-dural bridging veins, not arteries. 

Chronic SDH is commonly seen in elderly patients. It is also a common cause of acute neurological deterioration in them. Cerebral atrophy in the elderly age group results in the stretching of cortical–dural bridging veins, which makes them vulnerable to rupture. The resulting hematoma can expand over days or weeks by osmosis, ultimately leading to symptoms of raised intracranial pressure or focal deficits.

There is usually a history of a recent injury. Even apparently trivial impacts may be responsible for this condition, especially if on antiplatelet or anticoagulant medications. Burr hole evacuation is the preferred treatment in most patients with chronic SDH. Conservative treatment can be considered a case of small, asymptomatic bleeds.

Acute SDH results from the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. The tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses is the most common cause of acute SDH. On head CT scan, acute SDH appears as a hyperdense, crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) lesion as shown in the image below.

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  1. Thickness >1 cm
  2. Midline shift >5 mm
  3. Or GCS drop by two or more points from the time of injury to hospitalization.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text:
Which of the following viruses have segmented RNA?
  1. Bunyavirus
  2. Herpes virus
  3. Reovirus
  4. Calicivirus
  5. Orthomyxovirus
  6. Astrovirus
  7. Arenavirus
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

The following viruses have segmented RNA and the corresponding number of segments in each one of them are as follows:

Viruses Segments
Arenavirus 2
Bunyavirus 3
Orthomyxovirus 8
Reovirus 10-12

Herpes virus is a DNA virus. Rest all are RNA virus but with unsegmented genome.

The importance of segmented genome is that it helps in reassortment of genetic material. This is the reason behind antigenic shift in orthomyxovirus.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female patient had undergone a Pap smear test whose reports show LSIL (Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion). What would be the next step of management in the given scenario?

HPV- Human Papilloma Virus

LLETZ- Large loop excision of the transformation zone
questions.solution:
HPV testing is the next step of management in a woman aged ≥ 30 years whose Pap smear cytology report shows LSIL.

In women aged ≥ 30 years with cytology showing LSIL, HPV-testing is done. If HPV test comes positive, further management is with colposcopy with biopsy. If the HPV test comes negative, both the Pap smear test and HPV test (co-testing) are repeated after one year. 

If either the HPV test or the cytology report comes positive after one year, a colposcopy with biopsy will be done. Whereas a negative report warrants another co-testing at 3 years. Co-testing at 3 years will be followed by 5 yearly routine screening or colposcopy with biopsy based on the results.

However, LSIL in women < 30 years will be further proceeded by annual repeat cytology for two years. 

Cytology

(Betheseda

system) 

 Age Management
ASCUS < 30 years Annual repeat cytology for 2 years
ASCUS ≥ 30 years

HPV testing, Cytology at 1 year
LSIL < 30 years Annual repeat cytology for 2 years
LSIL ≥ 30 years HPV testing

ASC-H 

HSIL

 < 30 years

Colposcopy ± biopsy

ASC-H/ HSIL

 ≥ 30 years

Colposcopy with cervical biopsy and endocervical assessment

ASCUS - Atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance

LSIL - Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

ASC-H - Atypical squamous cells: cannot exclude High grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

HSIL - High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

Mild dysplasia/CIN-I can be treated with ablation, if persisting for more than 2 years. CIN-II and III are usually managed with therapeutic conization, Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP), ablation of the transformation zone, etc.

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented to her gynecologist with postcoital bleeding and was diagnosed as a case of carcinoma cervix stage IA1 after evaluation. She was treated with a modified radical hysterectomy. Which of the following structures are not removed?
questions.solution:
In modified radical hysterectomy/Type II hysterectomy, the uterine vessels are not removed. They are ligated at the level of the ureter. 

Structures removed in Type II hysterectomy:

  • Uterus
  • Cervix
  • Proximal 1-2cm of the vagina
  • Parametrial and paracervical tissue medial to the ureter
  • Pelvic nodes

Indications:

  • Stage I A1 cervical cancer with positive margins following conization, but have insufficient cervix to repeat conization.
  • Stage I A1 with lymphovascular space invasion
  • Stage I A2 cervical cancer
  • Occasionally, it may be performed in
    • Preinvasive or micro-invasive disease when a more invasive lesion cannot be excluded
    • Selected stage IB1 disease with < 2 cm lesion
    • Small central post-irradiation recurrences

Main differences between a modified radical hysterectomy (type II) and radical hysterectomy (type III):

  Modified radical hysterectomy Radical hysterectomy
Uterine artery Ligated at the level that it crosses the ureters Ligated at the origin from the internal iliac artery
Cardinal ligaments Medial half of cardinal ligaments resected Cardinal ligaments divided at the sidewall
Uterosacral ligament  Divided midway between uterus and sacrum Divided at sacrum
 Vagina 1-2cm of proximal vagina removed >2cm of upper vagina removed

 

Related Pearl: General treatment for primary invasive cervical carcinoma

Stages Fertility preserved Fertility not preserved
IA1 Cervical conization Simple hysterectomy
IA1 (LVSI) Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Modified radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
IA2

1. Cervical conization with extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy

2. Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

 Modified Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

IB1

Some IB2, IIA1

 Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or)chemoradiation Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or) chemoradiation
Bulky IB3, IIA2 Chemoradiation
IIB to IVA Chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration 
IVB Palliative chemotherapy or palliative radiotherapy or supportive care

questions.text: A middle-aged woman complains of increased anxiety and repetitive thoughts of her hands being contaminated. She washes her hands repeatedly. Her thoughts are distressing but she is not able to overcome them. If she tries to hold herself from washing, it further aggravates her anxiety. The treatment of choice for this condition is:
questions.solution:
Repetitive thoughts of contamination of hand and repeated hand washing is suggestive of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). Treatment of choice in OCD is cognitive behaviour therapy.

The most common form of obsessive-compulsive disorder is contamination where they have repeated thoughts of their hands being contaminated and want to wash their hands repeatedly. The patients are aware of this, but if they try to resist, it leads to anxiety.

Note: Both SSRIs and psychological therapy (CBT) are first-line treatment modalities of OCD. However, the NICE guideline mentions that psychological therapy is more effective than pharmacological therapy and should be used as first-line where possible.

questions.text: Which of the following marked layers gives rise to the only efferent of the cerebellar cortex?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the marked structure B i.e. the Purkinje cell layer gives rise to the only efferent of the cerebellar cortex. The axons of Purkinje cells are inhibitory to the cerebellar nuclei.

The structures marked in the given image are:

  • A - Molecular layer
  • B - Purkinje cell layer
  • C - Granular layer
  • D - White matter

The cerebellum is covered by pia mater which is seen as thin connective tissue, with blood vessels lying under it. The cerebellum consists of outer grey matter (cerebellar cortex) and inner white matter.

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: The given diagram shows the steps in bacterial cell wall formation. Identify the site of action of the drug of choice for actinomycosis.
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for actinomycosis is Penicillin, which is a beta lactam.Beta lactams act on step 4 in the given image.

Mechanism of action of beta-lactams: They are the cell wall synthesis inhibitor. The β-lactam antibiotics inhibit this last step in peptidoglycan synthesis. They inhibit the enzyme transpeptidase which is required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan chain. Transpeptidases cleave the terminal D-alanine of the peptide chains and form cross-linkages between them. This cross-linking provides rigidity and stability to the cell wall.   

Transpeptidases and other related proteins constitute penicillin-binding proteins(PBP) and, are located in the bacterial cell membrane. β-lactam antibiotics are bactericidal. This is because bacterias swell and burst due to deficient cell walls when they divide in the presence of β-lactam antibiotics. Penicillins, cephalosporins, monobactams, and carbapenems are examples of β-lactam antibiotics.

Gram-positive bacteria are more susceptible to β-lactam antibiotics than gram-negative because their cell wall is almost entirely made of peptidoglycan.

Resistance to β-lactam antibiotics develops due to the production of the beta-lactamase enzyme and the development of altered penicillin-binding proteins like in methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). β-lactamases inactivate β-lactam antibiotics by opening the β-lactam ring. This could be overcome by using drugs that inhibit this enzyme. Examples of β-lactamase inhibitors are clavulanic acid, sulbactam, and tazobactam.

Other options:

Option A: Fosfomycin inhibits step 1 in the image. It inhibits the cytoplasmic enzyme enol pyruvate transferase that catalyses the initial step in the bacterial cell wall and hence cell wall synthesis. It is used for the treatment of urinary tract infections.

Option B: Bacitracin inhibits step 2 in the image. It is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor that interferes with dephosphorylation in the cycling of the lipid carrier which transfers peptidoglycan subunits to the growing cell wall. It is only given for topical application because of its severe nephrotoxicity when given systemically.

Option C: Vancomycin inhibits step 3 in the image. It binds to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of the newly formed peptidoglycan pentapeptide. This prevents further elongation of the peptidoglycan and its cross-linking. It is used against MRSA and Clostridium difficile infection. Redman syndrome due to histamine release following infusion is an important side effect.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman was found to be pregnant at 8 weeks of amenorrhoea. She has 2-year-old twins who were born at 34 weeks gestation and had one stillborn baby, delivered at 39 weeks gestation, 3 years back. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score according to the GTPAL system?
questions.solution:
The obstetric score is G3(1+1+0+2) according to the GTPAL system. The patient has had 3 pregnancies including the present one(Gravida 3), one 39 week infant who was stillborn(Term 1), one 34 weeks gestation twin pregnancy(Preterm 1), no pregnancy loss within 20 weeks gestation(Abortion 0), and 2 living children who are twins(Living 2). Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and term/preterm. 

The obstetric score is used to summarise the past obstetric history of a pregnant woman.

GTPAL system is currently used -

  • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one.
  • T - Term delivery, any delivery that happens at or beyond 37 weeks.
  • P - Preterm delivery, number of deliveries that happen between 20 to 36 weeks+6 days.
  • A - Abortion - any pregnancy loss that occurs before 20 weeks. This includes induced abortions, spontaneous miscarriages, and ectopic or molar pregnancies.
  • L - Living children at present.

GPAL system was followed earlier - 

  • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
  • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability, which is 28 weeks in India 
    • This includes both live births and stillbirths
    • The current pregnancy is not included
    • Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and para. 
  • A - Abortion - the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason before 20 weeks of gestation. This includes induced abortions, spontaneous miscarriages, and ectopic or molar pregnancies.
  • L - Living children at present

This system is not used currently due to the discrepancy in scoring the pregnancy outcome between 20 to 28 weeks.

For the patient in this question, the GPAL score is G3P2A0L2.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient came with complaints of a sudden decreased vision in both eyes and pain while moving his eyeballs. On examination, vision in both eyes is 3/60. He finds it difficult to read Ishihara’s chart.  Fundus examination showed normal discs and vessels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of retrobulbar neuritis. The normal optic disc is an important pointer toward retrobulbar neuritis.

Optic neuritis is of three types, based on the appearance of optic disc on fundoscopy:

  • Retrobulbar neuritis - Normal optic disc because optic nerve head is not involved.
  • Papillitis - Hyperemic and edematous disc with peripapillary flame-shaped hemorrhages.
  • Neuroretinitis - Macular star appearance due to involvement of nerve fiber layer (NFL)

The clinical features of retrobulbar neuritis include sudden painful vision loss, decreased color contrast sensitivity, Marcus Gunn pupil and pain on movement of eyeballs.

Demyelinating disorders like multiple sclerosis are the most common cause of retrobulbar neuritis.

Steroids are the mainstay of treatment for such demyelinating causes.

Option A: Eale's disease is characterized by recurrent vitreous hemorrhages. Due to this, the fundoscopic findings will not be normal. It is a type of hypersensitivity reaction to tubercular proteins. This causes periphlebitis leading to hemorrhages.

Option B: Papilloedema is swelling of the optic nerve head due to raised intracranial pressure (ICP). Here also the optic disc would not be normal. The patient will have symptoms of raised ICP such as headache, nausea, deterioration of consciousness, etc.

Option D: Papillitis will have an abnormal optic disc as described above.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old male patient is being evaluated for sweating, palpitations, and pallor that occur a few times a day. He was diagnosed with pheochromocytoma and planned for surgery. Choose the correct matches among the options given.
Column A Column B
1.Malignant hyperpyrexia A
2.Curare cleft B
3.Rebreathing C
4.Esophageal intubation D
  E
  F
  G
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Malignant hyperpyrexia - D

Curare cleft - A

Rebreathing - B

Esophageal intubation - C

E - Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patients.

F - Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression.

G- Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: A couple arrives at an infertility clinic with a complaint of not being able to conceive even after unprotected sexual intercourse for 2 years. Starting the investigations for the cause of the same, the gynecologist orders a semen analysis of the husband. In a semen analysis report, according to WHO criteria, which of the following is an abnormal finding?
questions.solution:
Progressive motility of 22% is the abnormal finding in the semen analysis. Total motility should be at least 42% and 30% should have progressive forward motility.

Semen abnormalities:

  • An acidic pH or lack of fructose indicates an obstruction in the efferent ductal system.
  • A low semen volume reflects incomplete specimen collection, short abstinence interval, partial vas deferens obstruction or retrograde ejaculation
  • Oligospermia: A sperm concentration <15 million/ ml, and counts <5 million/mL are considered severe.
  • Azoospermia: Absence of sperm in semen due to outflow tract obstruction as a result of congenital absence of vas, infection, vasectomy, or non-obstructive causes like testicular failure.
  • Teratospermia or teratozoospermia: Abnormal sperm morphology 

Note: 

Morphology is the most important factor/marker of semen analysis.

The revised WHO recommendations, 2021 for normal semen analysis are as follows:

Parameters Minimum cut-off 
Semen volume(mL)  1.4
Sperm concentration(106 per mL) 16
Total sperm number (106 per ejaculate) 39
Total motility (%) 42
Progressive motility (%) 30
Non-progressive motility (%) 1
Immotile spermatozoa(%) 20
Vitality (%) 54
Normal forms (%) 4

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is being evaluated for chronic back pain. She also gives a history of using corticosteroids for bronchial asthma from her childhood. On examination kyphosis of the spine is present. MRI of the spine shows a 'codfish' vertebra. Which of the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the MRI showing codfish vertebrae are suggestive of osteoporosis and low body mass index (<18.5kg/m2) is a risk factor for osteoporosis. The MRI of the spine shows decreased bone density with a biconcave appearance of vertebrae known as codfish vertebrae. 

Osteoporosis is commonly seen in postmenopausal women because there is decreased estrogen after menopause. This results in increased osteoclastic activity and increased bone resorption.

Other important risk factors for osteoporosis are:

  • Alcohol
  • Smoking
  • Family history of hip fracture
  • Low body mass index- less than 18.5 kg/m2
  • Excessive usage of glucocorticoids

They present with fractures that occur without any trauma or as a result of low-impact trauma. The commonly associated fractures are fracture of the distal part of the radius (Colle's fracture), fractures of the hip, and fractures of the vertebrae. In severe cases, the fracture of vertebrae can cause kyphosis.

Diagnosis of osteoporosis is made by the T score. T score measures the patient's bone mineral density with that of a young adult. A score of ≤-2.5 is defined as osteoporosis.

Treatment- The mainstay of treatment is to reduce the risk of fractures. Following medications can be useful in the treatment

  • Bisphosphonates. They are the first line of medication. They reduce osteoclastic bone resorption and prevent bone loss. Eg. Zoledronate
  • Denosumab- This is an antibody to the RANK ligand. It prevents the activation of RANK which is required for the proliferation of osteoclasts. Therefore, it decreases bone resorption
  • Parathyroid hormone- Preotact and teriparatide are recombinant parathyroid hormone analogs. At low and intermittent doses, they can promote bone formation.
  • Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs)- They act on the estrogen receptors and prevent bone resorption. Eg. raloxifene.
  • Strontium ranelate- It is thought to increase bone formation and reduce bone resorption.
  • Cathepsin K inhibitor- Odnacatib is a cathepsin K inhibitor that inhibits the activity of collagenases.
  • Sclerostin inhibitor- Sclerostin inhibits the activity of osteoblasts. Romosozumab is a humanized antisclerostin monoclonal antibody that increases bone formation.

If the fractures are already present, they need operative treatment.

questions.text:
A female patient presents with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. A vaginal smear was taken and saline microscopy was done as seen in the image. To make a diagnosis, how will you use the criteria given below?
  1. Cells on a smear as shown in the image above.
  2. Thin, white homogenous discharge is present.
  3. pH of the discharge: 5.5
  4. Fishy odor on adding 10% KOH

choices.text: Only criterion 1 is sufficient to make a diagnosis.
Any 3 out of these 4 criteria are needed.
Criterion 1 + any two of 2, 3, 4 are required.

questions.solution:
The correct answer is option B-Any 3 out of these 4 criteria are needed.

The given image shows clue cells that are seen in bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella.

Bacterial vaginosis is diagnosed using Amsel's criteria:

Amsel's Criteria: (any 3 should be present)

  • Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge
  • pH of Vaginal fluid>4.5
  • Fishy odor of discharge accentuated on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test)
  • Presence of clue cells on microscopy. Many epithelial cells present with granular cytoplasm caused by small gram-negative bacilli adhering on their surface, these cells are called clue cells.  

Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection characterized by malodorous (fishy smell) vaginal discharge. Causative organisms include:

  • Gardnerella,
  • Mobiluncus,
  • Mycoplasma hominis 

Treatment is oral metronidazole 500 mg BD for 7 days. Alternatively, Ampicillin 500 mg or cephalosporin 500 mg bid for 7 days is also effective.

The given images show clue cells on microscopy. 

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient with cystic fibrosis presents with a chronic airway disease by Pseudomonas. How does inflammation, in this case, differ from the usual process?

choices.text: Neutrophils are continuously recruited for several days.
Neutrophils are not the first cells to arrive.
Neutrophils are not present in an inflammatory  infiltrate.
Neutrophils remain present for a shorter duration than normal.

questions.solution:
In Pseudomonas infection, Neutrophils are continuously recruited for several days. This is an exception to the usual process of inflammation where neutrophils are short-lived, they undergo apoptosis and disappear within 24-48 hours. The nature of the leukocyte infiltrate varies with the age of the inflammatory response and the type of stimulus.

Other exceptions:

In a viral infection, lymphocytes may be the first cells to arrive. 

Some hypersensitivity reactions are dominated by activated lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells.

Helminthic infections and allergic reactions have eosinophils as the main cell type.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child was brought to the OPD as the mother noticed that the scrotum contained only one testicle. On examination, the testis is not palpable in the inguinal region or abdomen. A diagnostic laparoscopy reveals abdominal testes and orchiopexy is done. Which of the following tumors is most likely to develop in this patient?
questions.solution:
The tumor most likely to develop in this patient is seminoma.

The tumor that develops most commonly in undesceded testes is germ cell tumor in situ or intratubular germ cell tumor. It commonly progresses into seminomas.

In patients with a nonpalpable testicle, diagnostic laparoscopy is performed. If testis is still not visualised, the spermatic cord or testicular artery is traced at the deep inguinal ring to locate it.

If a blind ending spermatic cord is found instead, vanishing testis syndrome (or testicular regression syndrome) is suspected. It is the partial or total absence of testicular tissue often due to an ischemic event in foetal life.

The testis once found can be delivered into the scrotum, and an orchidopexy is performed.

questions.text: A 25-year-old, G2P1 woman has presented to the hospital in active labor. You conduct the delivery and now proceed to active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL).  Which of the following is not recommended in AMTSL according to WHO?
questions.solution:
Sustained uterine massage is not recommended according to WHO guidelines for active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL). 

AMTSL recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonic (Oxytocin). Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV.
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping for at least 1-3 minutes. This reduces rates of anemia in infants.
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women

Note: Sustained uterine massage is not recommended

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum haemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor to decrease PPH. Delayed cord clamping is a less important component in this direction and similarly, cord traction is not as critical.

Uterine massage does not form the main component of AMTSL yet may be recommended by some and to be considered with the warning that evidence for this practice is not strong.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with silvery-white scaly lesions on the extensor aspect of the elbows and knee. The clinical diagnosis is assisted by ______.
questions.solution:
The presence of silvery-white scaly lesions on the extensor aspect of the elbows and knee is a characteristic feature seen in psoriasis. The condition can be diagnosed clinically by demonstrating the Auspitz sign.

Auspitz sign is due to the elongated vessels in the dermal papilla which are under the thin supra papillary epidermis.

Demonstration of Auspitz Sign:
If superficial silvery scales are removed by scratching (grattage), then the scales come off attached together, as if one has scratched on a wax candle (wax candle scales).

Subsequently, a thin membrane, known as Bulkeley membrane is seen. Removal of Bulkeley membrane reveals classical pinpoint bleeding known as the Auspitz sign.

Silvery-white scales on the extensor aspect of the elbow seen in psoriasis are portrayed in the picture below:

questions.text:
Arrange the following structures of the femoral triangle from medial to lateral.
  1. Femoral nerve
  2. Sartorius
  3. Femoral vein
  4. Femoral artery
  5. Adductor longus
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of structures of the femoral triangle from medial to lateral is 5-3-4-1-2 i.e. adductor longus - femoral vein - femoral artery - femoral nerve - sartorius. 

The femoral triangle is an intermuscular space present in the anterior, proximal thigh. It is an inverted and depressed triangular space. The boundaries of the triangle include:

  • Base - inguinal ligament
  • Medial border - adductor longus
  • Lateral border - sartorius
  • Apex - confluence of the sartorius and adductor longus. 

Contents of the femoral triangle from medial to lateral are as follows- deep inguinal lymph nodes, femoral vein, femoral artery, and femoral nerve. 

The cadaveric image given below shows the contents of the femoral triangle.

The image given below shows the muscles forming the floor of the femoral triangle.

Related Pearl: Femoral Triangle

The femoral triangle is a depressed, intermuscular space present in the anteromedial aspect of the proximal thigh.

Boundaries of Femoral triangle are:

Medially- Medial border of Adductor longus

Laterally- Medial border of Sartorius

Base- Inguinal ligament

Floor (lateral to medial)- Iliacus, Psoas major, Pectineus, Adductor longus

Roof- Skin, Superficial fascia, Fascia lata, superficial branches of femoral vessels–superficial epigastric, superficial external pudendal, superficial circumflex iliac vessels and GSV. 

Note: Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve which forms a content of the triangle also forms its roof as it pierces the fascia to supply the skin over the triangle. 

Contents:

  • Femoral sheath containing lymph node of Cloquet, femoral vein, femoral artery, femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve.
  • Femoral nerve and its branches
  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: A patient presents with the following cataract. What other finding would you expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a rosette cataract, which is associated with iridodialysis. It typically follows closed globe injuries (blunt trauma).

In blunt trauma, there may be minute ruptures in the lens capsule resulting in an influx of aqueous humor, leading to hydration and subsequent opacification of the lens. Commonly there is posterior subcapsular opacification in a flower shape along the posterior sutures. Hence it is called rosette cataract.

Iridodialysis occurs due to dehiscence of the iris from the ciliary body at its root. The pupil becomes D-shaped. The following image shows iridodialysis.

Apart from this, blunt trauma can cause a ring-shaped anterior subcapsular opacity underneath the Vossius ring. 

Option A: Kayser-Fleischer ring is seen in Wilson disease. It maybe associated with sunflower cataract.This conditions are due to copper deposition.

Option B: Micro-aneurysms of retinal vessels is seen in diabetic retinopathy. Diabetic patients can also develop snowflake cataract.

Option C: Vogt stria are seen in keratoconus.These are deep, vertical, stromal stress lines. There is no specific cataract associated with it.

questions.text: The image shown below represents which type of mechanical asphyxia?
questions.solution:
The type of strangulation shown in the image is Burking. 

Burking is a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter throws the victim to the ground and kneels or sits on the chest of the victim preventing chest movements. He/she then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his/her hands. 

Other options:

Option A: Mugging is a type of strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the crook of the elbow.  Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm. In mugging, the attack is usually made from behind.

The below image show strangulation by mugging.

Option B: Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown around the unaware victim’s neck and then tightened by twisting it with a lever such as a rod or stick within the ligature. Earlier in Spain, garroting was an official method of judicial execution.

 

Option D: In bansdola, one strong bamboo or stick is placed across the back of the neck and another across the front. The victim is squeezed to death by tieing both ends of the stick with rope.

On examination, a bruise can be seen in the centre of the neck across the windpipe corresponding to the width of the stick or the substance used. A similar mark can be seen on the back of the neck if two sticks are used. 

Sometimes two sticks are used across the back and front of the upper part of the chest and squeezed forcibly. This causes laceration of the muscles, rib fractures and interferes with respiration.

questions.text: Which of the following shows Dienes phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Dienes phenomenon is exhibited by Proteus mirabilis.

When two identical strains of Proteus are inoculated at different places of the same culture plate, the resulting swarms of growth coalesce and no line is formed between swarming cultures of the same strain. However, if they are from two different strains, the spreading films of growth fail to coalesce and remain separated by a narrow but easily visible furrow (known as Dienes line). This is known as Dienes phenomenon.

The image below shows Dienes phenomenon.

questions.text: A 43-year-old lady presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in her left hand.  On examination, there is swelling and tenderness over the radial styloid. The test shown in the image below results in acute pain, resulting from the involvement of the structures marked as A and B. Identify the structures.

choices.text: A- Abductor pollicis longus and B- Extensor pollicis brevis
A -Extensor pollicis longus and B- abductor pollicis brevis
A- Abductor pollicis brevis and B- Extensor pollicis brevis
A- Extensor pollicis brevis and B- abductor pollicis longus

questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is De Quervain's disease, which is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (marked as A) and abductor pollicis longus (marked as B). It is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

The image shows Eichhof's test: performed by asking the patient to place the thumb within their palm and clench it with the other fingers after which the wrist is passively ulnar flexed by the examiner. 

It is positive in the following conditions:

  • De Quervain's tenosynovitis
  • Arthritis in the intercarpal and radiocarpal joints
  • Superficial radial nerve entrapment 
  • Intersection syndrome- A tenosynovitis occurring due to friction between the obliquely placed extensor and abductor pollicis tendons, and the longitudinally placed extensor tendons.

Other clinical features of De Quervain's disease include visible swelling over the radial styloid, palpable thickening of the tendon sheath, tenderness at the tip of the radial styloid and pain on resisted thumb extension (hitch-hiker’s sign).

Treatment:

  • The majority of the patients are treated conservatively with steroid injection and splinting.
  • Few require surgical release of the 1st dorsal compartment (housing the APL and EPB tendons).

questions.text: A male patient is brought to the hospital with generalized weakness and a history of diarrhea. He also gave a history of removal of renal stones 6 months back. Investigations reveals metabolic acidosis and hypokalemia. Urine analysis shows a pH of 5.9, positive urine anion gap, hypocitraturia, and hypercalciuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is renal tubular acidosis - type 1 (RTA-1)  or distal renal tubular acidosis. The history of diarrhea and renal stones with metabolic acidosis, urine with pH>5.5, hypokalemia, positive urine anion gap, and hypercalciuria are characteristic findings of RTA-1.

RTA-1 occurs due to defective urinary acidification in the cortical collecting tubule due to ineffective H+ ion secretion by the alpha-intercalated cells. This leads to the formation of urine with pH > 5.5. The decreased H+ secretion also leads to inadequate HCO3- regeneration in the alpha-intercalated cells thus leading to metabolic acidosis. As H+ is usually exchanged with K+ from the lumen in the DCT, decreased H+ secretion is also associated with decreased K+ absorption, resulting in hypokalemia.

Acidosis reduces net proximal fluid reabsorption, which leads to volume contraction and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). This results in decreased proximal tubular Na+ reabsorption and increased distal delivery of Na+ to the cortical collecting duct. These processes, along with increased aldosterone secretion, leading to increased K+ secretion by activation of ENaC (epithelial sodium channel) channels in the collecting duct thus causing hypokalemia.

Ammonium produced as a result of glutamine metabolism is secreted in the proximal tubule, which normally combines with H+ ions secreted in the alpha-intercalated cells of the distal tubule to form NH4+ ions. Since this process is impaired in RTA-1, the urine anion gap (UAG) is positive due to low urine NH4+ concentration. RTA-1 is associated with hypercalciuria and with persistent alkaline urine it is a risk factor for developing calcium phosphate stones. 

Other options:

Option A- Renal tubular acidosis - type 2 or proximal RTA occurs due to generalized proximal tubule dysfunction. Defective HCO3- resorption is the primary dysfunctional mechanism causing metabolic acidosis and is also associated with glycosuria, aminoaciduria, and phosphaturia.

In the initial stages of the disease or during HCO3- replacement the urine remains alkaline, but as HCO3- losses continue, the urine turns acidic with pH <5.5. There is no defect in the urine concentrating mechanism at the cortical collecting tubule, thus urine NH4+ concentration is normal and UAG is negative. There is no associated hypercalciuria.

Option C- Renal tubular acidosis - type 4 also known as pseudohypoaldosteronism occurs due to end-organ resistance to aldosterone and is characterized by hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and a positive UAG.

Option D- Alport syndrome is caused by mutations affecting type IV collagen that result in hematuria with progression to chronic renal failure, sensorineural deafness, and various eye disorders, including lens dislocation, posterior cataracts, and corneal dystrophy.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of renal tubular acidosis (RTA)

   Hypokalemic RTA  Hyperkalemic RTA
