questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with sudden onset dysarthria and impaired sensation over the right side of her face. Further examination shows loss of pain and temperature on the left side of the body. When asked to walk in a straight line, she sways to the right side. Which of the following marked vessels is most likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral medullary syndrome/Wallenberg syndrome. This may result from a stroke affecting the ipsilateral (right-sided, in this case) vertebral artery marked as '4' in the image above.

Lateral medullary syndrome: The clinical findings correspond to the neuroanatomical structures affected in the lateral portion of the medulla:

  • Descending tract and nucleus of CN V (trigeminal)- loss of pain and sensation over the ipsilateral half of face.
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle – ipsilateral ataxia (gait and limb)
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract – loss of pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body. 
  • IX and X CN - ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex giving rise to dysphagia, dysarthria.
  • Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Descending sympathetic tract – ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis).

The lateral medullary syndrome may also occur as a consequence of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) stroke. PICA is a branch of the vertebral artery.

 

Other options:

The other structures marked in the image are as follows - 

1 - Anterior cerebral artery

2 - Middle cerebral artery

3 - Basilar cerebral artery

questions.text:
Effective CPR in infants includes:

1. One or both palms are placed in the midline

2. Chest compressions: 100-120/min

3. Allow full chest recoil after every compression

4. Depth of compressions should be at least 2 inches or 1/4 the depth of the infant’s chest
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 4 are false and statements 2 and 3 are true.

Chest compressions in infants are given by placing two fingers, one between the nipple line and the other 1 cm below it, if only one provider is available. The torso is encircled by the palms of both hands with the thumbs pointing cephalad and positioned 1 cm below the nipples over the sternum.

The depth of compressions in infants should be at least 1.5 inches or 1/3 the depth of the infant’s chest.

Effective chest compressions in infants (<1 year):

  • 100 to 120 compressions per minute (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).
  • One provider: Place two fingers, one between the nipple line and the other 1 cm below the first finger
  • Two providers: Encircle the infant's torso with both hands, thumbs pointing cephalad and positioned 1cm below the nipples over the sternum. 
  • Depth of compressions should be at least 1.5 inches or 1/3 the depth of the infant’s chest.
  • Press hard and fast
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression
  • Effective chest compressions in a child older than 1 year and up to puberty:
  • The compression rate is 100 - 120/min  (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).
  • Depth of compression is 2 inches or 1/3 the depth of the patient's chest.
  • Press hard and fast
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression

Effective chest compression in adults:

  • Provide 100-120 compressions per minute (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).
  • Place your arms, one over the other in the midline, on the lower 1/3rd of the patient's sternum, and lock your arms.
  • Use both arms to press the chest to a depth of 5-6 cm (2 - 2.4 inches)or more.
  • Press hard and fast
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

questions.text: The iceberg phenomenon in epidemiology is not shown by ____.
questions.solution:
The iceberg phenomenon in epidemiology is not shown by measles.

Diseases like tuberculosis, diabetes, malnutrition, anemia, hypertension and mental illnesses show the iceberg phenomenon of disease.

The iceberg phenomenon of diseases is not shown by diseases such as tetanus, rabies, and measles.

The iceberg phenomenon is shown by:

  • Polio
  • Influenza
  • Rubella
  • Mumps
  • Japanese Encephalitis
  • Diphtheria
  • Hepatitis A and B

Note: Rubella shows a large number of subclinical infections. Thus, it is considered to show the iceberg phenomenon.

questions.text: You are a medical officer at the PHC. During the training, the PHC nursing staff asks you about the DPT vaccination. While explaining the same, you mention that the 'open vial policy' is applicable to the DPT vaccine. What do you want to convey by this term?

choices.text: Once the vial is opened, it should be discarded even if it is not used completely.
Once the vial is opened, it can be reused upto 4 weeks subject to certain conditions.
Once the vial is opened, It can be reused upto 48 hours subject to certain conditions.
Once the vial is opened, it should be kept open until it is completely used.

questions.solution:
Open vial policy means once the vial is opened, it can be reused for upto 4 weeks subject to certain conditions.

It is not applicable for BCG, JE, and measles vaccines.

It is applicable for:

  • DPT
  • TT
  • Hepatitis B vaccine
  • OPV
  • Pentavalent vaccine
  • Rotavirus vaccine
  • Japanese encephalitis vaccine (inactivated)

Note: Open vial policy does not apply to rotavirus vaccine with VVM on cap, it applies only to new rotavirus vaccine with VVM on label.

Related Pearl: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an anti-diabetic drug?
questions.solution:
Teduglutide is a GLP-2 analog and is approved for the treatment of short bowel syndrome.

GLP-2 binds to enteric neurons and endocrine cells, stimulating the release of a number of hormones such as insulin-like growth factor. This stimulates mucosal epithelial growth and enhances fluid absorption.

GLP-1 analogs:

  • Exenatide 
  • Liraglutide 
  • Albiglutide 
  • Dulaglutide
  • Lixisenatide 
  • Semaglutide

Note: GLP-1 analogs are used for the treatment of Type II diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A patient presents with LMN-type facial weakness as shown in the image below. Thorough investigations were done which did not reveal any significant abnormality. The doctor as a diagnosis of exclusion prescribed him prednisolone for 5 days and he recovered 3 weeks later. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Right facial nerve is affected and weakness of right half of face
Flattening of the forehead and nasolabial fold on the contralateral side
Corner of the mouth is drawn to affected side
Left facial nerve is affected and weakness of right half of face

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of acute onset facial paralysis recovering within 3 weeks is a classical case of Bell's palsy.

The right half of this patient's face is weak and the right facial nerve is affected.

Bell's palsy is a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve and involves the ipsilateral side of the upper and lower halves of the face. Bell's palsy is idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis, or paresis of acute onset. The onset of Bell's palsy is fairly abrupt. 

If the patient attempts to close the eye, the eyeball would turn up and out - this is known as the Bell's phenomenon. Decreased tearing, hyperacusis, taste disturbances, otalgia, weakness of the facial muscles, poor eyelid closure, etc can be seen. When the patient smiles, the face becomes distorted and lateralizes to the side opposite the palsy. Flattening of the forehead and nasolabial fold on the side affected by palsy. 

Treatment of Bell's palsy involves prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then tapered over the next 5 days. The use of artificial tears and covering the eye at night prevents corneal drying.

Approximately 85 to 95% of patients recover fully. The presence of incomplete paralysis in the first week is the most favourable prognostic sign. Recurrences are seen in some cases. Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigation.

questions.text: A young man presents with painful genital lesions shown below to a Suraksha clinic. He has no other complaints like burning micturition, discharge, or inguinal swelling. Which colored kit should be used for his management?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a close cluster of cutaneous blisters on the penile shaft. This indicates genital herpes. The red kit is used for genital herpes.

Genital herpes is caused by the Herpes Simplex Virus-2 (HSV-2) pathogen. It begins as blisters, on or around the genitals or rectum. These blisters break causing ulcers.

Though other causes of genital ulcers might present with blisters, only the red kit is used for genital vesicles among the options given. He does not have complaints which require the other kits mentioned.

Other options: 

  • Grey kit- for urethral discharge
  • Black kit- for inguinal bubos
  • Green kit- for vaginal discharge

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text: An elderly man presents with halitosis and regurgitation of food for the past 7 months. He mentions that he often feels like food is stuck in his throat. A barium swallow was performed and the findings are shown below. Which of the following procedures is used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and barium swallow are suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. The procedure used for the treatment of this condition is Dohlman's procedure.

The pharyngeal pouch or Zenker's diverticulum is a protrusion of the mucosa through Killian's dehiscence a weak area of the posterior pharyngeal wall between the oblique fibres of the thyropharyngeus and the transverse fibres of the cricopharyngeus.

It presents at around 60 years of age and is more common in men than women. The patients usually experience regurgitation of foul-smelling, undigested food, halitosis and recurrent cough. The diagnosis is usually made by a lateral barium swallow.

The treatment is either endoscopic or open surgery. The endoscopic treatment of Zenker's diverticulum is also called the Dohlman technique. It is a transoral endoscopic approach in which the septum between the diverticulum and the cervical esophagus is ablated using laser, electrocautery, or stapler devices. It can be used for diverticula between 2 and 5 cm in size.

Other options:

Option A: Heller myotomy is used for the treatment of achalasia cardia.

Option C: Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy is used to treat infantile pyloric stenosis.

Option D: Nissen's fundoplication is used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and hiatal hernia.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: A surgeon performs a Dunhill procedure on a patient with thyroid carcinoma. This procedure is best described as:
questions.solution:
Total lobectomy + isthmusectomy + subtotal lobectomy is an accurate description of the Dunhill procedure. 

 

Related Pearl: Thyroid Surgeries

  • Lobectomy - One entire thyroid lobe is removed.
  • Hemithyroidectomy - Total lobectomy of one lobe +isthmusectomy
  • Subtotal thyroidectomy - 2 x subtotal lobectomy (Leaving greater than 1 g of thyroid tissue on each lobe)+ isthmusectomy
  • Near total thyroidectomy - Total lobectomy but leaving less than 1 g of tissue adjacent to the RLN at the ligament of Berry on one lobe + isthmusectomy (also known as Hartley-Dunhill procedure)
  • Total thyroidectomy - 2 x total lobectomy + isthmusectomy

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presented with short stature.His upper segment to lower segment ratio is 1. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
The upper segment to lower segment (U/L) ratio in this child is 1. The U/L ratio is low for his age which makes spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia most likely among the given options.

The lower segment is defined as the length from the symphysis pubis to the floor. The upper segment is measured by subtracting the lower segment from the height.

The U/L ratio is

  • 1.7 at birth
  • 1.3 at 3 years
  • 1 after 7 years
  • 0.9 in adults

High U/L ratio:

  • Rickets
  • Achondroplasia
  • Untreated congenital hypothyroidism 

Low U/L ratio:

  • Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia
  • Vertebral anomalies

questions.text: Four types of breech presentations have been shown below. Which one has the highest chances of cord prolapse?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option 3: Footling breech which has the highest chances of cord prolapse (15%) among the four types of breech presentation.

Overall highest chances of cord prolapse are in a transverse lie.

Types of breech:

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Incomplete: Breech with extended legs (frank breech), footling, or knee presentation
  • Complete: Breech with flexed legs

In frank breech presentation, thighs are flexed on the trunk, and legs are extended at the knees. The presenting part would be two buttocks and external genitalia.

In footling presentation, both thighs and legs are partially extended. The presenting part would be the legs.

In knee presentation, thighs are extended but the knees are flexed. The presenting part would be the knee.

In complete breech presentation, thighs are flexed at hips and legs at knees. The presenting part would be two buttocks, external genitalia, and two feet.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man files a medical negligence case against a surgeon who operated on him for inguinal hernia three and a half years ago. Which of the following defenses against negligence will be applicable in this case?
questions.solution:
Res indicata is the defense against negligence that will be applicable in this case. 

Res indicata specifies that a suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed as being beyond the period of limitation. Legal action may still be brought up to three years after the alleged negligent act where a patient and doctor have entered into a specific contract that requires the provision of care.

Other defenses against negligence

  • No duty owed to the plaintiff
  • Duty discharged according to prevailing standards
  • Misadventure - This may be therapeutic, diagnostic, and experimental. Therapeutic misadventure is a situation in which a patient has suffered harm or has died as a result of an error made by a doctor or agent of the doctor or the hospital.
  • Error of judgment
  • Contributory negligence - the absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant
  • Res judicata (S.300, CrPC) -If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same in another legal proceeding, based on the same set of facts. Multiple appeals cannot be made. 
  • Limitation (Res indicata) - A suit for damages for negligence must be filed within 2 years from the date of alleged negligence against the doctor. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed. But, where a breach of duty to provide care as per a contract between a patient and a doctor is committed, legal action may be undertaken for up to three years from the date of alleged negligence.

Other options:

'Res ipsa loquitur' means 'the thing or fact speaks for itself'. It is obvious evidence of the negligent act committed, such as swabs left in the abdominal cavity post laparotomy.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text:
You are an intern posted in the labor ward. You see that a pregnant woman at her 32nd week of gestation has a BPP score of 2. Her BPP score remained the same when monitored for the next two hours. What is the next best step in this case?

BPP - biophysical profile
questions.solution:
A persistent biophysical profile (BPP) score of 2 for 2 hours points towards fetal asphyxia. Immediate delivery should be done regardless of the gestational age in this patient.

BPP is a multi-parametric screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency. It consists of five components (Mnemonic: BATMaN):

B - Breathing movements of the fetus
A - Amniotic fluid volume
T - Tone of the fetus
M - Movements of the fetus
N - Non-stress test (NST)

Parameters Minimal Normal Criteria
Fetal breathing movements ≥ 1 episode lasting over 30 seconds
Amniotic fluid volume (AFV) ≥ 1 pocket measuring 2 cm in two perpendicular planes (2 ×2 cm pocket)
Fetal muscle tone ≥ 1 episode of active limb or trunk extension with the return of flexion; Eg. opening and closing of the hand
Gross body movements   ≥ 3 body or limb movements
Non-stress Test (NST) Reactive

Each parameter has a maximum score of 2 and a minimum score of 0. So the total maximum score will be 10.

Interpretation of BPP scores:

BPP score Interpretation Management
8-10 Normal, nonasphyxiated fetus Repeat test weekly (or biweekly in diabetic mother or post-term pregnancy)
6 Possible fetal asphyxia

Deliver, if AFV is abnormal or >36weeks or if the repeat test score is ≤ 6

If the repeat score >6, observation and repeat test weekly
4 Probable fetal asphyxia

If >36 weeks then deliver

If <32 weeks - repeat testing the same day - if persistently low, then deliver
0-2 Almost certain fetal asphyxia Test for 2 hours - if persistent score of ≤ 4 - then deliver regardless of gestational age

questions.text: To study the effects of radiation, Court-Brown and Doll (1957) assembled a cohort in 1955 consisting of 13,352 patients who had received a large amount of radiation between 1934-1954. The outcome evaluated was death from leukemia/ aplastic anemia between 1935-1954. The death rate was higher than the general population. The cohort was then followed, as established in 1955, to identify deaths occurring in subsequent years. Identify the type of study design.

choices.text: Combination of prospective and retrospective cohort studies

questions.solution:
The study given here is a combination of prospective and retrospective cohort studies. Here, both methods are combined. The cohort is identified from past records and is assessed to date for the outcome. The same cohort is followed up prospectively in the future for further assessment of the outcome.
 
Other options:
 
Option B: A prospective cohort study is a study in which the outcome has not yet occurred at the time that the investigations begin. They begin in the present and continue into the future.
This study is a prospective cohort study because the subjects (pregnant women) were categorized on the basis of exposure or lack of exposure to a risk factor -smoking during pregnancy. They were followed to determine if the outcome- the low birth weight of the babies occurred or not.
The design of a prospective cohort is shown below.
 
Option C : A retrospective cohort study is when both the exposure and outcome have occurred before the investigations and study is undertaken. An example would be if the charts in a hospital from the previous year were reviewed, and mothers classified as smokers or nonsmokers based on records. The records are then followed through time and then the birth weight of the children in both groups are compared. It is also called a historical cohort study, a prospective study in retrospect, or a non-concurrent prospective study.
In a case-control study of the same, low birth weight infants would be selected as the cases and normal birth weight babies as the controls. The frequency of maternal smoking would then be compared in the two groups.
In cross-sectional studies, exposure and outcome are measured at the same point in time.
 
Option D : A case-control study is another type of analytical study. It is often called retrospective studies. It is a common method used to test causal hypothesis initially. It proceeds from effect to cause. Both the exposure and outcome have already occurred before the start of the study. It has a control and comparison group.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: A 20-year old patient is admitted to the emergency department due to breathlessness and hypotension after a blunt trauma to the chest. ECG of the patient shows the following findings. Which of the following components of JVP is expected to be prominent?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows decreased voltage and electrical alternans (alternating amplitude of QRS complexes), indicative of a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. Promiment x descent in JVP is a feature of cardiac tamponade.

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space leading to impairment of diastolic relaxation of the cardiac chambers. This leads to a decline in cardiac output.

Clinical presentation -

  • Acute cardiac tamponade - Within minutes, due to trauma, rupture of the heart or aorta, or as a complication of an invasive diagnostic or therapeutic procedure. Presents as cardiogenic shock.
  • Subacute cardiac tamponade - occurs over days to weeks and can be associated with neoplastic, uremic, or idiopathic pericarditis. Symptoms include dyspnea, chest discomfort or fullness, peripheral edema, and fatigability.

The characteristic signs of cardiac tamponade include:

  • Tachycardia and hypotension
  • Pericardial rub
  • Pulsus paradoxus - this is a paradoxical reduction in the systemic blood pressure (>10 mm Hg) on inspiration. In tamponade, with an increase in venous return to the right side (during inspiration) of the heart, the interventricular septum bows towards the left ventricle (fixed total heart volume), thereby reducing left heart volume. This leads to a reduction in stroke volume and systemic blood pressure. 
  • Beck's triad - this is a triad of findings in tamponade that consists of :
    • hypotension
    • muffled heart sounds, and 
    • elevated jugular venous pressure with prominent x descent and absent y descent

 

ECG shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans. Electric alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction. When the heart is nearer to the chest wall, it leads to an increased amplitude deflection on the ECG, whereas, a lower amplitude deflection is seen when the heart moves away from the chest wall.

 

The echocardiography shows swinging heart sign, which is characteristic of cardiac tamponade. The pericardial pressures exceed the left ventricular diastolic filling pressures, causing the collapse of heart chambers, IVC plethora, and respiratory variation in volumes and flows.

 

In a patient with clinical features suggestive of tamponade, the best course of action is performing pericardiocentesis, preferably carried out under echocardiographic guidance. In cases of recurrent tamponade, a small catheter may be left in place to drain subsequent collections of fluid. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text:
In a gynecology OPD, 4 patients present with menstrual cycle-related complaints. How many patients out of these 4 have menorrhagia?
  1. She has bleeding of approximately 100 ml with a cycle every 30 days.
  2. She has painful bleeding between two cycles spaced at a 1-month duration.
  3. She has c/o bleeding for almost 10 days with every regular cycle.
  4. She has bleeding of 40 ml but cycles occur every 20 days.
questions.solution:
Out of the 4 patients- a total of 2 patients (Option-D) ie. patients I and III are having menorrhagia.

Patient II has metrorrhagia and dysmenorrhea(painful bleeding).

Patient IV has polymenorrhea. 

The definitions of various menstrual cycle irregularities are:

Amenorrhoea refers to the absence of menstruation. 

Intermenstrual bleeding refers to occasional episodes of bleeding (usually not excessive) that occur between otherwise normal menstrual cycles.

Hypomenorrhea refers to regularly timed cycles, but having scanty episodes of bleeding.

Menorrhagia refers to regularly timed menstrual cycles with excessive bleeding (>80 mL in amount) and/or increased duration of flow (>7 days).

Metrorrhagia refers to normal cyclical bleeding with superimposed irregularly timed episodes of bleeding.

Menometrorrhagia refers to excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs at irregularly timed and frequent intervals.

Oligomenorrhea refers to infrequent, irregularly timed cycles with intervals of more than 35 days.

Precocious menstruation refers to the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years.

questions.text: A patient following chest trauma presented with breathlessness and hypotension. After the Chest X-ray, he was diagnosed with tension pneumothorax. For the definitive treatment, the triangle of safety which is used for a chest tube insertion is marked by a resident. This triangle lies anterior to _______ and below and lateral to _______

choices.text: Pectoralis major muscle, anterior axillary line
Anterior axillary line, latissimus dorsi muscle

questions.solution:
The correct answer is option A- midaxillary line, pectoralis major muscle.

Triangle of safety: It is a safe site through which a chest tube can be inserted. It lies:

  • anterior to the midaxillary line
  • above the level of the nipple
  • below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle

The technique of drain insertion includes the following:

  • The area should be thoroughly sterilized before the procedure.
  • Adequate local anesthesia to include the pleura.
  • Sharp dissection should be done to cut only the skin.
  • Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers; which involves the serratus anterior and the intercostals.
  • An oblique tract is made so that the skin incision and the hole in the parietal pleura do not overlie each other and so that the drain is in a short tunnel, which reduces the chance of entraining air.
  • A drain for pneumothorax and hemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung.
  • A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base.
  • The drain should pass over the upper edge of the rib to avoid injury to the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib. 
  • A vertical mattress suture is inserted for later wound closure. This is important for pneumothorax management but not required if the drain is for empyema (provided there is the adherence of the pleura) because that tract should lie open.
  •  The drain should be connected to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve.
  • Do not attach to a suction device at another end because it may worsen the air leak if the lung is fragile or might even cause a shift of mediastinum if the lung doesn't expand well
  • After completion, check the position of the drain by taking a chest radiograph.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with complaints of upper abdominal discomfort, nausea and bloating for the past 2 weeks. Decision to start on omeprazole was made after an assessment of his symptoms. His past drug history revealed that he has been on voriconazole therapy for 2 months. Taking his drug history into consideration what changes will you make to his current prescription?

choices.text: Decrease omeprazole dose due to CYP2D6 inhibition
Increase omeprazole dose due to CYP2D6 induction
Decrease omeprazole dose due to CYP2C19 inhibiton
Increase omeprazole dose due to CYP2C19 induction

questions.solution:
Omeprazole dose has to be decreased due to CYP2C19 inhibition by Voriconazole. Voriconazole is a strong inhibitor and substrate of CYP2C19. Concomitant omeprazole administration can result in increased omeprazole levels because of inhibition of metabolism.

In a patient on omeprazole 40 mg/day, the dose of omeprazole should be reduced to half when voriconazole is initiated. Additionally, higher levels of omeprazole can also interfere in voriconazole metabolism as omeprazole also inhibits CYP2C19.

Omeprazole serves as both substrate and inhibitor for CYP2C19.

CYP2C19: Common drugs that are metabolized include omeprazole, phenytoin, diazepam, and propanolol. Inducers of the CYP2C subfamily are rifampicin and carbamazepine. Omeprazole is an inhibitor.

CYP2D6: Drugs metabolized include SSRIs,  tricyclic antidepressants, antiarrhythmic drugs, beta-blockers, and opiates. It is inhibited by quinidine and it will prevent the formation of morphine from codeine. Hence quinidine decreases the analgesic effect of codeine.

Following drugs are metabolized by CYP2C19 :-

  • Omeprazole
  • Clopidogrel
  • Voriconazole
  • Mephenytoin
  • Proguanil
  • Hexobarbital

questions.text: An elderly man presenting with bladder outlet obstruction undergoes an extensive workup. PSA levels are 25 ng/ml. Adenocarcinoma of the prostate was confirmed on biopsy. This condition commonly arises from which zone of the gland?
questions.solution:
Prostatic carcinoma arises from the peripheral zone (B) of the gland.

The prostate has three distinct zones as follows:

ZONE STRUCTURES ENCLOSED CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
Transitional zone Urethra  The common site for BPH (benign prostatic hyperplasia)
Central zone Ejaculatory ducts Rarely diseased
Peripheral zone

Central transitional zone

Pre-prostatic urethra

 The common site for prostatic carcinoma

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) arises from the transitional zone.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years  They may range from indolent lesions that cause no harm to aggressive metastatic tumors. Most cancers are clinically silent and are detected on routine rectal examination or PSA measurements.

Grossly, malignant tissue is gritty and firm in consistency (in contrast to the spongy appearance of benign tissue) and thus more readily palpable on digital rectal examination. 

Only advanced disease gives rise to symptoms:

  • Bladder outlet obstruction
  • Pelvic pain and haematuria
  • Bone pain, arthritis
  • Anemia or pancytopenia
  • Renal failure

PSA (prostate specific antigen) is a glycoprotein peptidase that facilitates the liquefaction of semen. It is useful for screening and for monitoring response to therapy but is neither specific nor sensitive to the condition as it can be elevated due to old age and benign conditions such as prostatitis and BPH. A PSA >10ng/ mL is suggestive of cancer and >35 ng/ml is almost diagnostic of advanced prostate cancer. Following radical prostatectomy, the serum PSA should fall to undetectable levels

A prostate biopsy using an automated gun is used to confirm the diagnosis. Around 12 systematic biopsy cores are obtained. This procedure can be done by transrectal or transperineal approach.

Gleason grading may be used after the biopsy to evaluate the stage of the histopathological specimen. Gleason scores range from 6 to 10 where 6 is a low risk for prostate cancer while 10 is a high risk.

Staging of prostate carcinoma
Tx Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of primary tumor
T1 Clinically inapparent tumor. Neither palpable nor visible on imaging
T1a Incidental histologic findings in 5% or less of tissue resected
T1b Incidental histologic findings in more than 5% of tissue resected
T1c Tumors identified by needle biopsy (for example, because of elevated PSA)
T2

Tumor confined within the prostate
T2a

A tumor involves one-half of one lobe or less
T2b

Tumor involves more than one-half of one lobe but not both lobes
T2c

Tumor involves both lobes
T3

Tumors extend through the prostate capsule
T3a The extracapsular extension (unilateral or bilateral)
T3b

Tumor invades seminal vesicle(s)
T4 Tumor is fixed or invades adjacent structures other than seminal vesicles, such as the external sphincter, rectum, bladder, levator muscles, and/or pelvic wall

Management of prostatic carcinoma:

Management of prostatic carcinoma   
Stage of cancer Age>70 or Gleason score=6  Age<70 or Gleason score>6    
Early prostate cancer: T1, T2A Active surveillance Radical prostatectomy   
Locally advanced prostate cancer: T2B, T2C, T3, T4, N1 Brachytherapy + Androgen deprivation therapy Brachytherapy + Radical prostatectomy
Metastatic prostate cancer   

Androgen deprivation therapy

Chemotherapy and radiotherapy (hormone-resistant  tumor)

Radiopharmaceutical therapy (hormone-resistant bony metastasis) 

Active surveillance is done when there is:

  • Gleason's score of 6
  • Early-stage disease (T1c)
  • Small volume disease on biopsy
  • Low PSA (< 10 ng/ml)

Active surveillance protocols include a digital rectal examination and PSA monitoring every 3 to 6 months, with TRUS-guided prostate biopsies every 1 to 3 years.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department with palpitations and dizziness. On examination, a new onset diastolic murmur is heard in the left third intercostal space. A diagnosis of acute severe aortic regurgitation is made. Arrange the expected clinical signs in this patient from above downwards with respect to the body part affected.
  1. Landolfi’s sign
  2. Traube’s sign
  3. Muller’s sign
  4. Rosenbach’s sign
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option B: 1-3-4-2.

Landolfi’s sign: Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Muller’s sign: Systolic pulsation of the uvula

Rosenbach’s sign: Pulsation of liver

Traube’s sign: A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

Hill’s sign

 The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20mm Hg

Muller’s sign

Systolic pulsation of the uvula

questions.text: A patient with a road traffic accident(RTA) is sent to you for USG thorax suspecting a pneumothorax. You observe the following findings on USG. What mode of ultrasound did you use and what would be your advice to the accompanying doctor?

choices.text: M mode, nothing to be done
M mode, insert a chest tube at the earliest
B mode, insert a chest tube at the earliest

questions.solution:
The following image is a M-mode ultrasound showing seashore sign which suggests a normal lung and hence nothing needs to be done.

M-mode refers to motion mode. It gives the information about the motion of various structures over time in a small cross section.

On M-mode, classical signs for the grayscale imaging are seen:
• Seashore sign: normal lung
• Barcode/stratosphere sign: pneumothorax

The M-mode image in the pneumothorax demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line and a similar linear pattern deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon, known as the stratosphere sign or barcode sign, indicates absent lung sliding and suggests the presence of pneumothorax.

The M-mode image of a normal lung demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line and a granular or sandy appearance deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon is known as the seashore sign, and it indicates normal lung sliding and excludes pneumothorax at this interspace.

B mode USG refers to brightness mode. It shows two-dimensional images.

questions.text: A part of the nephron which is acted upon by furosemide is impermeable to the transport of which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A part of the nephron which is acted upon by furosemide is a thick ascending limb of Henle's loop, and it is impermeable to the transport of water across it.

The thick ascending limb is permeable to the electrolytes like sodium, potassium, chloride, and other ions which will get transported through it into the medullary interstitium. It is virtually impermeable to water. 

Related Pearl: Water transport along nephron

Segment

Mechanism of Water Reabsorption

Proximal tubule(67%)

Osmosis, AQ 1

Loop of Henle (15%)

Descending thin limb only; aquaporin 1 channels

Early distal convoluted tubule(0%)

No water reabsorption

Late distal tubule and collecting duct (8-17%)

Passive(aquaporin-2) under the influence of ADH

Related Pearl: Site and mechanism of action of diuretics

Diuretics  Site of action  

Enzyme/receptor/transporter inhibited 
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors   Proximal tubule   Carbonic anhydrase  
Loop diuretics  Thick ascending loop of Henle  Na+- K+- 2Cl- symporter
Thiazides Distal convoluted tubule  Na+- Cl- symporter
Epithelial sodium channel inhibitors  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts   ENaC 
Aldosterone antagonists  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts  Mineralocorticoid receptors (indirectly ENaC)

questions.text: In past, many screening tests were introduced without subjecting them to rigid scrutiny. A modern view is that they should be implemented after proper evaluation. Which of the following is not a method to evaluate the screening program?
questions.solution:
The cessation experiment is not used to evaluate the screening program. Here, an attempt is made to evaluate the termination of habit (or removal of suspected agent) which is causally related to the disease. If such action is followed by a significant reduction in disease, the hypothesis of the cause is greatly strengthened. 

Other options:

Option A-Randomized control trials are ideal to evaluate the screening tests. One group (randomly selected) receives a screening test and the other group (control) receives no such test. 

Option B-Uncontrolled trials are used to see if people with diseases detected through screening tests live longer after the diagnosis and treatment compared to the patients who were not screened. Eg, cervical cancer screening indicated that deaths from that disease could be very much reduced if every woman was examined periodically.

Option D-Case-control trials and comparison in trends between areas with different degrees of screening coverage can also be used to evaluate screening tests.

questions.text: Which of the following patient is not having physiological jaundice?

choices.text: A term neonate with bilirubin levels of 10mg/dl on day 3 and absent urobilinogen in urine
A preterm neonate with bilirubin level of 5 mg/dl on day 2 and 7 mg/dl in day 3
A term neonate with bilirubin levels of 5 mg/dl on day 3 and increased urobilinogen in urine
A term neonate with bilirubin levels of 10 mg/dl on day 3 and absent bilirubin in the urine

questions.solution:
The patient which is not a physiological case of jaundice is a term neonate with bilirubin levels of 10mg/dl on day 3 and absent urobilinogen in urine. Absent urobilinogen in urine suggests an obstructive pathology which is almost always pathological.

In physiological jaundice, there is increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, and absent bilirubin in urine.

Physiological jaundice occurs due to increased bilirubin production due to the destruction of the fetal RBCs along with a transient limitation in bilirubin conjugation in the immature neonatal liver. This would lead to an increase in indirect/unconjugated bilirubin. Increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood lead to increased production of urobilinogen which would be present in the urine in large amounts. Urine bilirubin is not usually found in this condition.

It first appears on the 2nd or 3rd day, usually peaks between 2nd and 4th day at 5–6 mg/dL, and decreases to <2 mg/dL between the 5th and 7th days after birth. In this condition, there is reduced glucosyltransferase activity, and probably decreased synthesis of UDP-glucuronate.

The following indications are suggestive of pathological jaundice and it warrants further investigations for the cause of jaundice.

  • Jaundice appears in the first 24-36 hours of birth
  • A rise in serum bilirubin faster than 5mg/dl/24hr
  • Serum bilirubin > 12mg/dL in a full-term infant(especially if there are no risk factors)
  • Serum bilirubin > 10-14mg/dL in a preterm infant
  • Persistent jaundice after 10-14 days of birth
  • Direct bilirubin > 2mg/dL at any time

When the concentration of unconjugated bilirubin exceeds 20-25mg/dL, bilirubin would penetrate the blood-brain barrier and lead to kernicterus.

Other options fit the criteria of physiological jaundice.

Related Pearl: Types of Jaundice

Type of jaundice Serum bilirubin Urine Urobilinogen Urine bilirubin
Pre-hepatic ↑ Indirect          ↑        -
Hepatic ↑ Direct and indirect   Normal/ ↓       +/-
Post-hepatic ↑ Direct          -        +

questions.text:
Match the following columns regarding the classification of amyloidosis.
Type of amyloidosis

Major fibril protein
1. Primary amyloidosis a. AL

2. Hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis

 b. Aβ2m
3. Systemic senile amyloidosis c. ATTR
4. Senile cerebral amyloidosis d. Aβ
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option D : 1-a, 2-b, 3-c, 4-d.

Type of amyloidosis

Major fibril protein
1. Primary amyloidosis a. AL

2. Hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis

 b. Aβ2m
3. Systemic senile amyloidosis c. ATTR
4. Senile cerebral amyloidosis d. Aβ

Amyloidosis is characterized by a number of inherited and inflammatory disorders in which extracellular deposits of fibrilar proteins are responsible for tissue damage and functional compromise. A characteristic feature of amyloid is that it shows Apple green birefringence under polarized microscopy when it is stained with congo red.

Related Pearl: Classification of Amyloidosis

Clinicopathologic Category

Seen in Multiple myeloma and other monoclonal plasma cell proliferation

Seen in chronic inflammatory conditions

AA

SAA

Hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis

Seen in chronic renal failure

Aβ2m

β2-microglobulin

Hereditary Amyloidosis:

Familial Mediterranean fever

AA

SAA

Familial amyloidotic neuropathies

ATTR

Mutated transthyretin

Systemic senile amyloidosis

ATTR

Normal transthyretin

Localized Amyloidosis:

Senile cerebral amyloidosis

Seen in Alzheimer's disease

Aβ

APP

Endocrine disorders like Type 2 diabetes

    

Medullary carcinoma thyroid

A Cal

Calcitonin

Islets of Langerhans

AIAPP

Islet amyloid peptide

Isolated atrial amyloidosis

AANF

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of facial puffiness and frothy urine. Given below is the histological image of the condition. What do you think is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image is suggestive of membranous nephropathy. The given hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained image shows uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall (intense pink color).

Membranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome. It is a form of chronic immune-complex-mediated disease.

  • Light microscopy: diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall without cellular proliferation. Irregular spikes projecting from the basement membrane are best seen with silver stains.
  • Immunofluorescence microscopy: granular deposits containing Ig and complement along the glomerular basement membrane
  • Electron micrograph: electron-dense subepithelial deposits and effacement of foot processes of podocytes.
 Image: The silver stain of the glomerulus highlights the proteinaceous basement membranes in black. There are characteristic "spikes" of the basement membrane between the immune deposits of membranous nephropathy. The black basement membrane material shown here appears as projections in the capillary loops. 

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

Disease

 Light microscopy Fluorescence microscopy

Electron microscopy

Nephritic syndrome:

Postinfectious glomerulo-nephritis

Diffuse endocapillary proliferation; leukocytic infiltration

Granular IgG and C3 in glomerular basement membrane and mesangium, 

Granular IgA in some cases

 

Subepithelial humps Subendothelial deposits in early disease stages

Goodpasture syndrome

 Extracapillary proliferation with crescents; necrosis  Linear IgG and C3; fibrin in crescents

Linear deposits along the basement membrane. 

Disruptions in GBM

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

 Focal mesangial proliferative glomerulo-nephritis; mesangial widening  IgA ± IgG, IgM, and C3 in mesangium Mesangial and paramesangial dense deposits 

Alport syndrome

 Normal Negative Basket-weave appearance of GBM

Nephrotic syndrome:

Membranous  nephropathy

Diffuse capillary wall thickening

Granular IgG and C3; diffuse

 

Subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes), effacement of podocyte 

Minimal change disease

Normal; lipid in tubules

 Negative 

No deposits.

Effacement of podocyte 

Focal segmental glomerulo-sclerosis  (FSGS)

Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis

 Occasional C3 and IgM deposits in the sclerotic areas and the mesangium.

No deposits.

Effacement of podocyte 

Epithelial denudation.

Nephrito-nephrotic syndrome:   

Membrano-proliferative glomerulo-nephritis

(MPGN) type I

Mesangial proliferative pattern of proliferation; GBM thickening; splitting

C3, C1q, C4 deposits 

IgG deposits

Subendothelial deposits

Dense-deposit disease (MPGN type II)

Mesangial proliferative  pattern of proliferation; GBM thickening; splitting

C3 deposits;

No C1q and C4 deposits

No IgG deposits

 

Intramembranous Dense deposits

Fibrillary glomerulo-nephritis

  

Membrano-proliferative or mesangio-proliferative patterns

 IgG4 and C3  Fibrillar deposits in the mesangium and capillary walls

 

Note:

  • Anionic antigens form subendothelial deposits.
  • Cationic antigens form subepithelial deposits.
  • Neutral antigens form mesangial deposits.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent bleeding for the past 1 year. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is taken which is shown below. Which of the following statements is false about the diagnosis?

choices.text: Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is the investigation of choice
Carotid angiography is the investigation of choice
Radiation is done in case of intracranial extension
Blood supply is from the internal maxillary artery

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a 16-year-old boy presenting with unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent bleeding for the past 1 year and a contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) scan showing anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral sign/Holman Miller sign) is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. CECT is the investigation of choice for this condition, not carotid angiography.

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor predominant in adolescent males aged 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity, close to the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen. These patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx that grows to form angiofibroma under the influence of testosterone. Therefore, it is thought to be testosterone-dependent.

Blood supply is most commonly from the ipsilateral internal maxillary artery.

Angiofibroma can extend into the nasal cavity causing obstruction, epistaxis, paranasal sinuses, pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa, cheek, orbits causing proptosis, frog-face deformity, and cranial cavity. The clinical features include:

  • Profuse, recurrent, spontaneous epistaxis - most common
  • Progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech - due to mass in the postnasal space
  • Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion - due to obstruction of the eustachian tube
  • Sessile, lobulated, or smooth mass in the nasopharynx
  • Other clinical features include the broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis, cheek swelling, involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth, and VIth cranial nerves

MRI can also be done that reveals soft tissue extensions.

Carotid angiography is also done which shows the extent of the tumor with its vascularity. The feeding vessels mostly come from the external carotid artery. In large tumors with intracranial extension, vessels also come from the internal carotid system. 

 Staging of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

Stage Spread
IA Limited to the nose and/or nasopharynx
IB Extension into ≥ one paranasal sinus
IIA Minimal extension into the sphenopalatine foramen with minimal part of pterygopalatine fossa
IIB Full occupation of pterygopalatine fossa with Holman-Miller sign; may occur along with the erosion of orbital bones
IIC Extension into the cheek, temporal fossa, or posterior to pterygoids through the pterygomaxillary fossa
IIIA Erosion of skull base with minimal intracranial
IIIB Erosion of skull base with extensive intracranial with or without cavernous sinus

Treatment: Surgical approach is the treatment of choice. Embolization of the vessels can be done before surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding. Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy can also be considered. Radiation can be used in cases of intracranial extension.

questions.text: Postmortem examination of a mine worker who died of cardiac failure, reveals the following finding. Which of the following is characteristically associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The image showing Aldrich-Mees lines are suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning.

Arsenic in its metallic form is not poisonous but when it unites with oxygen it forms poisonous vapors of arsenic trioxide. These interfere with cellular respiration damaging mitochondrial enzymes. It is present in fruit sprays, copper and gold mineral deposits, weed-killers, insecticides, rat poisons, wallpapers, and artificial flowers.

There are several types of arsenic poisoning:

  • Fulminant - When massive doses are rapidly absorbed, death occurs in 1-3 hours due to shock and peripheral vascular failure.
  • Gastrointestinal - This is the common form of acute poisoning and resembles bacterial food poisoning. There is constriction in the throat and difficulty in swallowing. The stools are dark-colored, stinking, and bloody initially and later take a colorless odorless watery form similar to the rice-water stools of cholera.
  • Chronic poisoning - It occurs due to repeated daily exposure. The main features include finely mottled raindrop pigmentation that appears on the skin of flexures, temples, eyelids, and neck. In prolonged contact, hyperkeratosis of the palms and soles occurs along with the development of a transverse white line in the fingernails called Aldrich-Mees lines.

Tests to detect arsenic poisoning:

  • 24-hour urine excretion of arsenic
  • Detection of arsenic by atomic absorption spectroscopy.
  • Marsh's and Reinsch's tests are now considered obsolete.

The preferred treatment option is freshly prepared hydrated ferric oxide which converts toxic arsenic to non-toxic ferric arsenite. DMSA (Succimer),  BAL (British Anti Lewisite), and penicillamine can also be used. 

 

The images given below show the skin manifestations of arsenic poisoning.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: To plan blood transfusion in a patient, the medicine resident asks you to withdraw the patient's blood samples to send it to the IHBT (immunohematology and blood transfusion) department for blood grouping and cross-matching. The serum is needed for cross-matching and RBCs for blood grouping; considering this fact in mind, you will use which vacutainer(s)? (colors in the options indicate the caps of vacutainers.)
questions.solution:
Red and purple vacutainers are used for cross-matching and blood grouping.

Red vacutainer provides serum, which has got antibodies of the patient which will be required for cross-matching.

Purple vacutainer provides RBCs, which has got antigens of the patient which will be required for blood-grouping.

Related Pearl: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with the complaints of mass per vagina, as shown in the below image was posted for operative repair. During a pre-anesthetic check-up, she was found to be unfit for major surgery. Which of the following procedures is recommended in her?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image is suggestive of severe uterine prolapse in elderly women. Le Fort’s repair is recommended in this case.

This repair is done in patients who satisfy the following criteria:

  • Very elderly menopausal patient with an advanced prolapse
  • Do not wish to retain sexual function
  • Medically unfit for major surgeries

This procedure can be performed under sedation and local anesthesia, or epidural anesthesia. The vaginal flaps from the anterior and posterior vaginal walls are excised, the raw areas are apposed in the midline with catgut sutures. This prevents the uterus from prolapsing.

This operation limits marital functions; hence, it should not be advised in women who wish to retain sexual function.

Other options

Abdominal sling operations are designed for women with type II or III degree prolapse and who are desirous of retaining childbearing function and menstrual function.

Sling operations are best suited to nulliparous prolapse. It includes,

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy (Option A) 
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation (Option B) 
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation (Option D) 

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Category Treatment
Nulliparous or congenital prolapse 

Abdominal sling operations:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation
Pregnancy and postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks period of gestation)
  • Pelvic floor exercises
<40 years            
  • Fothergill's repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar's procedure
>40 years - with completed family  Vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair 
>60 years - unfit for surgery 
  • Le Fort's repair
  • Colpocleisis

These are done if the patient doesn't want to retain sexual function

questions.text: HMG CoA is not an intermediate in which of the following pathways?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, tyrosine catabolism does not have HMG CoA as an intermediate.

Tyrosine produces homogentisic acid as an intermediate during catabolism, which is converted to fumerylacetoacetate by homogentisic acid oxidase. Fumerylacetoacetate is further hydrolyzed to form fumarate (glucogenic) and acetoacetate (ketogenic).

Other options:

Option A: HMG-CoA is reduced to mevalonate by NADPH in a reaction catalyzed by HMG-CoA reductase which is the principal regulatory step in the pathway of cholesterol synthesis. It is the site of action of the cholesterol-lowering statins, which are HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors.

Option B: Leucine is a purely ketogenic amino acid. In the penultimate step of its catabolism, HMG CoA is produced which is acted upon by HMG CoA lyase to form acetoacetate + acetyl CoA.

Option C: Ketone synthesis is also known as ketogenesis. In this process, acetoacetyl CoA combines with acetyl CoA with the help of HMG CoA Synthase which is a rate-limiting step to form HMG CoA.

questions.text:
A new couple wanted to delay childbirth after their marriage due to financial concerns. Considering that fact in mind, a gynecologist prescribes a female with a combined oral contraceptive pill which was FDA-approved in 2011. This pill termed as 'Lo Loestrin Fe' contains how much estrogen?

[mcg=micrograms]
questions.solution:
FDA-approved (2011) contraceptive pill 'Lo Loestrin Fe' contains 10 mcg estrogen in a form of Ethinyl estradiol.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week
