questions.text: Which phase of damage control surgery focuses on the correction of coagulopathy?
questions.solution:
Phase 2 of damage control surgery focuses on the correction of coagulopathy, hypothermia and acidosis.

Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definite surgery later. It centres on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries. 

It includes an abbreviated laparotomy, temporary packing, and closure of the abdomen in an eﬀort to blunt the physiologic response to prolonged shock and massive haemorrhage.

Phases of damage control surgery are: 

  • Phase I (initial exploration) - this phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of active hemorrhage and contamination
  • Phase II (secondary resuscitation) - this phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia, coagulopathy and acidosis
  • Phase III (definitive operation) - this phase consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. It typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation.

Related Pearl: Damage Control Surgery

Five stages of damage control surgery:

1. Patient selection
2. Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination
3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
4. Deﬁnitive surgery
5. Abdominal closure

Phases of Damage Control Surgery:

Phase 0: Identification of patient for damage control surgery in emergency room
Phase 1: Emergency laparotomy to stop bleeding and prevent contamination
Phase 2: ICU care for resuscitation
Phase 3: Re-laparotomy for definitive repair

Indications for damage control surgery:

Anatomical

  • Inability to achieve haemostasis
  • Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas
  • Combined vascular, solid and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury
  • Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava
  • Demand for non-operative control of other injuries, e.g. fractured pelvis
  • Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

  • Temperature <34ºC
  • pH <7.2
  • Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)
  • Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s
  • Blood transfusion approaching 15 units
  • Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental

  • Operating time >60 min
  • Inability to approximate the abdominal incision
  • Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

questions.text: What are the maximum values of the Balthazar score (B) and necrosis score (N) that can be given while grading a patient with acute pancreatitis based on the CT severity index?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option B- B: 4, N: 6

Related Pearl: Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI)/Balthazar Scoring for Acute Pancreatitis

Balthazar Score
Balthazar Grade Appearance on CT CT Grade Points
Grade A Normal CT 0 Points
Grade B Focal or diffuse enlargement of the pancreas 1 Point
Grade C Pancreatic gland abnormalities and peripancreatic inflammation  2 Points
Grade D  Fluid collection in a single location 3 Points
Grade E Two or more sites of fluid collection and/ or gas bubbles in, or adjacent to, the pancreas 4 Points

 

Necrosis Score  
Necrosis Percentage CT grade points
No necrosis 0 points
0 to 30% necrosis 2 points
30 to 50% necrosis 4 points
Over 50% necrosis 6 points

The numerical Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI) has a maximum of 10 points, and it is the sum of the Balthazar grade points and pancreatic necrosis grade points. 

CTSI score 0-3: Mild pancreatitis

CTSI score 4-6: Moderate pancreatitis

CTSI score 7-10: Severe pancreatitis

questions.text:
A primigravida with t(21; 21) on genetic testing will have which of the following result regarding blood markers?

N=Normal, ↓=Low level, ↑=High level

β-hCG = β human chorionic gonadotropin

UE3 = Unconjugated estriol

Options  Inhibin-B  β hCG  UE3
A  ↑  ↓  ↑
B  ↑  ↑  ↓
C  N  ↑  ↓
D  ↓  N  N
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option C: Inhibin-B-Normal, β hCG-high, Unconjugated estriol-Low.

Note- Inhibin-A is a marker of trisomy which is high in triple test in a case of down's syndrome baby, not Inhibin-B. 

Primigravida with t(21; 21) has a 100% chance of having a down's syndrome baby. 

Elevated levels of hCG and inhibin-A, and reduced levels of MSAFP (maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein), and unconjugated estriol in a quadruple test suggest trisomy 21/Down's syndrome.

The quadruple screening test is the measurement of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP), unconjugated estriol, hCG, and inhibin-A. It is ideally done in the second trimester, during 15-20 weeks of gestation. The most accurate values are seen during 16-18 weeks of gestation. 

The abnormalities seen on the quadruple screen are tabulated below:

  Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect
MSAFP Low Low High
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
β hCG High  Low Normal
Inhibin A High

Normal /Low

 Normal

Triple test for the diagnosis of Down syndrome includes AFP, HCG and Estriol. AFP is decreased, HCG is increased and Estriol is decreased.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman was diagnosed with a peritonsillar abscess. Which of the following is the least likely complication that may occur in her?
questions.solution:
Periodontal abscess is not a complication that occurs with peritonsillar abscess. Retropharyngeal abscess, laryngeal edema and parapharyngeal abscess are complications of peritonsillar abscess.

Peritonsillar abscess is the collection of pus in the peritonsillar space. It usually occurs following acute tonsillitis but it can also occur de novo.

Other complications of peritonsillar abscess are:

  • Septicaemia
  • Pneumonitis/ lung abscess
  • Jugular vein thrombosis
  • Spontaneous haemorrhage from carotid artery/ jugular vein

The image below shows a right peritonsillar abscess, with deviation of the uvula to the left side.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is found to have a profound neurologic deficit. On examination, the child is hypotonic, has a large anterior fontanelle, markedly separated cranial sutures, and has hepatomegaly. Investigations reveal elevated levels of very long-chain fatty acids. The dysfunction of which of the following cellular structures leads to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and investigations showing accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids are suggestive of Zellweger syndrome. The dysfunction of peroxisomes leads to this condition.

Zellweger syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX family of genes. This results in defective beta-oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids, defective alpha oxidation, and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.

The child presents with: 

  • Dysmorphic facial features like wide anterior fontanelles, markedly separated cranial sutures, epicanthal folds, etc
  • Profound developmental delay
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Renal cysts
  • Chondrodysplasia punctata - calcific stippling of the patellae, hips, and other epiphysis are seen in the majority of the patients.

Biochemical findings will show :

  • Accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, phytanic acid
  • Abnormalities in the synthesis of bile acids
  • Marked reduction of plasmalogens

There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe and infants rarely survive beyond six months of age.

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text:
A patient presented the clinical finding shown in the image. His lipid profile showed serum cholesterol levels to be 283 mg/dL and serum LDL to be 202 mg/dL. His triglyceride levels are found to be within normal limits. What is most likely defective in this patient?

LDL: Low density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with tendon xanthomas and elevated serum LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and elevated serum cholesterol points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia( type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia). This is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors.

This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk to develop atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Features of FH: 

  • Painful polyarthritis and tendinitis are common.
  • Physical findings seen are corneal arcus and tendon xanthomas over the Achilles tendon and the dorsum of the hands. Xanthomas are tumorous masses produced by foamy cell clusters (lipid-laden macrophages) found in the connective tissue of the skin and in tendons.

Diagnosis is done clinically based on hypercholesterolemia with 

  • LDL >190 mg/dl, 
  • Family history of hypercholesterolemia and/or
  • Premature coronary artery disease.

Treatment includes lifestyle changes, restriction of a fatty diet, and pharmacotherapy with statins in heterozygous FH patients.

Recent drugs for specific treatment of homozygous FH are:

  • Lomitapide, a microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) inhibitor, and
  • Mipomersen, an antisense oligonucleotide against apoB.

 A plain lateral radiograph of both ankles shows bilateral symmetrical swellings (arrows) superior to the calcaneum.

Other options

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. There is an increased risk of atherosclerosis.

The image below shows enlarged yellow-orange colored tonsils in Tangier's disease.

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes type I hyperlipoproteinemia due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk of coronary disease. Instead, patients have an increased risk of acute pancreatitis. This is due to very high triglyceride levels. It can also cause a milky appearance of plasma.

Option D: Acid lipase deficiency can lead to Wolman's disease which is a lysosomal storage disease. Pathognomic feature of this condition is adrenal calcification. So patients generally present with adrenal insufficiency and are neonates.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text:
A young woman delivered a baby at 34 weeks of gestation due to abruptio placenta. After four days of delivery, she developed bleeding from venipuncture sites, petechiae, and ecchymoses over her body. The lab findings and the peripheral smear are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb- 12 mg/dL
WBC count- 10000/cu. mm
Platelet count- 90,000/μL
Prothrombin time- 17s
Activated partial thromboplastin time: 47 s
Elevated fibrin degraded products
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the laboratory investigations are suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

DIC is characterised by widespread intravascular fibrin formation. The most common causes are bacterial sepsis, obstetric causes (abruptio placenta, amniotic fluid embolism), and malignancies like acute promyelocytic leukaemia.

Exposure of blood to phospholipids from damaged tissue, hemolysis, and endothelial damage leads to the exposure of tissue factors and the generation of thrombin. Thrombin generation leads to fibrin deposition in the small blood vessels, activation of coagulation factors, and consumption of platelets.

Patients will have bleeding manifestations due to decreased platelet counts. The most common findings are bleeding ranging from oozing from venipuncture sites, petechiae, and ecchymoses to severe haemorrhage from the gastrointestinal tract, lung, or central nervous system.

Laboratory investigations in DIC

  • Decreased platelet count 
  • Prolonged prothrombin time PT/TT
  • Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)
  • Elevated fibrin degradation products (D-dimers)
  • Peripheral smear shows schistocytes (fragmented red blood cells) 

Other options

Option A- Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is the autoimmune destruction of the platelets. It may be primary or may occur secondarily due to autoimmune disorders, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and infections, such as HIV and hepatitis C. They will also have a low platelet count. However, a peripheral smear may show large platelets with otherwise normal morphology.

Option B- Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is characterised by pentad- microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA), thrombocytopenia, neurologic symptoms, fever, and renal failure. The pathophysiology of TTP involves the accumulation of ultra-large multimers of von Willebrand factor as a result of decreased activity of the plasma proteases. These multimers cause MAHA. The coagulation tests are normal, and fibrin-degraded products are not elevated.

Option D- Factor V is normally inactivated by protein C. Factor V Leiden mutation results in resistance to the inactivation by protein C. This leads to abnormally high levels of factor V, leading to thrombosis. The patients may have thromboses like deep venous thrombosis and pulmonary thrombosis.

questions.text: A lady with no previous history of chickenpox in childhood develops chickenpox 2 days before delivery. She had an uncomplicated full-term vaginal delivery of a healthy baby. Which of the following is not true about her situation?

choices.text: Baby is at high risk of developing a disseminated disease
Baby should receive varicella zoster immunoglobulin
Give prophylactic acyclovir to the baby

questions.solution:
Prophylactic acyclovir is not recommended for the baby. The neonate should be treated with acyclovir only when signs of neonatal infection develop despite administering varicella zoster immunoglobulin.

The severity of neonatal infection is inversely related to the concentration of maternal antibodies present in the newborn circulation. The mother starts producing and transferring antibodies approximately five days after the onset of her disease. Thus babies born 5 days or more from the beginning of maternal disease will be protected.

Varicella-zoster IG is recommended for neonates whose mothers develop VZV rash from five days before delivery up to two days after delivery. Neonates born before or after this time probably do not need passive immunization because they are not at risk of severe neonatal chickenpox.

Antiviral treatment should be started in a neonate exposed to varicella when there is a disseminated disease( pneumonia, encephalitis, thrombocytopenia and severe hepatitis)

Varicella in pregnant women :

The contraction of the virus by a pregnant woman increases the risk of the fetus to congenital varicella syndrome. This is seen in mothers who are affected during the first 20 weeks of gestation. Affected babies present with the following :

  • Fetal wastage
  • Cutaneous scars
  • Atrophied limbs
  • Microcephaly
  • Low birth weight
  • Cataract
  • Microphthalmia
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Deafness
  • Cerebral-cortical atrophy

Prevention:

  • Varicella-Zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) is given as post-exposure prophylaxis within 72 hours of exposure and has been recommended for prevention of chickenpox in exposed susceptible individuals, particularly in immunosuppressed persons such as:
    • Persons receiving immunosuppressive therapy
    • Persons with congenital cellular immunodeficiency
    • Persons with acquired immunodeficiency including HIV/AIDS
    • Exposed pregnant women
    • Newborns
    • Premature infants of low birth weight
  • Live attenuated vaccine is administered to children who have not had chickenpox between the age of 12 to 18 months.

questions.text: A person doing endurance exercises will get energy from the aerobic system for ______ duration.
questions.solution:
A person doing endurance exercises will get energy from the aerobic system for an unlimited time (as long as nutrients last) duration.

The following systems are used during endurance as sources of energy:

  • Phosphocreatine-creatine system - the combined amounts of cell ATP and cell phosphocreatine provide energy. These substances together can provide maximal muscle power for 8 to 10 seconds.
  • Glycogen–lactic acid system - can provide 1.3 to 1.6 minutes of maximal muscle activity.
  • Aerobic system - the oxidation of foodstuffs in the mitochondria provides energy. It can sustain muscle activity for an unlimited time (as long as nutrients last).

The phosphagen system is used by the muscle for power surges for seconds. Following this, a glycogen-lactic acid system provides extra power during intermediate races such as 200-800 meter runs, and lastly, the aerobic system provides energy for prolonged athletic activity.

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination, foul-smelling discharge and yellowish-green crusts are present in the nasal cavity. Which of the following composition of alkaline solution (per 280ml of water) can be used in this patient to remove the crusts?

choices.text: Soda bicarbonate 2 part, Sodium biborate 1 part, Calcium chloride 2 parts
Soda bicarbonate 1 part, Sodium biborate 1 part, Sodium chloride 2 parts
Calcium bicarbonate 1 part, Sodium biborate 2 part, Sodium chloride 2 parts
Magnesium bicarbonate 1 part, Sodium biborate 2 part, Potassium chloride 2 parts

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of anosmia, foul-smelling discharge, and yellowish-green crusts in the nasal cavity points to a diagnosis of atrophic rhinitis.

The composition of alkaline solution is soda bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, and sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water.

It is used to irrigate the nasal cavities. It loosens the crusts and helps in its removal.

Other treatment options:

  • 25% glucose in glycerine
  • Estradiol spray
  • Submucosal placental extract
  • Local antibiotics
  • Potassium iodide
  • Systemic use of streptomycin

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash, and swelling of her hands and feet for the past 5 days. There is desquamative skin rash, edema of hands and feet, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Changes in the tongue and hands are as shown in the image.  Which of the following is not a complication of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of Kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome. The complication not seen in Kawasaki disease is thrombocytopenia.

Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It is commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age.

Complications include:

  • Coronary artery aneurysms and thrombosis
  • Myocardial infarction due to stenosis of the coronary artery at the site of aneurysm
  • Hydrops of gall bladder
  • Sterile pyuria (urethritis)
  • Arthritis
  • Aseptic meningitis
  • Thrombocytosis (late)
  • Diarrhea
  • Peripheral aneurysms and gangrene.

Clinical features include:

  • Fever
  • Conjunctival and oral erythema
  • Blistering, edema of hands and feet
  • Erythema of palms and soles
  • Desquamative rash
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy

The disease is usually self-limiting. In some cases, the disease may involve the coronary artery leading to thrombosis and acute myocardial infarction. Intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin may be given to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.

Related Pearl: Kawasaki disease criteria

Diagnostic criteria of Kawasaki disease: 

Fever of five days or more duration plus four out of the following five criteria:

  1. Oropharyngeal changes (90% of cases)
  2. Changes in peripheral extremities (90% of cases)
  3. Cervical lymphadenopathy (~75% of cases)
  4. Polymorphous rash (95% of cases)
  5. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival infection (90% of cases)

questions.text: The government of India starts a new initiative where rehabilitation centers are opened across the country to support wounded soldiers in dealing with the disability sustained. Which level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.solution:
The rehabilitation of wounded soldiers falls under the tertiary level of prevention.

The tertiary level of prevention signifies intervention in the late pathogenesis phase. Tertiary prevention can be defined as "all measures available to reduce or limit impairments and disabilities, minimize suffering caused by existing departures from good health and to promote the patient's adjustment to irremediable conditions".

Other levels of prevention :

  1. Primordial prevention :
    • Involves the prevention of the emergence or development of risk factors in countries or population groups in which they have not yet appeared.
    • Examples include adult health problems like obesity and hypertension have an early onset due to the mode of lifestyle like smoking, eating patterns and physical exercise which are discouraged from early childhood
    • The main intervention in primordial prevention is through individual and mass education.
  2. Primary prevention :
    • These are defined as "action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur''
    • It signifies intervention in the pre-pathogenesis phase of a disease or health problem
    • Primary prevention is accomplished by measures promoting general health and well-being, and the quality of life of people by specific protective measures.
    • They include two strategies 
      • Population (mass) strategy: Where the target group is the whole population
      • High-risk strategy: Where the target group is limited to the people who are most at risk of developing a particular disease
    • Examples: Immunization, sanitation, and protection of food.
  3. Secondary prevention:
    • This is defined as the "action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications".
    • The specific interventions are early diagnoses like screening tests and adequate treatment.
    • The main aim of secondary prevention is to arrest the disease process.
    • Secondary prevention is largely the domain of clinical medicine and health programs initiated by governments.
    • It is an imperfect tool in the control of the transmission of disease. It is often more expensive and less effective than primary prevention.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

Level

Specific causal or risk factors

questions.text: The structure that is related to the area marked 'A' in the given image is derived from:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the left lung and structure related to the marked area 'A' is the arch of the aorta which is derived from the left fourth aortic arch.

In the given image, the left lung is identified by the presence of the vertical sequence of structures at the left hilum - pulmonary artery, principal (hyparterial) bronchus, and inferior pulmonary vein. The image also shows an oblique fissure dividing the lung into superior and inferior lobes.

The aortic arches or pharyngeal arch arteries are a series of six paired embryological vascular structures. They give rise to the great arteries of the neck and head. They are ventral to the dorsal aorta and arise from the aortic sac.

The 4th aortic arch persists on both sides and forms different structures on either side:

  • Left side - part of the arch of the aorta between the left common carotid and the left subclavian arteries
  • Right side - proximal segment of the right subclavian artery

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Various Aortic Arches

The aortic arches or pharyngeal arch arteries are a series of six paired embryological vascular structures which give rise to the great arteries of the neck and head. They are ventral to the dorsal aorta and arise from the aortic sac.

The following table shows various arterial structures derived from the aortic arches: 

Aortic arches

Arterial Structures

First aortic arches

Part of maxillary arteries bilaterally

Second aortic arches

Stapedial and hyoid arteries bilaterally

Third aortic arches

Common carotid arteries and proximal portion of internal carotid arteries bilaterally

Fourth aortic arches

Right: Proximal portion of the right subclavian artery

Left: aortic arch

Fifth aortic arch

Regress completely

Sixth aortic arch

Right: proximal right pulmonary artery

Left: proximal left pulmonary artery, ductus arteriosus

questions.text:
Which of the following localities will be considered an 'urban locality' in the Indian context?
Locality No. of inhabitants

Density 
(persons/sq. mile)

Adult men engaged in non-agricultural jobs
A 1000 390 75%
B 1000 390 25%
C 5000 1000 25%
D 10,000 1000 75%
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Locality D.

Definition of an urban locality in the Indian context:

  • Towns (places with the municipal corporation, municipal area committee, town committee, notified area committee/ cantonment board)
  • ≥ 5000 inhabitants
  • Density: 1000 persons/sq mile Or 390 persons/sq km
  • Pronounced urban characteristics
  • At least three-fourths (75%) of the adult male population are employed in pursuits other than agriculture.

In the given question, the correct answer is Locality D which has 10,000 inhabitants (which is ≥ 5000), density is 1000 persons/sq mile, and 75% of the adult male population is employed in pursuits other than agriculture.

questions.text: The structure that is present in the deep perineal pouch is?
questions.solution:
Bulbourethral glands lie within the deep perineal pouch.

The perineal membrane divides the urogenital triangle into two parts: the deep perineal space, which lies above the membrane, and the superficial perineal space, which lies below it.

Contents of the deep perineal pouch:

  • Membranous urethra
  • Muscles: Sphincter urethrae and deep transverse perinei.
  • Nerves: Dorsal nerve of the penis and muscular branches of the perineal nerve.
  • Vessels: Artery of penis
  • Glands: Bulbourethral glands in males

Contents of superficial perineal pouch: 

  • Corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum
  • Three muscles – the ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus and superficial transverse perineal
  • The greater vestibular glands (Bartholin’s glands) in females and the duct of bulbourethral glands in males.
  • Arteries: Branches of the perineal artery (Posterior scrotal and Transverse perineal arteries) and Branches of the artery of the penis (Artery to the bulb, urethral artery, deep artery of the penis and dorsal artery of the penis)
  • Nerves: Long perineal nerve, Branches of perineal nerve (Posterior scrotal, Nerve to bulb and Muscular branches)
  • Clitoris in female
  • Urethra in male

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presented with a history of floaters for the past 6 months. Fundoscopy shows a snow-banking appearance. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of floaters and snow banking appearance on the fundoscopy is suggestive of a diagnosis of pars planitis. 

Pars planitis or intermediate uveitis is an inflammatory condition that affects the pars plana of the ciliary body, the peripheral retina, the choroid, and the vitreous base.

Individuals in their 2nd and 4th decade are typically more prone to this condition. It affects both eyes more commonly and is usually idiopathic in nature.

Patients often complain of floaters and deterioration of vision.

Examination shows:

  • Snowball or cotton ball opacities (ant's eggs): Exudates near the ora serrate in the inferior quadrant.
  • Snow banking (hallmark of pars planitis): It is formed by the coalescence of the snowball opacities.
  • Occasional keratic precipitates due to spill-over anterior uveitis.
  • Anterior vitreous condensation.

Treatment is planned according to the modified 4 steps protocol of Kaplan:

  • Step 1: Periocular and systemic steroids are administered.
  • Step 2: Immunosuppressive drugs such as cyclosporine, azathioprine, methotrexate, or cyclophosphamide are given.
  • Step 3: Cryotherapy or indirect laser photocoagulation is tried in cases with snow banking.
  • Step 4: Pars-plana vitrectomy is indicated in severe/resistant cases. It helps by removing inflammatory debris and the possible traction on the macula.

questions.text:
A patient develops respiratory failure. The interpretation of his laboratory reports is as shown below. Which of the following is an unlikely cause of this type of respiratory failure?

pO2: low

pCO2: high

pAO2-paO2 gradient : normal
questions.solution:
The patient has type 2 respiratory failure based on laboratory findings. Patients with pneumonia develop type 1 respiratory failure. It is characterized by low pO2 and normal/low pCO2.

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby presented with hypertonia, irritability, and tonic spasms with light. These symptoms rapidly progressed resulting in the death of the baby. An autopsy was conducted and the histology of the brain parenchyma is shown below. Which of the following enzyme was deficient in him?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hypertonia, irritability and tonic spasms with light and the image showing characteristic globoid cells are suggestive of Krabbe disease. The enzyme deficient in Krabbe's disease is beta-galactosidase.

Krabbe's disease or globoid cell leukodystrophy is a neurodegenerative disorder with severe myelin loss and the presence of globoid bodies in white matter.

It is an autosomal recessive leukodystrophy due to the deficiency of galactocerebroside β-galactosidase. β-galactosidase helps in the catabolism of galactocerebroside to ceramide and galactose. As a result, an alternative catabolic pathway shunts galactocerebroside to galactosyl sphingosine. Elevated levels of these compounds are cytotoxic and cause the destruction of oligodendroglia.

The onset of symptoms is between 3 and 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as stiffness and weakness. Patients also have irritability and tonic spasms with light or noise stimulation. They often don't survive beyond the age of 2 years. The brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.

The characteristic and diagnostic feature of Krabbe disease is the aggregation of engorged macrophages called globoid cells in the brain parenchyma and around blood vessels.

Other options:

Option B: A deficiency of enzyme alpha-galactosidase results in Fabry's disease. It is characterized by painful acroparaesthesia, hypohidrosis, abdominal cramping, diarrhea, small petechiae around the umbilicus, lenticular opacities, and corneal dystrophy.

Option C: A deficiency of enzyme beta-glucosidase results in Gaucher's disease. It is characterized by joint pain mostly affecting hips and knees, pancytopenia, convulsions, and hepatosplenomegaly. It shows crumbled tissue paper appearance on microscopy.

Option D: A deficiency in enzyme arylsulphatase A results in metachromatic leukodystrophy. It is characterized by progressive regression of milestones, ataxia dysarthria, hypotonia, spasticity hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and optic atrophy.

questions.text:
What is the amount of calories required per day by these family members respectively?
  1. A sedentary male with a BMI of 30.
  2. His wife, who is a moderate worker and 8 months pregnant
  3. His father, who is 70 years old parkinsonism patient.
questions.solution:
The amount of calories required per day by this family is 2110 Kcal, 2480 Kcal, and 1700 Kcal respectively.

According to the RDA 2020 guideline, 

  • A sedentary male with a BMI of 30 requires 2110 Kcal/day 
  • His wife, who is a moderate worker and 8 months pregnant: A moderate worker female requires 2130 Kcal/day. She requires 350 Kcal/day extra during her 3rd trimester (8th month) of pregnancy. So, she requires 2130 + 350 = 2480 Kcal/day.
  • His father, who is 70 years old parkinsonism patient: Elderly men require 1700 Kcal/day.

Dietary Reference Intakes

  • Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) - The average daily dietary intake that is sufficient to meet the requirements of almost all individuals in a group
  • Estimated Average Requirement (EAR) - A nutrient intake value that is estimated to meet the requirements of half the individuals in a group

The EAR for an elderly male (>60 years) is 1700 Kcal/D and for an elderly female (>60 years) is 1500 Kcal/D.

Note: There is no RDA for energy. The EAR is equivalent to Estimated Energy Requirement (EER).

questions.text: A young man presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He reported significant left hip pain and an inability to bear weight. The affected leg is in the position as shown in the image. Which of the following nerves is most commonly injured in a case like this?

choices.text: Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.solution:
In the above image, the affected leg is in the state of flexion, abduction, and external rotation (FABER). Hence the most likely diagnosis is anterior dislocation of the hip and the most common nerve injured is femoral nerve.

According to the position assumed by the femoral head, anterior dislocation of the hip can further be classified as superior and inferior. When seen from the side:

  • If the femoral head lies anteriorly it is called as the superior (pubic) type
  • If the femoral head lies in the groin it is called as the inferior (obturator) type

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

Radiological findings

  • Femoral head appears larger than normal 
  • Lesser trochanter is prominent
  • Femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualised

questions.text: The skin biopsy specimen, stained with H&E, when observed under a microscope appears as shown in the given image. The appearance is seen in which of the following fungal infections?
questions.solution:
The given image shows asteroid bodies characteristic of Sporotrichosis. They are rounded or oval basophilic, yeast-like bodies of 3-5 µm in diameter, with rays of an eosinophilic substance radiating from the yeast cell. The yeast is cigar-shaped and this phenomenon is known as Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon.

Sporotrichosis:

  • It is caused by Sporothrix schenckii (Sporotrichum).
  • It is a chronic infection involving the cutaneous, subcutaneous and lymphatic tissue leading to the formation of indolent ulcers commonly encountered frequently among gardeners, forest workers, etc.
  • From the lesions in the skin and subcutaneous tissue, the infection can spread via the lymphatic channels to the lymph nodes. This condition is known as “lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis”.

Note: Asteroid bodies are also seen in Sarcoidosis. Those are irregular, star-shaped inclusions seen in multinucleate giant cells.

questions.text: A pediatrician is evaluating a child's developmental milestones. She is able to stand with support and says words like mama and dada. The doctor hands an object to her and lets her play with it. When she takes the object and hides it under the towel, the child searches for it. What other milestone is attained by the child at this age?
questions.solution:
According to the given clinical scenario, the age of the child is 9 months and at this age, the child waves bye-bye.

At 9 months of age, a child is able to stand with support (motor milestone), can say bisyllables like ma-ma, da-da (language milestone), and the child would have attained object permanence. 

Object permanence is the understanding that the object continues to exist even when not seen. When the pediatrician hides the object, a baby who is 4 to 7 months of age would not search for it and quickly gives up, while a baby of 9 months of age understands that the object is hidden and continues to exist, and therefore searches for it.

The other milestones attained at this age are waving bye-bye (social and adaptive milestone) and immature pincer grasp and probes with forefinger (fine motor milestone). An immature pincer grasp is grasping the object from the radial side of the hand. A mature pincer grasp is using the index finger and thumb to approach any object and it develops at the age of 12 months.

Other options:

Option A- A child points to objects of interest by the age of 15 months.

Option B- A child copies or mimics parents in tasks by age of 18 months.

Option D- A child understands simple questions by age of 12 months.

questions.text: An obstetrician determines a primigravida's Bishop's score before inducing labour. At which level does the foetal station have no impact on the final Bishop's score?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option D-3 cm above the ischial spine.

Fetal station at 3 cm above the ischial spine has a score of 0 in Bishop's score so it will not affect the final total value. 

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text:
A patient with erectile dysfunction is on medication for the same. He notices transient blue-green tinting of vision. This adverse effect is due to inhibition of which enzyme?

PDE=phosphodiesterase
questions.solution:
Visual disturbance is due to PDE-6 inhibition with sildenafil, the drug used for erectile dysfunction.

Sildenafil and Vardenafil cause retinal PDE-6 inhibition and can result in blurring of vision and blue-green tinting of the vision. 

The mechanism of action behind treatment of erectile dysfunction and Pulmonary hypertension is due to inhibition of PDE-5

Tadalafil and Avanafil have better PDE-5/PDE-6 selectivity, so their visual side effects are less. 

Note: PDE-5 inhibitors and nitrates should not be prescribed together due to increase risk of hypotension.

questions.text: 25 years old man presents to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of having low mood, not being interested in the surroundings, and decreased appetite. He had these symptoms for the last 15 days. On probing further, he says "I will suffer this way forever and I will never succeed in my life." What is the specific term used to describe this feature in the patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient expects suffering and failure to last forever and does not see a better future. This is described as hopelessness.

The patient presenting with the above-mentioned features for more than two weeks is diagnosed to have depression. Aaron Beck described the cognitive triad seen in depression.

Aaron Beck's cognitive triad consists of:

  1. Worthlessness- Negative views about one's self - A tendency to devalue, to feel personally inadequate
  2. Helplessness- Negative views about the world - A tendency to feel that there is no help available, the world is cruel
  3. Hopelessness- Negative views about the future - The expectation of suffering and failure

Anhedonia - Loss of interest in activities that the patient used to enjoy earlier, decreased ability to experience pleasure.

questions.text:
Which of the following genes is being described here?
  • It is located in the short arm of chromosome 17.
  • It arrests the cell cycle at the G1-S phase checkpoint.
  • It is known as the Guardian of the genome.
  • It is a tumor suppressor gene.
  • It is degraded by the E6 protein of HPV (Human papillomavirus).
questions.solution:
The gene being described here is p53. Following are its characteristics:

  • It is located in the short arm of chromosome 17 (17p13.1)
  • It arrests the cell cycle at the G1-S phase checkpoint.
  • It is known as the Guardian of the genome.
  • It is a tumor suppressor gene.
  • It is degraded by the E6 protein of HPV (Human papillomavirus).

Note: The E7 protein of HPV degrades Rb (Retinoblastoma gene).

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with fever, earache, and stiffness on opening the mouth. On examination, the parotid gland is enlarged, as shown below, and tender. Choose the correct strain used to prepare a vaccine for this disease.
questions.solution:
The clinical diagnosis in this case, based on clinical features and image, is most likely Mumps. The strain used to prepare the Mumps vaccine is Jeryl Lynn. It is a live attenuated vaccine.

Mumps is an infectious disease caused by an RNA virus from the paramyxoviridae family. Infection is caused by air droplets through the respiratory route and also through the conjunctiva.

The incubation period is 12-25 days. Then parotid swelling appears first. It is unilateral, to begin with, but may become bilateral. Some patients may have a prodrome of fever and malaise before the swelling appears.

Major complications of Mumps include epididymal orchitis and meningoencephalitis.

Mumps vaccine is given only after one year of age because, before that, maternal antibodies may interfere with its action. It can be given separately or as a part of Measles, Mumps, Rubella (MMR) vaccine.

Other options:

Option A: Edmonston-Zagreb strain is used for the Measles vaccine.

Option B: The 17D strain is used for the Yellow fever vaccine.

Option C: The Oka strain is used for the Varicella vaccine.

questions.text: Which of the following BNS/IPC sections related to rape is considered a cognizable, bailable offence?
questions.solution:
The BNS Sec 67 i.e. sexual intercourse by the husband upon his wife during separation is considered a cognizable and bailable offense. Here, the punishment is cognizable only at the request of the victim.

questions.text: A patient presented with shortness of breath and a dry cough. His spirometry test shows a restrictive pattern. The HRCT scan is shown below. Which of the following would you expect to find in the physical examination of this patient?

choices.text: Stony dull note note on percussion

questions.solution:
In a patient with chronic shortness of breath and dry cough, spirometry showing a restrictive defect points to a diagnosis of interstitial lung disease. The given HRCT shows prominent honeycombing in the lower and posterior lung zones, likely to be idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). The patient will have bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation.

Interstitial lung diseases are characterized by inflammation and fibrosis involving the lung parenchyma. Although there are multiple diseases under this subset, the clinical presentation for all of them is the same. The patients are usually over 60 years of age and present with progressive exertional dyspnea and dry cough. On examination, fine inspiratory, velcro crackles may be heard. Digital clubbing and cyanosis are signs of advanced disease.

Pulmonary function tests (PFT) will show a restrictive deficit and reduction of TLC, FEV1, and FVC. There is also a reduction in DLCO and may be the first finding seen in PFT. Other laboratory tests should be undertaken if the patient has symptoms involving other systems, to rule out any connective tissue disorder which might have led to ILD.

IPF is the most common interstitial lung disease occurring due to an unknown cause. HRCT shows predominant subpleural and basal involvement, in the form of reticulation, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis. This is known as the usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern. Note that ground glass opacities are absent in this pattern. 

The treatment of IPF is with antifibrotic therapy such as pirfenidone and nintedanib.

Other options :

Option A: Bronchial breath sounds are heard in patients with consolidation, such as in pneumonia. The sound from the airways is conducted to the skin better when the alveoli are consolidated. This leads to bronchial breath sounds.

Option C: Barrel-shaped chest is associated with emphysema. This occurs because of the loss of the parenchymal elastic tissue in the lung, leading to hyperinflation.

Option D: Stony dull note on percussion is seen in pleural effusion.

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: What is the use of the following instrument ?
questions.solution:
The image shows a Placido or Keratoscopic disc which is used for corneal surface assessment. 

There are alternating black and white circles painted on it. The observer (the doctor) looks through a hole in the center at the corneal image reflected from a light behind the patient. Irregularities in the rings indicate irregularities on the corneal surface.

Option A: A pachymeter is used to measure corneal thickness.

Options C: A retinoscopy is used to measure refractive errors.

Option D: A Jackson cross-cylinder is used for the refinement of cylinders.

questions.text:
Identify the imaging modality and the most probable diagnosis for the given image.

DWI- Diffusion weighted imaging

SWI- Susceptibility weighted imaging
questions.solution:
The given image is a susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) and the most probable diagnosis based on it is diffuse axonal injury (DAI).

SWI is a form of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) sequence that is very sensitive to substances that distort the local magnetic field. Compounds with diamagnetic, paramagnetic, and ferromagnetic properties will interact with the local magnetic field and produce distraction. This would lead to a loss of signal in these areas.

Deoxyhemoglobin, hemosiderin, and ferritin are paramagnetic. Bone minerals and dystrophic calcifications are diamagnetic.

The main clinical use is the identification of microhemorrhages/ blood products or calcium that are not detected in other MRI sequences. In diffuse axonal injury(DAI) there are microhemorrhages at the grey-white matter junction which are easily picked by SWI.

Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) is an MRI technique in which contrast within the image is based on the microscopic motion of water. Thus, it is more sensitive to early changes of cytotoxic or vasogenic damage at the cellular level than traditional MRI.

Diffusion gradients sensitize the MR image to the motion of water molecules. Thus, a loss of motion results in restricted diffusion and appears bright on DWI and greater motion produces a darker image. Structures with increased diffusion such as cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) will appear dark on DWI and bright on ADC (apparent diffusion coefficient) maps.

Restricted diffusion on DWI will be seen in the following conditions:

  • acute infarct
  • brain abscess
  • haemorrhage
  • lymphoma
  • epidermoid cyst

DWI is the earliest modality to diagnose acute infarction (as early as 30 min). The image given below shows DWI in acute infarct of the brain:

questions.text:
A primigravida is diagnosed with pre-eclampsia. She presents with a BP of 168/110 mmHg. She is planned to be administered magnesium sulfate following the Pritchard regime. You are an intern in the labor room. How will you prepare the IV MgSO4 for a loading dose?

One vial of MgSO4 has a 2 ml solution containing 1 gram drug.

choices.text: Add 10 vials of MgSO4 in a syringe with no saline.
Add 4 vials of MgSO4 in a syringe with 8 ml saline.
Add 4 vials of MgSO4 in a syringe with 12 ml saline.
Add 10 vials of MgSO4 in a syringe with 8 ml saline.

questions.solution:
A loading dose of IV MgSO4 is prepared by adding 4 vials of MgSO4 in a syringe with 12 ml saline (option C).

In the Pritchard regime, we have to administer 4 grams of 20% IV MgSO4 as a loading dose.

Now, one vial has a 2 ml solution containing 1 gram drug hence concentration is 50%. To take 4 grams of MgSO4, we need 4 vials, but this 8 ml (4 vials × 2 ml) solution has 50% MgSO4.

So, to make the concentration of 20%, we have to add 12 ml saline to the final solution. So we have a total of 20 ml solution with 4 grams of MgSO4 making a concentration of 4/20 = 0.2 = 20%.

Magnesium sulfate is used to treat eclampsia and also prevent it in the following conditions:

  • Severe pre-eclampsia
  • Acute rise in blood pressure to a systolic BP > 160 mm Hg or a diastolic BP > 110 mm Hg or both

MgSO4 regimens:

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4 g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
followed by 10 g (5O%), deep IM
(5 gm in each buttock)		 5 g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2 g/h IV infusion

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient on clopidogrel is scheduled for cataract surgery under topical anesthesia. What would be your advice regarding the drug?
questions.solution:
Clopidogrel is continued as usual as the patient is undergoing cataract surgery under topical anesthesia. Patients undergoing cataract surgery under general or topical anesthesia do not need to stop taking clopidogrel.

Clopidogrel is also continued in patients on drug-eluting stents or bare-metal stents unless they have completed 6 months and 1 month of dual antiplatelet therapy respectively.

For other surgical procedures, clopidogrel is stopped 5-7 days before the procedure to avoid the risk of bleeding. The table below summarises the time interval for discontinuing anti-platelet drugs before surgery.

Antiplatelets Waiting Period
Clopidogrel 5-7 days
Ticagrelor 5-7 days
Prasugrel  7-10 days
Ticlopidine 10 days

 

Related Pearl: Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery

Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery:

Drug Duration before discontinuation

Topical medications

 Discontinue on the day of surgery

Diuretics (except thiazides) 

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Oral hypoglycemic agents (except SGLT-2 inhibitors)

Discontinue on the day of surgery

SGLT-2 inhibitors

Discontinue 24 hours before elective surgery and 72 hours before intermediate to high risk surgery

Sildenafil 

Discontinue 24 hours before the day of surgery

NSAIDs 

 Discontinue 48 hours before the day of surgery

Warfarin 

Discontinue 4 days before surgery (except for patients having cataract surgery without a bulbar block)

Short-acting Insulins 

 Discontinued (except when given by a continuous pump)

Thienopyridines (e.g., clopidogrel, ticlopidine) 

 Discontinued (Except in cataract surgery, patients with metallic/drug-eluting stents)

Aspirin 

 Discontinued 3 days before the surgery (except in patients with prior PCI, coronary artery disease and stroke)

MAO Inhibitors

 Discontinued 2 weeks prior

questions.text: The dose-response curve shown in the following image is seen in ________.
questions.solution:
The dose-response curve shown in the following image is seen in vitamins.

Vitamins show a U-shaped dose-response curve. At a low dose, adverse effects are observed because there is a deficiency of these nutrients to maintain homeostasis. As the dose increases, homeostasis is achieved, and the bottom of the U-shaped dose-response curve is reached. As the dose increases to surpass the amount required to maintain homeostasis, overdose toxicity can ensue. Thus, adverse effects are seen at both low and high doses.

Hockey stick-shaped dose-response curve for toxicants that are also metabolic by-products depicted in the image given below.

Inverted U-shaped dose-response curve (image below) for ligands that downregulate their receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the equipment shown below?

questions.solution:
The above image shows an autoclave machine. It uses steam under pressure. Steam at atmospheric pressure is used in Koch or Arnold steamer.

Steam at atmospheric pressure (1000C) is used in Koch or Arnold steamer (image below). It is used to sterilize culture media which may decompose if exposed to higher temperatures.

questions.text:
An elderly man presents with fatigue and weight loss. Physical examination revealed pallor and splenomegaly. 
Investigations:
Hb-10 mg/dL, 
Total leukocyte count- 1,50,000/mm3, 
Basophils-18% of TLC,
platelets- 5,00,000 per microliter,
LAP (leucocyte alkaline phosphatase) score decreased.
The peripheral smear is shown below. 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and chromosome translocation associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of fatigue, significant weight loss, splenomegaly, a white blood cell count of 1.5 lakh/mm3, and a low LAP score, point towards the diagnosis of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).  

CML is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder. Males are more commonly affected and the median age of diagnosis is 55-65 years. CML shows t(9q;22q), a translocation between BCR and ABL genes, forming the Philadelphia chromosome. This results in the activation of tyrosine kinase, which causes abnormal cellular proliferation. There is no familial association in CML, nor is there a specific etiological factor. Common presenting features are fatigue, malaise, weight loss, and abdominal discomfort due to splenomegaly. 

Blood investigations may show anemia, leucocytosis (often exceeding 100,000 cells/mm3), and thrombocytosis. It has decreased levels of leucocyte alkaline phosphatase due to a relative increase in abnormal myeloid cells. The peripheral smear shows increased white blood cells with myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band forms which further help to confirm the diagnosis.

Treatment includes tyrosine kinase inhibitors as first-line therapy. Imatinib is the most commonly used drug.

Aplastic anemia
