questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a gradual impairment of central vision. On fundoscopic examination following findings are seen. Which of the following is false regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: Autosomal recessive is the most common form
Dark choroid seen on fluorescein angiography

questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis based on the image and the age of the patient is Stargardt disease. The false statement regarding it is vitamin A supplementation is needed. 

Stargardt disease (STGD) is the most common macular dystrophy. It is characterized by lipofuscin accumulation within the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), as seen as snail slime maculopathy surrounded by flecks in the image.

There are three types of Stargardt's disease:

  • STGD1 is the most common form and it is autosomal recessive and is due to mutation of the ABCA4 gene.
  • STGD3 is autosomal dominant but uncommon.
  • STGD4 is autosomal dominant but uncommon.

The patient presents with central vision loss which is out of proportion to examination findings, thus it can be confused with malingering. 

Investigations:

  • Fluorescein angiography: will show characteristic dark choroid due to the lipofuscin covering the RPE and thus obscuring the dye behind.
  • Electroretinogram (ERG): is normal in early stages because it mainly represents rods and cones function which are not involved here.
  • Electrooculogram (EOG): is abnormal due to the involvement of RPE.

Treatment:

Vitamin A should be avoided because it will worsen lipofuscin accumulation. Gene therapy is done in the early stages. General protective measures like protection from excessive high-energy light exposure may be particularly important.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins play a role in Kreb's cycle?

choices.text: Vitamins B1, B2, B3 and B5
Vitamins B1, B3, B6 and B12
Vitamins B2, B3, B5 and B6
Vitamins B3, B6, B12 and B5

questions.solution:
Vitamins B1, B2, B3, and B5 of the vitamin B complex play a role in Kreb's cycle.

The following vitamins serve as cofactors for various enzymes of the tricarboxylic acid(TCA) cycle –

  • Vitamin B1: Thiamine
    • Active form - thiamine diphosphate
    • Cofactor for decarboxylation step of alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex.
  • Vitamin B2: Riboflavin
    • Active form - FAD (flavin adenine dinucleotide)
    • Cofactor for succinate dehydrogenase
  • Vitamin B3: Niacin
    • Active form - NAD+ (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide)
    • Cofactor for isocitrate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and malate dehydrogenase complex
  • Vitamin B5: Pantothenic acid
    • Active form - as a part of coenzyme A
    • Cofactor for esterified to the carboxylic acid residues, i.e. acetyl-CoA and succinyl-CoA.

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

Related Pearl: Active Forms and Functions of Water-Soluble Vitamins

Vitamin

Coenzyme

Name

Function

B1(Thiamin)

Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)

Decarboxylation

Transketolase reaction

B2(Riboflavin)

Flavin-adenine-dinucelotide (FAD)

Hydrogen Transfer

B3(Nicotinic acid, niacin)

Nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide(NAD+)

Hydrogen Transfer

B5(Pantothenic acid)

Coenzyme A

Transfer of an acyl group

B6(Pyridoxine)

Pyridoxal Phosphate(PLP)

Transamination

Decarboxylation

Co-factor of glycogen phosphorylase

B7(Biotin)

Biotin

Carboxylation

B9(Folic acid)

Tetrahydrofolic acid (THFA)

Donor of methyl/formyl group

B12(Cobalamin)

Methylcobalamin and Adenosylcobalamin

Co-factor of methionine synthase and methylmalonyl CoA mutase

C (Ascorbic acid)

 Ascorbic acid and dehydroascorbic acid

Oxidation-reduction

questions.text:
Given below are the 3 Mullerian malformations. What will be the status of paramesonephric ducts, respectively to give rise to these malformations?
  1. Bicornuate uterus
  2. Didelphys uterus
  3. Septate uterus
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option A: Partially fused, unfused, fused

Mullerian malformations  Status of paramesonephric ducts 
1. Didelphys uterus Unfused
2. Bicornuate uterus Partially fused
3. Septate uterus Fused but septum persists

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presented with seizures and her radiological image is given below. The MR spectroscopy of the lesion showed elevated choline, alanine, and lactate. Which of the following statement is true regarding the organism involved?

choices.text: Pigeon droppings are a source of infection

questions.solution:
The given radiological image and history of seizures suggest a diagnosis of neurocysticercosis. And the correct statement is eggs are the infective form.

Neurocysticercosis presents with seizures, hydrocephalus, and raised ICP, and may even cause signs of chronic meningitis. The image in the question shows multilobulated cystic lesions (with scolex) in the subarachnoid space, typical parenchymal brain calcifications are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by Taenia solium (Cysticercosis cellulose). 

Cyst with a dot sign (below image) is seen in both MRI and CT, and the dot represents the eccentrically placed scolex of the parasite.

MR Spectroscopy features of neurocysticercosis include elevated lactate, alanine, succinate, and choline levels and reduced levels of N -acetyl aspartate and creatine. Escobar's pathological stages describe 4 stages - vesicular, colloidal vesicular, granular nodular, and nodular calcified. 

Other options:

Option A: Cat is the definitive host for toxoplasmosis.

Option C: Pigeon droppings can cause cryptococcosis.

Option D: Larval stage, which is present in undercooked pork, causes intestinal taeniasis. Autoinfection plays a role in neurocysticercosis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman came with complaints of bloating,  recurrent abdominal pain for more than 6 months. The frequency of this has increased to 1 day per week for the last 3 months and pain is relieved with defecation. There is a hardening of stools since her symptoms have started.  Laboratory investigations are unremarkable.  All the following drugs can be prescribed for her condition except?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a female presenting with recurrent abdominal pain for more than 6 months with increased frequency of one episode per week for the last 3 months, pain relived during defecation, hardening of stools are suggestive of constipation-predominant irritable bowel disease (IBS).  Among the given drugs, alosetron is prescribed for diarrhea-predominant IBS while all others are used for constipation dominant IBS.

Alosetron is a 5HT-3 receptor antagonist. 5HT-3 receptors enhance the sensitivity of afferent neurons projecting from the gut. Alosetron reduces the perception of painful visceral stimulation in IBS. It also induces rectal relaxation, increases rectal compliance, and delays transit from the colon. 

Lubiprostone (option A) is a chloride channel activator. It promotes the secretion of water and chloride into the bowel and improves bowel movements. It is effective in the treatment of constipation predominant IBS.

Linaclotide (option C) is a minimally absorbed 14-aminoacid peptide guanylate cyclase-C (GC-C) agonist. They bind and activate GC-C on the luminal surface of the intestinal epithelium. This triggers the secretion of fluid, sodium, and bicarbonate into the lumen.

Psyllium husk (option D) is fiber supplementation that helps to improve the stool pattern and abdominal pain in constipation dominant IBS. They tend to produce less bloating and rectal distension. 

IBS is a functional bowel disorder. It is characterized by abdominal pain or discomfort and altered bowel habits in the absence of detectable structural abnormalities. Diagnosis is based on ROME IV criteria. 

IBS can be presented in any age group. However, most of the patients have their symptoms before 45 years of age. They are predominantly present in females. 

Alteration in bowel habits is the consistent clinical feature in IBS. Alternating constipation and diarrhea with one of these symptoms predominating are the most common pattern seen in IBS. 

Patients with constipation-predominating IBS can have weeks or months of constipation interrupted with brief periods of diarrhea. 

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient with a category-II dog bite presents to the trauma center on 2nd September 2022. After the local wound management, the patient has been prescribed a schedule for rabies vaccine administration. He marks the days in a calendar as shown below when he is supposed to take the vaccine.  Which regimen is likely prescribed to the patient? What is the route of administration in this case?
questions.solution:
The regimen prescribed here is the Essen regimen which is intramuscular.

Post-exposure prophylaxis regimen for rabies:

Intramuscular regimen: In this regimen, 1 ml or 0.5 ml of vaccine is injected into the deltoid in patients with category II and III wounds.

  • Essen regimen: It is a 5-dose regimen in which 1 dose of vaccine is given on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 each. (1,1,1,1,1)
  • Thai Red Cross regimen: It is a 4-dose multisite regimen in which 2 doses of vaccine are given on day 0, 3, 7, 28 each. (2-2-2-0-2)

Intradermal regimen: In this regimen, 0.1 ml of injection is given at 2 sites on days 0, 3, 7, and 28 each.

The following measures should be taken immediately to stop the contraction of rabies:

  • Cleansing- The most important step in the prevention of rabies is washing the affected area with plenty of soap and water under a running tap for 15 minutes. This is a standard procedure that minimises the contraction of rabies.
  • Chemical treatment- Irrigation of the wound should be done with virucidal agents like alcohol, tincture, 0.01% solution of aqueous iodine, or povidone-iodine. Even irrigating the wound with cetrimide + chlorhexidine solution can be done. This process eliminates the residual virus in the wound.
  • Suturing- Bite wounds are not sutured generally. If suturing is necessary, it is done after 24-48 hours under the cover of local infiltration of the rabies immunoglobulin which is generally done in category III wounds.
  • Other measures- Local antibiotics and tetanus toxoids should be given.

Different wound categories for post-exposure prophylaxis:

Categories of wound Post-exposure prophylaxis
Category I - touching or feeding animals, licks on intact skin None
Category II - nibbling of uncovered skin, minor scratches, or abrasions
without bleeding		 Immediate vaccination and
local treatment of the wound
Category III- single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, licks on broken skin contacts with bats Immediate vaccination and
administration of rabies
immunoglobulin; local
treatment of the wound

 

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: In 1970, the World Medical Association adopted a resolution on therapeutic abortion known as:
questions.solution:
The Declaration of Oslo (1970) is related to therapeutic abortion.

Other options:

  • Declaration of Alma-Ata: Identified primary health care as the key to the attainment of the goal of Health for All
  • Declaration of Tokyo: related to torture and other degradation
  • Declaration of Helsinki: concerned with Human experimentation.

Related Pearl: Health-related International Declarations:

  1. Declaration of Alma-Ata (1978): Identified primary health care as the key to the attainment of the goal of Health for All.
  2. Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion (1986): The aim of the conference was to continue to  achieve the objectives of the World Health Organization (WHO) Health for all by the year 2000.

3. Declaration of Oslo (1970): Related to therapeutic abortion.

4. Declaration of Tokyo (1975): Guidelines for medical doctors concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detention and imprisonment. (T – Tokyo – Torture)

5. Declaration of Helsinki (1975): Related to human experimentation. (H – Helsinki – Human experimentation)

6. Declaration of Geneva (1948): Most recent amendment was done on October 14, 2017 in Chicago. It gives the modern version of the 2500-year-old Hippocratic Oath which laid down the fundamental principles of medical ethics that any physician should follow.

7. Declaration of Malta (1991, revised in 1992): Related to hunger strikes.

8. Declaration of Lisbon: Related to rights of the patients like right to information, confidentiality, dignity, freedom of choice etc.

9. Declaration of Sydney on human death: It stated that the determination of death “will be based on clinical judgment, supplemented if necessary by a number of diagnostic aids”, emphasising the EEG. Nonetheless, it asserted that “the overall judgment of the physician” could not be replaced by any ancillary test.

The statement also recommended that two or more physicians should make the diagnosis of death when organs were removed for transplantation.

10. Declaration of Istanbul: To address the urgent and growing problems of organ sales, transplant tourism and trafficking in organ donors in the context of the global shortage of organs.

11. Declaration of Taipei: Related to ethical considerations regarding health databases and biobanks.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with sensory neuropathy. His history is significant for taking an off-the-counter vitamin B6 supplement in large doses. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this vitamin?

choices.text: It causes prostaglandin mediated cutaneous flushing
It is useful in the management of Homocystinuria
Erythrocyte transaminase assay is used for assessing it's nutritional status
It's deficiency plays a role in the development of hormone-dependent cancers

questions.solution:
Excess Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) causes sensory neuropathy as given in the scenario. The incorrect statement regarding vitamin B6 is it causes prostaglandin-mediated cutaneous flushing. Niacin causes prostaglandin-mediated cutaneous flushing.

The B-complex vitamins which cause toxicity:

  • Niacin - it causes prostaglandin mediated cutaneous flushing, fulminant hepatitis (most fatal manifestation), and glucose intolerance
  • Pyridoxine - it causes sensory neuropathy.

Other options:

Option B: Vitamin B6 - Pyridoxine is a cofactor in the synthesis of cystathionine from homocysteine. Classic homocystinuria is due to cystathionine synthase deficiency which leads to elevated homocysteine levels. It promotes oxidative damage, inflammation and endothelial dysfunction. Supplementation of vitamin B6 has been shown to reduce the level of circulating homocysteine. 

Option C: Vitamin B6 status can be assessed by assaying erythrocyte transaminase which is activated by pyridoxal phosphate.

Option D: The active form of Vitamin B6 is pyridoxal phosphate and it removes the hormone-receptor complex from DNA binding, terminating the action of the hormones. In vitamin B6 deficiency, there is increased sensitivity to even low concentrations of steroid hormones(estrogen, androgen, cortisol) leading to the development of hormone-dependent cancer ( breast, uterus, and prostate).

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

The concept for treatment:

  • Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.
  • As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

Related Pearl: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

Vitamin

Assay and test

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)

RBC Trans-ketolase

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)

RBC glutathione reductase

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

RBC transaminase

Vitamin B9 (Folic acid)

FIGLU excretion/Histidine load test

Vitamin B12 (Cobalamine)

Serum methyl malonate level

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Beriberi

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Cheilosis, Magenta-coloured tongue, 

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Niacin (B3)

Pellagra

Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Pyridoxine (B6)

Microcytic anemia, convulsions, depression

Biotin (B7)

Relatively unknown

Dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, alopecia, paraesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, hallucinations

Folic acid (B9)

Megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, neural tube defects, atrophic glossitis

Cobalamin (B12)

Pernicious anemia, dementia, spinal cord degeneration, homocysteinemia

Ascorbic acid (C)

Scurvy

Ecchymosis, bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, joint effusion, Scorbutic rosary

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female patient presents with weakness and dizziness. She has low blood pressure, but no diarrhea or fever. She has a history of vitiligo and Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Her examination findings and investigations are given below. Which of the following is the reason for her adrenal insufficiency?

Lab results show: 

Cortisol level- low, ACTH level- raised

Serum Electrolytes Values Normal Range
Sodium (mmol/L)  130  135-145 
Chloride (mmol/L)  100 95-105
Potassium (mmol/L)  5.3 3.5-5 
Bicarbonate (mmol/L)  20 18-22
questions.solution:
This patient with weakness, low blood pressure, hyperpigmentation, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and raised ACTH levels with decreased cortisol levels points to a diagnosis of primary adrenal insufficiency. The most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency is autoimmune adrenal insufficiency, especially in this patient as she has other underlying autoimmune conditions such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis and vitiligo. 

Primary adrenal insufficiency Secondary adrenal insufficiency
Decreased cortisol and elevated ACTH Decreased cortisol and ACTCH
Hyperpigmentation present Hyperpigmentation absent
Causes: Autoimmune, TB, adrenal metastasis Causes: Chronic glucocorticoid therapy, pituitary lesions


Primary adrenal insufficiency:

The common causes of Addison’s disease are:

  • Tuberculosis in developing countries
  • Autoimmune (Idiopathic atrophy) in developed countries
  • Metastasis to adrenal glands

Clinical features - lethargy, weight loss, nausea/vomiting, hyperpigmentation in an exposed area, postural hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, eosinophilia, and hypoglycemia may be seen.

Diagnosis - Cosyntropin stimulation test, plasma ACTH and cortisol levels, plasma renin and aldosterone levels.

Treatment - glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and androgen replacement therapy.

Other options:

Options B and D - are both causes of secondary adrenal insufficiency. 

Option C - Adrenal metastasis is rare compared to autoimmune causes. Additionally, the metastatic disease will have signs of the primary tumor, weight loss, etc.

Related Pearl: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Anatomical destruction of gland
  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)
  • Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)
  • Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi
  • Surgical removal
  • Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)
  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic agents – mitotane
  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole
  • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)
  • X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

  • Neoplasm
  • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
  • Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

  • By endogenous steroids from tumor
  • By exogenous steroids

questions.text: What is this postmortem ocular finding shown in the image below known as? How will you be able to see this finding?
questions.solution:
The image shows the fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels known as the Kevorkian sign. It occurs due to the loss of blood pressure and can be seen only through an ophthalmoscope. This sign lasts for about 1 hour.

Tache noir is a black-colored deposition of cell debris, and mucous on the sclera that occurs within 3-4 hours of death, which can be seen through the naked eye. 

Initially, yellow-colored triangles appear on either side of the cornea with the apex pointing towards the canthus. The color then progressively changes to brown and black, followed by wrinkling of the surface.

Image of Tache noir is seen below:

 
Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:
  • Loss of corneal reflex
  • Flaccidity of eyeballs occurs due to a reduction in intraocular pressure (IOP). IOP reaches zero at the end of 2 hours after death
  • Dilatation of pupil due to relaxation of muscles of the iris
  • Increased potassium concentration in vitreous up to 100 hours following death.

questions.text: Which of the following images represents a surgeon's knot?
questions.solution:
The surgeon's knot is portrayed in image 3. 

In the given image:

  1. Half-hitch knot
  2. Extra half-hitch on square
  3. Surgeon's knot
  4. Granny's knot

The surgeon's knot is a square knot that contains a double turn in the first throw. A "throw" is a complete twist of two strands in the square knot. The double turn makes the first throw of the surgeon's knot less likely to slip while the second throw is being tied. It is used when added security is required. A two-throw technique prevents slippage.

A granny knot is a slip knot which is two throws of the same type. It is used to achieve the right tension and is followed by the reef knot for security. An Aberdeen knot is used for the final knot during continuous sutures.

An image showing standard knotting formations is given below.

questions.text: A woman just delivered a term baby girl and both the mother and the child are doing well following the cesarean delivery. The next morning, however, the baby started having trouble breathing and was shifted to the NICU. The chest X-ray is shown below. On the radiograph, you note streaky, perihilar linear densities and fluid in the horizontal fissure. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Benign respiratory distress in a newborn with a chest X-ray showing fluid in the interlobar fissure is indicative of transient tachypnoea of newborn (TTN), also known as retained fetal lung liquid syndrome.

It is more common after a term, cesarean delivery and is due to the delayed clearance of the lung fluid from the interstitium into the pulmonary lymphatics.

The management of TTN is supportive oxygen therapy in the range of 30-40% and observation. 

Other findings of chest x-ray imaging are prominent (perihilar) pulmonary vascular markings, increased interstitial markings, and a “wet silhouette” around the heart. 

Other options :

Option B : A preterm baby with more severe features within 6 hours of birth would have pointed towards Respiratory distress syndrome. The Xray in such cases shows air bronchogram.

Option C : Meconium aspiration syndrome commonly affects post-term babies and only 15% of term deliveries. Also the Xray here will show patchy inflitrates, atelectasis and bulla in some areas.

Option D : Brochopulmonary dysplasia usually occurs following more than 40% concentration oxygen administration which is toxic to lungs.The Xray shows a spongelike appearance here.

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presented with progressive worsening of vision. He said that he has been having recurrent falls lately. MRI brain showed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given MRI images (midsagittal) show the hummingbird sign. The clinical features of this patient combined with the MRI findings are suggestive of progressive supranuclear palsy. It occurs due to characteristic atrophy of the midbrain with relative preservation of the pons. 

Progressive supranuclear palsy is also known as Steele–Richardson–Olszewski syndrome. It is characterized by:

  • Slow ocular saccades
  • Eyelid apraxia
  • Restricted eye movements
  • Downward gaze is predominantly impaired
  • Early gait disturbance and falls

Tau deposition most prominent in subcortical structures is seen.

The MRI image below shows the hummingbird sign:

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct ascending order of half-lives of the following radioisotopes?
questions.solution:
The correct ascending order of half lives of the given radioisotopes is Iodine 131, Iodine 125, Iridium 192, Cobalt 60.

Iodine 125 60 days
Iridium 192 74 days
Cobalt 60 5.2 years

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the criteria that is used to prioritize liver transplantation in a 10-year-old female child with end-stage liver disease?
questions.solution:
PELD score (Pediatric End-Stage Liver Disease) is used to determine the prognosis and to prioritize recipients of liver transplantation for children younger than 12 years of age. Serum sodium is not a component of the PELD Score.

PELD Score (Pediatric End-Stage Liver Disease) is similar to the MELD score, but for children. It determines prognosis and prioritizes recipients of liver transplantation. It includes both clinical and biochemical factors. It is predictive of disease severity and waiting list mortality in pediatric patients. The PELD score is calculated using the following variables:

  • Albumin (g/dl)
  • Bilirubin (mg/dl)
  • INR
  • Growth failure (based on gender, height, and weight)
  • Age at listing

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text:
Given below are the 3 employees working in different occupations. Based on the description given, identify the correct statement pertaining to the ESI act.

Employee 1: He works in a mine, earning Rs. 20,000/- per month, and is diagnosed with TB.

Employee 2: He works in a newspaper establishment earning Rs. 10,000/- per month, and is diagnosed with TB.

Employee 3: She works in a restaurant, earns Rs. 15,000/- per month, and is pregnant.

choices.text: Employee 1 doesn't get any benefit under the ESI act
Employee 2 gets extended sickness benefit at 70% of daily wages for 91 days
Employee 3 gets maternity benefit at 90% of daily wages for 26 weeks
All the 3 employees are not eligible to get any benefit under ESI act

questions.solution:
The answer is Option A: Employee 1 doesn't get any benefit under the ESI act.

Under ESI Act:

Employee 1: He doesn't get any benefit under ESI act as mining sector is not covered.

Employee 2: He gets extended sickness benefit for TB at 80% of daily wages for 2 years.

Employee 3: She gets maternity benefit at full wages for 26 weeks.

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)- It is applicable to all factories in India but not the defense, railway, and mining sectors.

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

The benefits of the ESI act are:

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – the benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/- is given.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependents, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

 

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: An old lady slipped and fell and sustained a fracture of the upper limb. The procedure shown in the image below was used to reduce her fracture. The most likely fracture she had sustained was:
questions.solution:
The image shows traction, palmar flexion, and ulnar deviation. These steps are used in the reduction of Colle's fracture which is an extra-articular fracture of the distal radius. 

Colles' fracture occurs at the distal end of the radius, at the cortico-cancellous junction. The distal fragment shows dorsal displacement, dorsal tilt, lateral displacement and lateral tilt. This fracture is particularly common in post-menopausal women because of osteoporosis. The patient presents with pain and swelling of the wrist. On examination, there is classic dinner fork deformity.

Undisplaced Colles' fractures are managed by immobilization in a below-elbow plaster cast for 6 weeks. Displaced fractures are managed by closed manipulative reduction and immobilization in Colles' cast. The technique of reduction of Colles' fracture is as follows:

  • Disimpaction of the fracture fragments by longitudinal traction against counter traction provided by the assistant. 
  • The distal fragment is then pressed into palmar flexion followed by ulnar deviation.
  • The patient's hand is drawn into pronation, palmar flexion, and ulnar deviation.
  • A Colles' cast is then applied, extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, with the wrist in palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.

Surgical correction is advisable for comminuted fractures, especially in young adults where the dominant hand is involved. It can be with percutaneous K-wire fixation, external fixators, or locking compression plates.

The most common complication following Colles' fracture is stiffness of the adjacent joints. Other complications include malunion, carpal tunnel syndrome and Sudek's osteodystrophy.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.  

Related Pearl: Plaster casts and their uses:

  Name of cast   Usage

Risser’s cast

Turn-buckle cast

 Scoliosis 

Shoulder spica

questions.text:
Match the following hypolipidemic drugs with their mechanism of action(MOA):-
Drug MOA
1. Mipomersen a.Inhibtion of hormone sensitive lipase
2. Lomitapide b.Inhibition of NPC1L1

3. Ezetimibe

 c.Inhibition of microsomal triglyceride transfer
4. Niacin d.Degradation of apo B 100 mRNA
questions.solution:
The correct match is option C: 1-d; 2-c; 3-b; 4-a

Drug MOA
1. Mipomersen d.Degradation of apo B 100 mRNA
2. Lomitapide c.Inhibition of microsomal triglyceride transfer

3. Ezetimibe

 b.Inhibition of NPC1L1
4. Niacin a.Inhibition of hormone-sensitive lipase

Mipomersen is an antisense oligonucleotide that reduces the expression of apo B 100 protein by binding to mRNA of apo B 100 and causing its degradation. 

Lomitapide inhibits microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP), which is required for the transfer of triglycerides(Tgs) to proteins inside the liver. Failure of this transfer leads to a decreased combination of Tgs to proteins and thus decreased synthesis of Very low-density lipoprotein(VLDL).

Ezetimibe inhibits NPC1L1 which is a cholesterol transporter in the intestines and thereby decreases cholesterol absorption in the diet. This will lead to an increased expression of LDL-R on the surface of the liver for making cholesterol and thereby decreasing LDL levels.

Niacin inhibits Hormone-sensitive lipase(HSL) thereby decreasing lipolysis of triglycerides and decreasing free fatty acid transport to the liver. This in turn reduces new triglyceride synthesis in the liver and reduces the output of VLDL by the liver.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presents with a complaint of progressive hair loss over the past 6 months. On examination, she has areas of scarring alopecia with perifollicular erythema. She also has pruritic, polygonal, flat-topped, violaceous papules and plaques with Wickham's striae on her wrists and forearms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a clinical scenario of lichen planopilaris, characterized by scarring alopecia and the presence of typical lichen planus lesions characterized by pruritic, polygonal, flat-topped, violaceous papules and plaques with Wickham's striae.

Lichen planopilaris causes scarring alopecia. Scarring/ cicatricial alopecia is characterized by permanent destruction of hair follicles and irreversible hair loss.

Lichen planopilaris (LPP) is a type of follicular lichen planus. There are 3 types of follicular lichen planus, out of which LPP is the most common.

It is most commonly confined to the scalp and produces progressive cicatricial/ scarring alopecia. The proposed mechanism behind it is reduced expression of peroxisome proliferator‐activated receptor γ (PPAR‐γ) in hair follicles, causing their destruction and ultimately, scarring.

It can occur in isolation or in the presence of typical lichen planus lesions in other parts of the body.

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

Alopecia or hair loss can be classified as :

  1. Non-Scarring/Non-Cicatricial alopecia
  2. Scarring/Cicatricial alopecia 

Mnemonic for causes of non-scarring alopecia: THATS STD!

  • Tinea capitis(Non-Inflammatory Type  - grey patch and black dot types )
  • Hormonal - Hypothyroidism, Androgenetic alopecia
  • Anagen effluvium, Alopecia areata
  • Trichotillomania
  • Secondary syphilis (moth-eaten alopecia)
  • SLE(predominantly causes non-scarring alopecia but also can cause scarring alopecia)
  • Telogen effluvium
  • Deficiency of Zinc, Iron 

Mnemonic for causes of scarring alopecia: SF2L3

  • Scleroderma - Linear scalp morphea (en coup de sabre)
  • Favus and Kerion (Inflammatory Type of Tinea capitis)
  • Folliculitis decalvans
  • Lichen planopilaris
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Lupus erythematosis - discoid (DLE)
  • Pseudopelade of Brocq

questions.text: A 57-year-old female patient with end-stage kidney disease comes for a follow-up. An ECG is done which is shown below. Which of the following drugs is not likely to produce a similar ECG?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis based on the ECG showing tall, peaked T waves is hyperkalemia. The drug not causing hyperkalemia is Indapamide because it is a thiazide diuretic that can cause hypokalemia.

Hyperkalemia is defined as a serum potassium level of more than 5.5 mEq/L. 

Hyperkalemia can cause drastic conduction changes. It can be diagnosed by a sequence of changes affecting the ST-T segments and QRS complex. ST-T segment changes reflect a change in repolarization while QRS complex changes reflect a change in depolarization.

The ECG changes that can be seen in hyperkalemia depend on the extent of hyperkalemia. 

S. No. Serum potassium level ECG change
1 5.5 - 6.5 mEq/L tall, peaked T waves with 'tented' or 'pinched' shape
2 6.5 - 7.5 mEq/L loss of P waves
3 7.0 - 8.0 mEq/L widened QRS complex
4 > 8.0 mEq/L sine wave

Drugs that cause hyperkalemia include

  • angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors
  • angiotensin receptor blockers eg losartan (Option A)
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor blockers like spirinolactone, eplerenone(Option C), drospirenone
  • Epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) blockers like amiloride, triamterene.
  • Others: Trimethoprim(Option D), pentamidine, nafamostat

The most common cause of hyperkalemia is kidney failure. 

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following

  1. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective
  2. Administer regular insulin with dextrose. The insulin will reduce the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. The dextrose will counteract the hypoglycemic effects of insulin.
  3. Salbutamol nebulization will also shift potassium inside the cell.
  4. Remove potassium with calcium-based resins, diuretics, or hemodialysis.

questions.text:
On performing polysomnography in a patient, the waves of EOG, EEG, and EMG are seen arranged from above downwards, respectively. A stage of sleep that the marked area in the image depicts, is not involved in which of the following conditions?

EOG- Electroocoulography

EEG- Electroencephalography

EMG- Electromyography
questions.solution:
REM sleep is represented by the marked area in the given polysomnography. Night terrors occur during NREM sleep, not REM sleep.

The three zones in the given image represent EOG, EEG, and EMG, respectively. In the marked area,

  • EOG shows positive activity
  • EEG shows mixed waves
  • EMG shows minimal activity

This is characteristic of REM sleep.

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Events occurring during NREM stages 3 and 4:

Events

Description

Somnambulism

Sleepwalking

Sleep terror or Night terror

Also called pavor nocturnus.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

Nocturnal enuresis

Behavioral therapy is the mainstay.

Drugs like desmopressin and imipramine are used.

 

Events occurring in REM sleep:

Events

Description

Nightmares

Fearful sleep without autonomic disturbances that are well remembered in the morning.

TCAs may be used for treatment.

Nocturnal penile tumescence

A normal phenomenon that can be used to differentiate between psychogenic and organic impotence.

Narcolepsy

A disorder of the REM sleep characterized by disturbed sleep in the night, leading to excessive sleep in the morning.

Associated with symptoms such as cataplexy, hypnogogic and hypnopompic hallucination, and sleep paralysis.

 *Hypnogogic hallucinations are those that occur at the start of sleep and hypnopompic hallucinations are those that occur at the end of sleep.

 

Others:

Events

Description

Bruxism (teeth grinding)

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Frontal lobe epilepsy

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Sleep talking

Occurs in all stages of sleep and may accompany night terrors and sleepwalking.

Common in children.

No treatment is necessary.

questions.text: A biochemist is working on a study of enzyme activation in the fed and fasting state. He gives a dose of insulin to the study animal. Which of the following enzymes will be activated in response to this dose?
questions.solution:
Pyruvate dehydrogenase is highly active in the high insulin/well-fed/dephosphorylated state.

The rest of the enzymes are active in the phosphorylated state/low insulin/fasting state.

Fasting state / low insulin state :

Liver :

With a fall in the blood glucose levels, there is a fall in insulin levels with less uptake of glucose by muscle and adipose tissues. α-cells of the pancreas secrete glucagon which inhibits glycogen synthetase and in turn activates glycogen phosphorylase. This eventually releases glucose into the bloodstream intended for the use of the brain and RBCs. Glucagon stimulates the production of cAMP, activating cAMP-dependent protein kinase. This in turn inactivates phosphofructokinase-2 and activates fructose 2,6-bisphosphatase by phosphorylation.

Muscle: 

Acetyl-CoA formed by oxidation of fatty acids causes inhibition of pyruvate dehydrogenase consequently leading to an accumulation of pyruvate. It is then converted to alanine which is then transaminated back to pyruvate in the liver. This is used as a substrate for gluconeogenesis.

Adipose tissue:

A fall in insulin and an increase in glucagon leads to inhibition of lipogenesis and activation of hormone-sensitive lipase. This leads to a massive release of glycerol which serves as a substrate for gluconeogenesis in the liver. It is also utilised by the liver, heart, and skeletal muscle as metabolic fuel.

As fasting progresses, acetyl-CoA is used for the synthesis of ketone bodies which are utilised by skeletal and heart muscles and up to 20% of the brain's energy source. After 18 hours of fasting, amino acids from protein catabolism are utilized by the liver and kidneys for gluconeogenesis.

Related Pearl: Enzymes active in phosphorylated and dephosphorylated state

Phosphorylated state

(Low insulin)

Dephosphorylated state

(High insulin)
  • Fructose 2,6 bisphosphatase
  • PEP carboxykinase
  • Pyruvate carboxylase
  • Glycogen phosphorylase
  • Hormone-sensitive lipase
  • Phosphofructokinase
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Glycogen synthase
  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase
  • HMG CoA reductase

questions.text: A 50 years old man presenting with gastric outlet obstruction was referred to the cancer institute. He was diagnosed later as suffering from gastric carcinoma. What is the T stage of this tumor that has invaded the muscle fibers of gastric mucosa?
questions.solution:
The T stage of gastric cancer which has invaded the muscle fibers of gastric mucosa ie Muscularis mucosa is T1a.

Stage T2 is involvement of muscularis propria.

T1

Tumor invades lamina propria or muscularis mucosae

T1b

Tumor invades submucosa

T2

Tumor invades muscularis propria

T3

Tumor penetrates subserosal connective tissue without invasion of visceral peritoneum or adjacent structures

T4

Tumor invades serosa (visceral peritoneum) or adjacent structures

T4a

Tumor invades serosa (visceral peritoneum)

T4b

Tumor invades adjacent structures

Regional lymph nodes (N)

NX

N0

N1

N2

N3

N3a

questions.text: A patient with Alzheimer's disease needs treatment for an overactive bladder. Which drug is the best choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best choice for this patient is Trospium. 

For treatment of overactive bladder, we need anticholinergics, which will decrease detrusor contraction and thus promote filling of the bladder.

There are two types of anticholinergics useful for overactive bladder:-

  • Non-selective M receptor blockers:- Flavoxate, Festerodine, Oxybutynin, Tolterodine and Trospium
  • Selective M3 blockers :- Darifenacin and Solifenacin

In Alzheimer's disease, anticholinergics can worsen the presentation since the main pathogenesis in Alzheimer's disease is decreasing acetylcholine levels.

Trospium is a quaternary ammonium compound, which means it is lipid insoluble and thus can't cross the blood-brain barrier. Thus it doesn't have CNS side effects and can be safely used in patients with Alzheimer's disease.

Other drugs can cross the blood-brain barrier and thus can worsen the disease.

Related Pearl: Muscarinic antagonists indicated for detrusor instability/overactive bladder

Mechanism/Feature Drug
Direct smooth muscle relaxant  

Flavoxate

Oxybutynin
Bladder selective  

Tolterodine

Fesoterodine (prodrug)
Only quaternary compound   Trospium
M3 selective  

Darifenacin

Solifenacin

questions.text: A drug belonging to a class of cell cycle non-specific cytotoxic agents is known to cause hemorrhagic cystitis. Another drug belonging to the same class is more likely to produce veno-occlusive disease of the liver. Which of the following agent can be used to minimize the later side effect?
questions.solution:
The class of drugs mentioned in the question based on hemorrhagic cystitis is alkylating agents such as cyclophosphamide and Ifosfamide. Other members of this class like Busulfan cause veno-occlusive disease of liver and the drug that can minimize this adverse effect is Defibrotide.

Defibrotide is the only FDA-approved drug for treating veno-occlusive disease.It enhances the enzymatic activity of plasmin to hydrolyse fibrin clots. It increases tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) and thrombomodulin expression and decreases von Willebrand factor (vWF) and plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 (PAI-1) expression, thus, reducing activation of endothelial cells and increasing fibrinolysis mediated by them.

Other options :

Option B : Mesna is used to treat hemorrhagic cystitis since it conjugates with acrolein (the substrate causing the adverse effect) and removes it in urine.

Option C : Amifostine is used to reduce the nephrotoxic effect of cisplatin.

Option D : Dexrazoxane is used to reduce the cardiotoxic effect of anthracyclines.

Related Pearl: Classification of antineoplastic drugs

Alkylating agents

Nitrogen mustards

  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Ifosfamide
  • Mechlorethamine
  • Melphalan
  • Chlorambucil
  • Bendamustine

Nitrosoureas

  • Carmustine
  • Lomustine
  • Semustine
  • Streptozocin

  • Procarbazine
  • Dacarbazine
  • Temozolomide

The image shown is the new logo of the 360-degree holistic Family Planning Campaign.

questions.text: The intravenous pyelogram of a patient with persistent flank pain is given below. What is the most likely condition associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows medial deviation of bilateral ureters giving the appearance of a narrow-waisted maiden. Hence, this is called the maiden waist sign and is seen in retroperitoneal fibrosis. It is associated with IgG4 related systemic disease.

This is an uncommon fibrotic reaction in the retroperitoneum that typically presents with ureteral obstruction. In this condition, there is a medial drawing of the ureter due to the deposition of fibrous tissue in the lumbosacral junction. 

The following images show the maiden waist sign (A) as compared to a normal IVP (B).

Other options:

Option A: PKD1 mutation is seen in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).

Option C: Aberrant blood supply to kidneys is seen in horseshoe kidney.

Option D: Persistent right posterior cardinal vein is seen in retrocaval ureter.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: The image given below depicts the structure of an inflammatory chemokine. Which of the following chemokine belongs to this class?
questions.solution:
The given image shows CX3C chemokines and the only known member of this class is Fractalkine.

Chemokines are a family of small proteins that act as chemoattractants for specific types of leukocytes. They are classified into four major groups, according to the arrangement of cysteine (C) residues in the proteins:

  • C-X-C chemokines - The first two of the four conserved cysteine residues are separated by one amino acid residue. They are secreted by activated macrophages, endothelial cells, and other cell types. Their inducers include microbial products and cytokines like interleukin-­1(IL-1) and tumor necrosis factor (TNF). They cause activation and chemotaxis of neutrophils. IL­8 (CXCL8) is typical of this group. 
  • C-C chemokines have the first two conserved cysteine residues adjacent to each other. They mainly act on monocytes, eosinophils, basophils, and lymphocytes, and have fewer actions on neutrophils. Important C-C chemokines are monocyte chemoattractant protein, eotaxin and macrophage inflammatory protein-1α. 
  • C chemokines lack first and third of the four conserved cysteines. The C chemokines (lymphotactin) are relatively specific for lymphocytes.
  • CX3C chemokines have three amino acids between the two cysteines. fractalkine is the only known member of this class. It acts as a chemoattractant and promotes the strong adhesion of monocytes and T cells.

questions.text: In a modern sewage treatment plant, a light green oxidized flocculent material is formed after secondary treatment with the trickling filter method. This material is called as____.
questions.solution:
The light green oxidized sewage formed after secondary treatment (trickling filter method) is called humus. It is then led towards the secondary sedimentation.

Other options:

Option B- Sludge is the organic matter that settles down in the tank during the sedimentation step of the primary treatment of sewage.

Option C- The effluent, formed from the primary sedimentation tank, contains a proportion of organic matter in solution or colloidal state and numerous living organisms.

Option D-Sullage is the waste water that doesn't contain human excreta.

Related Pearl: Modern Sewage Treatment

Primary treatment:

  • Screening
    • A large metal screen is used to intercept large floating objects like dead animals, wood, rags, etc., so as to prevent clogging
  • Grit chamber
    • It is also called detritus chamber
    • It allows for the settlement of heavier solids like gravel or sand and permits the organic matter to flow through
    • The grit that is collected at the bottom is then disposed of
  • Primary sedimentation
    • In a primary sedimentation tank, sewage is allowed to flow slowly so that suspended matter that sediments form sludge which is then removed
    • Biological action takes place here and breaks down complex organic solids
    • Scum in the form of grease and fat collects on top of the tank
    • Sometimes, chemicals like lime are added to the effluent to enhance precipitation

Secondary treatment:

The effluent from the primary sedimentation tank is subjected to aerobic oxidation by trickling filter method or activated sludge process.

  • Trickling filter method
    • The trickling or percolating filter is a bed of crushed stones or clinker
    •  Effluent from the primary sedimentation tank is spread over the filter bed and as it percolates through it, it gets oxidized by bacterial flora. There is no actual filtration that occurs.
    • The oxidized sewage forms a light green material called humus. It is then led into secondary sedimentation tanks.
  • Activated sludge process
    • The heart of the activated sludge process is the aeration tank
    • In these tanks, the effluent from primary sedimentation is mixed with activated or return sludge (sludge from the final settling tank) and is then exposed to aeration for 6 to 8 hours.
    • During aeration, organic matter is oxidized into carbon dioxide, nitrates and water with the help of aerobic bacteria in the activated sludge.
  • Secondary sedimentation
    • From the trickling filters or aeration tanks, the oxidized sewage is allowed into a secondary sedimentation tank where it is held for 2 – 3 hours
    • Here, aerated sludge or activated sludge is formed, part of which is pumped back into an aeration tank
  • Sludge digestion
    • Sludge digestion can be done by incubating it under favourable conditions to allow anaerobic auto-digestion. This is done in sludge digestion tanks.
    • Disposal of sludge is also done by sea disposal
    • Sludge can also be disposed of by composting with solid refuse
  • Disposal of effluent
    • Disposal of effluent can be done by dilution in water bodies which has to then be chlorinated
    • Disposal on land is possible if the effluent can be used for irrigation purposes

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, chills, and rigor. The fever has a characteristic periodicity of 48 hours. Maurer's clefts are seen in erythrocytes infected with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Erythrocytes infected with Plasmodium falciparum show Maurer's cleft. These are coarse brick red dots inside the infected erythrocytes.

Plasmodium falciparum causes malignant tertian malaria. This means that the fever has a periodicity of 48 hours corresponding to one cycle of erythrocytic schizogony. Malignant because it is a more serious and fatal type of malaria.

The image below shows Maurer's cleft.

Apart from this, the ring forms of parasite are usually seen in peripheral blood film. They arrange themselves in a stereo headphone shape. They are also known as accole form.

Related Pearl: Difference between plasmodium species

Gametocyte Spherical, fills the cell Similar to but smaller than vivax Crescent, Banana shaped Similar to but smaller than vivax

questions.text: A 6-year-old child, weighing 20 kg presents to the emergency room with partial to full-thickness burns covering 20% of his total body surface area. As per the ATLS guidelines, the volume of fluids that need to be administered over 24 hours in this patient is?
questions.solution:
The child needs fluid resuscitation with 1.2 L of ringer lactate in 24 hours. 

According to the 10th Edition of ATLS (2018), fluid resuscitation in a pediatric patient < 14 years should begin at 3 ml of lactated Ringer’s x % TBSA x patient’s body weight in kg for second and third-degree burns. 

In this case, 20 (% TBSA) x 20 (body weight in kg) x 3 = 1200ml

Therefore, the total volume of RL to be given is 1.2 litres.

Note:

The superficial/1st-degree burns are not considered for the formula. Only the % TBSA of 2nd and 3rd-degree burns is calculated for the formula.

The goal of resuscitation is to maintain a fine balance of adequate perfusion as indicated by urine output. It is important to understand that formulas provide a starting target rate; subsequently, the amount of fluids provided should be adjusted based on a urine output target of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults and 1 mL/kg/hr for children weighing less than 30 kg.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

Related Pearl: Wallace's rule of 9

questions.text: An elderly man presents with acute chest pain. He was diagnosed with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction and later died from sudden cardiac death. An autopsy was conducted which showed the following cells in the vessel wall of his left main coronary artery. These cells would have ingested which substance?
questions.solution:
The cells marked in the image above are the foam cells in atheromatous plaques and they ingest lipoproteins. They are known as lipid-laden monocytes/ macrophages or smooth muscle cells within the plaques.

These cells ingest lipoproteins accumulated within the intima of the vessel wall. Since these lipoproteins are modified due to the action of inflammatory mediators, they cannot be degraded further within these cells. This leads to the accumulation of modified lipids within these cells converting them to foam cells.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with depression, being treated with phenelzine came to the emergency department with headache, nausea, vomiting, and diaphoresis following dinner at the restaurant. On examination, his BP is 190/120.  The patient is diagnosed with a cheese reaction. Consumption of any of the following foods could have caused cheese reaction except:
questions.solution:
Cheese reaction is seen on the consumption of tyramine-rich foods such as cheese, red wine, aged meat, fish, etc. Apples do not cause a cheese reaction.

Cheese reaction occurs in patients being treated with MAO inhibitors who consume tyramine-rich foods. Inhibition of the MAO-A isoform prevents the metabolism of dietary tyramine in the gut, thus allowing intact tyramine to enter circulation. A hypertensive crisis occurs as a result of a powerful pressor effect of tyramine. 

The hypertensive crisis in cheese rection is treated with phentolamine.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman is brought to the ER after she faints at home. Her husband says that she is very body-conscious and does intermittent fasting. She has been on a vegan diet for the past 2 months. Lab values are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 6 g/dL

MCV - 67 fL

MCH - 24 pg

RDW - elevated

TIBC - high

Peripheral smear - target cells noted
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of iron deficiency anemia due to the following findings: 

  • Low MCV (N: 87-96 fL) 
  • Low MCH (N: 27-33 pg)
  • Elevated RDW 
  • High TIBC

Option A: Anemia of chronic disease is associated with low TIBC.

Options B and D: Anemia due to B12 and folate deficiency presents with a high MCV (macrocytosis).

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Alpha or beta thalassemia Anemia of Chronic Disease
Serum Iron <60 µg/dL Normal/Increased Decreased
Serum Ferritin <20 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased
MCV Decreased  Decreased Normal/Decreased
RBC count Decreased Normal/Increased Normal/Increased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity

questions.text: A 58-year-old pathologist presented to the Dermatology OPD with the following condition, which he described to be painless and non-tender but has been gradually progressing on the dorsum of the hand for the past 3 months. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: The causative organism invades through the exogenous route
Seen in patients with poor immunity

questions.solution:
Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis is seen in patients with moderate to high degree of immunity.

Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis or Warty Tuberculosis is caused by exogenous inoculation of M. tuberculosis into the skin through open wounds or abrasions. It is also known as ‘anatomist’s warts’, ‘prosector’s warts’ and ‘verruca necrogenica’.  It occurs in a person who is already sensitized by previous exposure to TB. Thus it is a form of post-primary TB. Patients having this condition have good immunity against TB. Because of good immunity, they are effective in clearing the TB bacilli and thus, the lesion is paucibacillary. This condition is treated with anti-tubercular drugs.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of cutaneous tuberculosis

The classification of cutaneous tuberculosis is based on the mode of acquisition.

Type Pathophysiology AFB

Exogenous

Through broken skin or mucosa
Tuberculous chancre Occurs in individuals with no previous sensitization to TB Multibacillary
Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis Occurs in previously sensitized individuals with strong immunity Paucibacillary

Endogenous

Direct spread from a focus of infection
Scrofuloderma Contiguous spread from affected parts like lymph nodes, joints Multibacillary
Periorificial tuberculosis Autoinoculation at mucocutaneous borders from infected secretions Multibacillary

Hematogenous

Spread from a distant primary focus of TB
Acute cutaneous miliary tuberculosis Occurs in severe disseminated TB Multibacillary
Lupus vulgaris Occurs in previously sensitized individuals with strong immunity. Mostly hematogenous spread, sometimes exogenous. Paucibacillary
Tuberculous gumma/ abscess Occurs in immunocompromised patients Multibacillary

Tuberculids

Hypersensitivity reaction
Lichen scrofulosorum (micropapular) Hematogenous spread of M. tuberculosis antigens to the skin causes type III hypersensitivity which triggers type IV reaction with granuloma formation Very rarely seen
Papulonecrotic tuberculid
Erythema induratum of Bazin (nodular)

questions.text: A female patient was diagnosed with Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy. She and her husband were concerned about their offspring having the same disease. A geneticist explains about the disease and its mode of inheritance to them with the following pedigree chart. What does it depict?

choices.text: All the daugthers of affected father have the disease.
All children of affected father have the disease.
No child of affected mother has the disease.
All children of affected mother have the disease.

questions.solution:
This pedigree chart depicts that all the children of the affected mother have the disease. The pattern of inheritance shown is mitochondrial inheritance. 

The unique feature of mitochondrial inheritance is maternal inheritance. The mitochondrial DNA of the zygote is completely derived from the ovum. Therefore, when the mother is affected and the father is normal, all their children will be affected. 

However, children will not be affected if they are born to a normal mother and an affected father. Only the daughters of the affected mother will further transmit the disease to the next generations.

 
Features of mitochondrial inheritance:
  • The mitochondrial DNA encodes enzymes required for oxidative phosphorylation. The organs of the central nervous system, skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, liver, and kidneys are affected as they are most dependent on oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Heteroplasmy is a phenomenon in which the individual has both wild-type and mutant type of mtDNA. 
  • The threshold effect is defined as a minimum number of copies of mutant mtDNA to be present in the mitochondria that can lead to oxidative dysfunction to manifest the disease.
  • The expression of the disease varies even among different cells of an organ. This is because there is a variable distribution of the normal and mutant mtDNA in the cells.

Related Pearl: Diseases of mitochondrial inheritance

  • Inherited exclusively from the affected mother
