questions.text:
A female patient presenting with a breast lump is suspected to have invasive breast cancer. There are certain benign breast conditions that serve as risk factors for this cancer. Arrange the following conditions from lowest to highest risk for developing invasive breast carcinoma.
  1. Duct ectasia
  2. Papilloma with fibrovascular core 
  3. Atypical ductal hyperplasia
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1< 2 < 3

  1. Duct ectasia: No increased risk
  2. Papilloma with fibrovascular core: 1.5-2 times risk
  3. Atypical ductal hyperplasia: 5 times risk

Related Pearl: Relative risk of invasive breast carcinoma

Relative risk of invasive breast carcinoma based on pathological examination of benign breast tissue (American College of Pathologists Consensus Statement):

  • No increased risk
    • Adenosis, sclerosing or florid
    • Apocrine metaplasia
    • Cysts, macro and/or micro
    • Duct ectasia
    • Fibroadenoma
    • Fibrosis
    • Hyperplasia
    • Mastitis (inflammation)
    • Periductal mastitis
    • Squamous metaplasia
  • Slightly increased risk (1-5 - 2times)
    • Hyperplasia, moderate or florid, solid or papillary
    • Papilloma with a fibrovascular core
  • Moderately increased risk (5 times)
    • Atypical hyperplasia (ductal or lobular)
  • Insufficient data to assign a risk
    • Solitary papilloma of lactiferous sinus
    • Radial scar lesion

questions.text:
Identify the correctly matched image showing clinical findings and the corresponding clinical class to which it belongs to under the 2020 revised CEAP classification of varicose ulcer.

CEAP: Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the correctly matched clinical finding with the corresponding clinical class as per the revised CEAP guidelines is B - Atrophie blanche (C4b).

Image A - shows tortuous dilated veins - C2

Image B - Atrophie blanche(C4b)  - localized white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and hyperpigmentation, usually seen around the ankle. This is a sign of severe chronic venous disease. Lipodermatosclerosis(C4b) is also under the same class. It is due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis leading to a tight, contracted, 'woody' leg. Can lead to contractures over the Achilles tendon and is a sign of severe chronic venous disease.

Image C - fan-shaped telangiectasia over ankle or foot is characteristic of corona phlebectatica which is classified as C4c under CEAP guidelines.

Image D - Shows venous ulcer with active crusts falling under healing venous ulcer classified as C5.

Varicose veins - are tortuous dilatation of veins due to venous insufficiency. It commonly presents as lower limb swelling with a sensation of heaviness, burning, and aching over the affected area or whole limb.

Diagnosis is majorly done using duplex ultrasound and very rarely involves MR venography or intravenous ultrasound(IVUS).

Treatment is achieved using modalities such as compression, laser ablation, endothermal ablation, radiofrequency ablation, endovenous glue, ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy, open surgery, etc. 

Recent 2020 update on the CEAP system includes the following changes -

  1. C2r for recurrent varicose veins
  2. C4c for Corona phlebectatica
  3. C6r for recurrent active venous ulcer.

Related Pearl: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

C0

C1

C2

C3

C4

Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary

to chronic venous disease

C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche

C4c-Corona phlebectatica

C5

Healed ulcer

C6

C6r

Recurrent active venous ulcer

Note:

  • The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.
  • Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
  • Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm
  • Varicose veins refer to dilated tortuous veins >3 mm in diameter

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of ataxic gait, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of normal pressure hydrocephalus.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a communicating hydrocephalus (non-obstructive hydrocephalus) caused by delayed resorption of cerebrospinal fluid. Meningeal scarring is seen in some patients, due to previous history of meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or head trauma.

It presents with the characteristic triad of:

  • Dementia (mostly executive function)
  • Ataxic or apractic gait
  • Urinary incontinence (sometimes urgency too)

On imaging, dilated lateral ventricles are seen. Lumbar puncture opening pressure is in the normal to high range.

Treatment includes ventricular shunting. Gait improves more than cognition.

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

Condition Features
Alzheimer’s disease
  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia
  • Stepwise decline
  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging
Frontotemporal dementia
(Pick’s disease)
  • Early personality changes
  • Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors
  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Visual Hallucination
  • Spontaneous parkinsonism
  • Fluctuating cognition
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Gait abnormalities 
  • Urinary Incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
(Prion disease)
  • Behavioral changes
  • Rapidly progressive
  • Myoclonus and/or seizures

questions.text: A  patient with cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with an altered sleep cycle. When asked to draw a star, the patient was not able to draw a perfect one. He appears agitated. On examination, flapping tremors were noted. Which of the following does not form a part of the treatment?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the clinical presentation is hepatic encephalopathy. Benzodiazepines should not be used in its treatment because they may worsen the condition.

Benzodiazepines increase the effects of γr-aminobutyric acid (GABA) neuroinhibitory transmitter by binding endogenous benzodiazepine receptors. This has an inhibitory effect on the brain, thus worsening hepatic encephalopathy.

The clinical features which point to hepatic encephalopathy are:

  1. Altered sleep-wake cycle- this is the earliest symptom
  2. Unable to draw a star - this points to constructional apraxia which is the earliest sign.
  3. Agitation
  4. Flapping tremors- also known as asterixis. It is negative myoclonus. Also seen in carbon monoxide poisoning, and renal encephalopathy. 

Treatment of hepatic encephalopathy includes:

  • Correction of precipitating factors
  • Lactulose - decreased GI transit time due to cathartic actions leading to increased elimination of ammonia
  • Rifaximin - lowers the blood ammonia levels
  • Zinc - serves as a co-factor for the urea cycle and thus stimulating it.
  • L-ornithine L-aspartate - stimulates the urea cycle, resulting in the loss of ammonia

questions.text: An intern is inserting a central venous catheter through femoral vein in a burns patient. During the procedure, he accidentally injures one of the structures in the femoral sheath. Which of the following structures is not likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The structure unlikely to be injured is the femoral nerve, as it is not the content of the femoral sheath.

The femoral sheath is divided into three compartments:

  • The lateral compartment contains the femoral artery
  • The intermediate compartment contains the femoral vein
  • The medial compartment, termed as femoral canal, contains lymphatic vessels, areolar tissue, and the lymph node of Cloquet.

questions.text: A patient had "Calabar swellings" and granulomas in the bulbar conjunctiva. Peripheral blood shows the following microfilaria. What is the vector for the following parasite?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a peripheral smear showing sheathed microfilaria with nuclei up to the tail tip is suggestive of Loa loa. The vector for Loa loa is Chrysops (mango fly).

Chrysops flies are day bitters and transmit third-stage larvae. The third-stage larvae reach various subcutaneous tissues and mature into adults where they reside. 

Calabar swellings are temporary foci of inflammation due to wandering parasites in subcutaneous tissues. Loa loa mainly causes ocular manifestations like granulomas in the conjunctiva, edema of eyelids etc. Thus it is also known as African eyeworm.

 The image below shows the difference between microfilaria of various filarial nematodes.

questions.text:
The illustrations given below represent two panels for the management of a diabetic patient with insulin: panel A and panel B.

You are provided with the four different preparations of insulin, namely,

  1. Regular insulin
  2. Insulin Glargine
  3. Neutral protamine hagedorn insulin
  4. Insulin Aspart

Which preparation and curve are used for basal level insulin maintenance?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option C- 3, yellow curve.

A graphical plot of various preparations of insulin vs time is as follows:

Yellow curve NPH insulin
Red curve Insulin Aspart  
Green curve Insulin glargine  
Dotted blue curve Regular insulin

Panel A shows the administration of long-acting Insulin glargine (green curve) to provide basal insulin and a premeal short-acting insulin analog (red curve).

Panel B shows a twice-daily injection of NPH insulin providing basal insulin (yellow curve) and regular insulin (dotted curve) or insulin analog (red curve) providing mealtime insulin coverage. Note that only one type of short-acting insulin would be used.

The insulin level attained following subcutaneous insulin (short-acting insulin analog) by an insulin pump programmed to deliver different basal rates would appear as below:

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presented with dyspnea. She does not have hoarseness of voice or change in voice. She underwent total thyroidectomy 2 days back. Laryngoscopy reveals the vocal cords to be in paramedian position. All of the following can be done in the management of this patient except:
questions.solution:
All of the above management options can be done in this patient except Thyroplasty type I that is medialization of the vocal cords.

The above clinical scenario of breathing difficulty with a good voice (no hoarseness), history of total thyroidectomy, and the laryngoscopy revealing the vocal cords in the paramedian position are suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury is often acute. Neuritis or surgical trauma (thyroidectomy) are the most important causes. Other causes include carcinoma thyroid, cervical lymphadenopathy, and carcinoma of the cervical esophagus. The vocal cords lie in the median or paramedian position due to the paralysis of all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx and the unopposed action of cricothyroid muscles. This leads to dyspnoea and stridor but the voice is good.

Treatment: Many cases of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy develop stridor and dyspnea that requires tracheostomy as an emergency procedure. Widening the respiratory airway without a permanent tracheostomy can be achieved by:

  • Lateralization of the vocal cords.
  • Thyroplasty type II- This creates a lateral expansion of the larynx similar to lateralization of the vocal cords.
  • Arytenoidopexy is the fixing of the arytenoid in the lateral position.
  • Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation)- This involves excising laterally the soft tissue at the junction of membranous cord and vocal process of arytenoid with laser.
  • Partial arytenoidectomy- This involves excision of the medial part of the arytenoid with laser.
  • Reinnervation procedures- Innervation of the paralyzed posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is achieved by implanting a nerve-muscle pedicle of sternohyoid or omohyoid muscle with its nerve supply from ansa hypoglossi.

Other options:

Option C- Thyroplasty type I that is medialization of the vocal cord is done in cases of complete paralysis (recurrent and superior laryngeal nerve paralysis). This is achieved by Teflon paste injection lateral to the paralysed cord or thyroplasty I procedure.

Related Pearl: Positions of the Vocal Cord

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker complains of cough, occasional chest pain, breathlessness and increased thirst  for the past 6 months. The radiological investigations revealed a centrally located tumor with the histopathology showing a characteristic finding as given below. What does this finding indicate?

choices.text: Basophilic staining of vessel wall by calcium
Eosinophilic staining of vessel wall by calcium
Eosinophilic staining of vessel wall by DNA
Basophilic staining of vessel wall by DNA

questions.solution:
The image given shows the basophilic staining of the vessel wall by DNA from necrotic tumor cells (azzopardi effect). The clinical scenario and the image point towards a diagnosis of small cell carcinoma of the lung. 

This tumor originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells (kulchitsky cells), which are present in the lining of the bronchial epithelium.

Histology of small cell lung carcinoma shows clusters of small cells with scanty cytoplasm, ill-defined borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. The cells are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent.

Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung include :

  • Cushing syndrome due to ACTH production.
  • Small cell lung cancer-associated SIADH is due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. It is associated with increased thirst and hyponatremia. It resolves within a month of initiation of chemotherapy.
  • Hypocalcemia - Due to the secretion of calcitonin.
  • Gynecomastia - Due to the secretion of gonadotropins.
  • Hypercalcemia - Due to the secretion of parathormone, parathyroid hormone-related peptide, prostaglandin E, and some cytokines.

Immunohistochemistry in Lung cancers:

  • Primary lung adenocarcinoma - Napsin-A, thyroid transcription factor (TTF-1).
  • Primary lung squamous cell carcinoma - p40, p63.
  • Primary small cell lung carcinoma - chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56.
  • Mesothelioma - CK5/6, calretinin, and Wilms tumor gene-1 (WT-1).

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

questions.text: Ashley's rule of 149 is used for sex determination using the length of _____ bone.
questions.solution:
Ashley's rule of 149 is used for sex determination using the length of the sternum. 

Ashley’s rule is used to know the sex from the sternum bone. It is also known as the 149 rule. According to Ashley's rule, the male sternum has a total length of >149 mm and the female sternum has a total length of <149 mm.

Features Male sternum Female sternum
Body Bigger, longer and more than 2x the length of the manubrium Shorter and less than 2x the length of the manubrium
Ashley’s rule Total length>149mm Total length <149mm
Level of the upper border At the level of the lower part of the body of 2nd thoracic vertebrae At the level of the lower part of 3rd thoracic vertebrae
manubrium smaller bigger
Sternal index 46.2 54.3

 Sternal index = Length of manubrium x 100/length of the body of sternum

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding the condition shown in the image below which is seen in a 2-month-old child with stridor.

choices.text: There is excessive flacidity of supraglottic larynx.
Flexible laryngoscopes are useful in diagnosis.

questions.solution:
The given image shows the omega-shaped epiglottis in a child with stridor, suggesting the diagnosis of laryngomalacia. The arytenoids are prominent in laryngomalacia.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis.  It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor is increased on crying but improves (decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding. The cry is normal.

Direct laryngoscopy shows -

  • Elongated epiglottis, curled upon itself (omega-shaped)
  • Floppy aryepiglottic folds, and 
  • Prominent arytenoids 

A flexible laryngoscope is very useful to make the diagnosis. Laryngomalacia cannot be visualized in a paralyzed patient.

Treatment:

  • conservative in most cases
  • Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

The below image shows the omega-shaped epiglottis.

questions.text: Dermatomyositis and polymyositis have a predilection for _____ and _____ muscles involvement, respectively.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is C-proximal, proximal.

Dermatomyositis and polymyositis both have a predilection for proximal > distal muscle involvement. Inclusion body myositis involves both proximal and distal muscles with a predilection for finger/wrist flexors/knee extensors.

questions.text: A 75-year-old diabetic patient presented to the emergency department with facial abnormalities and speech problems for 1.5 hours, which resolved later. He was diagnosed with a transient ischemic attack. The ABCD2 score used for the assessment of the risk of stroke, in this case, gives a score of '2' to which component?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option C-Duration: 1.5 hours.

Duration >60 minutes and unilateral weakness are the two components of the ABCD2 score which are given a score of '2'.

questions.text: A newborn baby is vaccinated against tuberculosis disease. All of the following are true about the vaccine except:

choices.text: The dose given at birth is 0.05 ml
Distilled water is preferred for reconstitution

questions.solution:
BCG vaccine is primarily used against tuberculosis disease. Normal saline is recommended for reconstituting the vaccine, as distilled water may cause irritation. Hence, option D is not true. 

BCG (bacillus of Calmette and Guerin) is the only live bacterial vaccine. The WHO has recommended the Danish 1331 strain for the production of the BCG vaccine. It protects against severe forms of childhood tuberculosis and tuberculous meningitis. It also reduces morbidity and mortality against primary tuberculosis.

There are two types of BCG vaccine: the liquid (fresh) vaccine and the freeze-dried vaccine. The freeze-dried vaccine is a more stable preparation (option B) than the liquid vaccine. Currently, the vaccine is distributed in the freeze-dried form because of better storage qualities. Normal saline is recommended for reconstituting the vaccine, as distilled water may cause irritation. The reconstituted vaccine may be used up within 3 hours.

The usual strength for vaccination is 0.1 mg in 0.1 ml volume. The dose given at birth (option A) and for newborns < 4 weeks of age is 0.05 ml. It is injected intradermally (option C) just above the insertion of the left deltoid muscle using a tuberculin syringe.  

A papule develops at the vaccination site after 2-3 weeks. It increases slowly in size and then subsides or breaks into a shallow ulcer after 5 weeks. Healing occurs spontaneously within 6 to 12 weeks, leaving a permanent, tiny, round scar, typically 4-8 mm in diameter. Usually, the individual becomes Mantoux-positive after 8-14 weeks. 

Complications include prolonged severe ulceration at the vaccination site, suppurative lymphadenitis, osteomyelitis, and disseminated infection. It should not be given to patients with generalized eczema, infective dermatosis, hypogammaglobulinemia, immunodeficiency state, or pregnancy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was referred to cardiology OPD for the management of hypertension. His BP was not controlled with spironolactone and laboratory investigations revealed hypokalemia & metabolic alkalosis. His BP comes down when spironolactone is replaced with amiloride. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a young patient with hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, responding to amiloride but not spironolactone, a diagnosis of Liddle syndrome (also known as pseudohyperaldosteronism) is most likely.

Liddle syndrome is due to the autosomal dominant gain of function mutation in epithelium sodium channel, ENaC, in collecting tubules. It classically causes hypertension in young patients, along with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. The disease responds to amiloride but is resistant to spironolactone. Although its presentation is similar to primary hyperaldosteronism, aldosterone is nearly undetectable in the serum due to negative feedback. Hence it is also known as pseudohyperaldosteronism.

Other options:

Option A: Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME) occurs due to the activation of mineralocorticoid receptors by cortisol, like in 11-β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency. It also presents with hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, but mineralocorticoid receptor blockade with spironolactone is successful in treating SAME. Spironolactone does not work in Liddle syndrome because the defect is downstream to where spironolactone acts.

Option C: Addison's disease refers to adrenal insufficiency and decreased levels of aldosterone. It presents with hyponatremic volume contraction (which may lead to hypotension), hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis.

Option D: Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive renal tubular reabsorption defect in Na+/K+/2Cl- channel. It causes hypokalemia, hypercalciuria, and metabolic alkalosis. But BP is usually low to normal. It mimics chronic loop diuretic use.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the fungus depicted in the image?
  1. It is a thermally dimorphic fungi
  2. It is also known as South American blastomycosis
  3. It causes desert rheumatism
  4. The yeast form is intracellular with broad base budding
questions.solution:
The image shows mold with septate hyphae resembling the shape of a barrel called anthroconidia, which is characteristic of Coccidioides immitis.

Statement 1 is true - It is a thermally dimorphic fungus. All the fungi causing systemic mycosis are thermally dimorphic i.e., exist in both yeast (at 37°C) and mold form (at 22-25°C) at different temperatures. 

Statement 2 is false - South American blastomycosis is another name for Paracoccidiomycosis. 

Statement 3 is true - Desert rheumatism is caused by Coccidioides immitis. It is also called valley fever. It is an influenza-like illness.

Statement 4 is false - Broad base budding yeast is found in Blastomyces dermatitidis.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.
